componenttext: Thanks, Deborah, and welcome everyone to today's call. As you can tell from our press release and from the commentary we posted on our website, Q4 was a great quarter. Over 1 million net new subscribers, strong earnings and a significant expansion in streaming. And as our guidance for 2010 indicates, we expect the momentum to continue. So with that, let's go directly to Q&A.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question is from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Is the bounty paid to the game platform manufacturers materially different than that paid to other customer acquisition channels. Is it higher or is it lower?
componenttext: The first question is from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Is the bounty paid to the game platform manufacturers materially different than that paid to other customer acquisition channels. Is it higher or is it lower?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steven, we don't disclose the individual deals as you probably would expect. But what you can see is that as we've expanded with the various CE platforms, including the game platforms, that our subscriber acquisition cost has continued to come down nicely
componenttext: Steven, we don't disclose the individual deals as you probably would expect. But what you can see is that as we've expanded with the various CE platforms, including the game platforms, that our subscriber acquisition cost has continued to come down nicely. So from that, you can intuit that there's no significant model shift.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question, also from Steven Frankel. Is the decline in SAC driven by more declining ad rates, increased brand awareness or reduction in the bounties you are paying for customer acquisition?
componenttext: Next question, also from Steven Frankel. Is the decline in SAC driven by more declining ad rates, increased brand awareness or reduction in the bounties you are paying for customer acquisition?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, it's Reed here. Mostly, brand awareness and the improvement in the product. The products, fundamentally the service, is better than it was two or three years ago because of the streaming. So that increased attractiveness makes it easier to sell, if
componenttext: Again, it's Reed here. Mostly, brand awareness and the improvement in the product. The products, fundamentally the service, is better than it was two or three years ago because of the streaming. So that increased attractiveness makes it easier to sell, if you will. That combined with the large scale that we're operating is what's driving down SAC, as opposed to some change, say, in the display ad markets or outside factors.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Final question from Steven Frankel. With HBO, Starz and Showtime so focused on original programming, do you expect that as their respective studio output deals come up for renewal, that they will be less willing to lay out large amounts of cash potentiall
componenttext: Final question from Steven Frankel. With HBO, Starz and Showtime so focused on original programming, do you expect that as their respective studio output deals come up for renewal, that they will be less willing to lay out large amounts of cash potentially opening up content for you to acquire?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's see. On the first part, they've had great success with episodic, first HBO, then Showtime and most recently, Starz, where Spartacus is just launched. That's been a huge success for Starz. It hasn't lowered their appetite for movies. As an example, H
componenttext: Let's see. On the first part, they've had great success with episodic, first HBO, then Showtime and most recently, Starz, where Spartacus is just launched. That's been a huge success for Starz. It hasn't lowered their appetite for movies. As an example, HBO pioneered episodic and I guess, probably seven, eight, nine years ago, and they've continued to renew their deals and be very focused on movie content. And we're focused on being a distributor for those services. We are a distributor for Starz now, we would like to be for Showtime, HBO and Epix. So that's the relationship that we want, as opposed to trying to bid against them. It's just not necessary for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next two questions are from Youssef Squali at Jefferies. Will you be renegotiating content rights with the studios along the lines of what you've done with Warner Bros. for day and date releases? Help us understand the cost benefit to you.
componenttext: The next two questions are from Youssef Squali at Jefferies. Will you be renegotiating content rights with the studios along the lines of what you've done with Warner Bros. for day and date releases? Help us understand the cost benefit to you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll broaden the question slightly to the general 28-day question, which is why did we do the Warner deal. I don't think it impacts the streaming directly. But with Warner Bros., they wanted to create a window to improve sell through. As you all kno
componenttext: Well, I'll broaden the question slightly to the general 28-day question, which is why did we do the Warner deal. I don't think it impacts the streaming directly. But with Warner Bros., they wanted to create a window to improve sell through. As you all know, in the book industry, there's hardcover books for sale for a while and then paperback. And that's a proper profit maximization strategy, than they asking quite reasonably, would like to have DVDs for sale at Amazon, Wal-Mart, Best Buy, et cetera, for some period of time before they're available for rental. We were willing to agree with them to work within that system, which we hope and they hope will improve the DVD profits in the DVD ecosystem. And for us, most consumers, they're not sure if DVDs come 90 days after the theatrical release, 120 days, 150, 180, it's all over the map. It constantly changes not only between studios, but also between specific releases. So there's not a high expectation of any perfect day when it's supposed to be out. There is potentially competitive risk if Redbox and others continue to be able to have availability day and date. It certainly appears that Warner is going to try to do and the other studios, is to have us and the kiosks fundamentally at the 28th day, which creates the window for the studios. Video stores, we're not sure what will happen there, but they're closing so quickly. It may not be that relevant in the next couple of years. And that kiosks and rental-by-mail together could create that window. The advantage to us in doing the deals is cost savings. Warner has given us a huge number of copies at the 29th day at a very attractive price, so we're able to fulfill all of the consumer demand. And then we're able to use those savings to pour that in a more streaming content. So it's really a win all around, in terms of what we're doing. And that's why we're looking forward to expanding that with other studios over the next two years as our deals come up.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question from Youssef Squali. On the Wii deal, what's the percentage of the total Wii installed base that is actually addressable in that relationship? Arguably, you need connectivity to stream the content, which many older devices don't have.
componenttext: The next question from Youssef Squali. On the Wii deal, what's the percentage of the total Wii installed base that is actually addressable in that relationship? Arguably, you need connectivity to stream the content, which many older devices don't have.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, actually, that's one of the amazing things about the Wii is 100% of the devices of Wi-Fi included. So of the 26 million installed base, 100% are addressable by Netflix. So we're very excited about them.
componenttext: Well, actually, that's one of the amazing things about the Wii is 100% of the devices of Wi-Fi included. So of the 26 million installed base, 100% are addressable by Netflix. So we're very excited about them.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next two questions are for Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Can you talk about Netflix digital content acquisition strategy as it relates to new content? In other words, is it possible to get digital content closer to DVD release, or possibly longer
componenttext: The next two questions are for Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Can you talk about Netflix digital content acquisition strategy as it relates to new content? In other words, is it possible to get digital content closer to DVD release, or possibly longer term getting DVD windowing rights? What are the business model pros and cons for offering newer digital title?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're not terribly likely to have equivalent to DVD streaming content and newness in the service. And that's true for frankly any subscription service including HBO, Starz etc. And so the big advantage that Netflix has competitively, is we can offer this
componenttext: We're not terribly likely to have equivalent to DVD streaming content and newness in the service. And that's true for frankly any subscription service including HBO, Starz etc. And so the big advantage that Netflix has competitively, is we can offer this incredible subscription with the new releases on DVD, and the vast catalog is potentially available for streaming. We fit in to the subscription TV window in studio parlance which is the same window with HBO, Starz and others. And within that, there's a lot more content that we can get that we haven't yet licensed, which is fundamentally us writing bigger and bigger checks to be able to purchase more and more content which is coming along nicely. So I would say the strategy is not particularly focused on how do we break through to get the newest new releases on streaming, it's much more how do we get every TV episode, every movie ever made, vast catalog and incredibly rich catalog and then to use our personalized merchandising to figure out which parts of that are relevant to each consumer, so that when they turn on their TV, or do they go to the Netflix website, the 20 or so movies listed are 20 movies that, that consumer is just dying to watch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Ralph. Can you talk about the subscribers that were out of this quarter in terms of how many we're purely streaming digital subscribers? Or perhaps more broadly, are you seeing any measurable mix shift to subscribers renting less DVDs
componenttext: Second question from Ralph. Can you talk about the subscribers that were out of this quarter in terms of how many we're purely streaming digital subscribers? Or perhaps more broadly, are you seeing any measurable mix shift to subscribers renting less DVDs, and converting to streaming only?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ralph, all of our subscribers pay for hybrid service, so they get both DVD and streaming and nearly all of them also take DVDs. So they really use both. And again on DVD, we've got over 100,000 titles, so it's just incredibly comprehensive. You can see wh
componenttext: Ralph, all of our subscribers pay for hybrid service, so they get both DVD and streaming and nearly all of them also take DVDs. So they really use both. And again on DVD, we've got over 100,000 titles, so it's just incredibly comprehensive. You can see why someone would do that. In terms of the substitution question that you asked, you know our long-term model is to be able, as a percentage of our cost, to pay a little bit less each year on DVD and Blu-ray as a percentage and to put more and more money into streaming. And that's where you'll eventually see the substitution. We're not able, at this point, to be conclusive about any substitution that exists because we don't have a good control set of subscribers that don't get streaming. So when we look at it, we're very happy with the effect streaming is having, but it's mostly coming in terms of additional growth. That's the one, we see it directly which is -- where it gets lower SAC and lower churn. More than it is a cost substitution. But we're, as you can tell from our P&L and our margin structure, we're able to get enough digital content, to have significant expansion in streaming and we're moving along each quarter and getting more and more content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next three questions are from Aaron Kessler at Kaufman Bros. It doesn't appear that you are as aggressive as you would have liked to have been in terms of purchasing digital content in 2009. What prevented you from acquiring the rights to more content
componenttext: The next three questions are from Aaron Kessler at Kaufman Bros. It doesn't appear that you are as aggressive as you would have liked to have been in terms of purchasing digital content in 2009. What prevented you from acquiring the rights to more content in 2009? What is the outlook for availability of content in 2010? And any comments on, I think, or concerns the studios have on Starz licensing digital content to Netflix?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's a couple of key questions in there. We're very happy with the content we've been acquiring. It's a small part of the content for streaming we eventually want to have, but it's enough content that the percentage of subscribers viewing or streaming
componenttext: There's a couple of key questions in there. We're very happy with the content we've been acquiring. It's a small part of the content for streaming we eventually want to have, but it's enough content that the percentage of subscribers viewing or streaming has significantly increased. In one quarter, we went from 41% to 48% of our subscribers. And remember, the subscriber base is growing over that time also. So I know we don't have everything that we want, but we got a ton of content for subscribers and they're super happy with it. And again, as we write checks, and are able with a larger P&L to write larger checks, we'll get more and more content. In terms of Starz specifically in Starz/Disney, we don't have any reason to believe there's going to be any change in that in the short-term. That's working well for us. We've got a good agreement in place. In terms of the long term, we're not dependent on any one content source particularly. The strength of Netflix is to have a very broad range of content. So we're not particularly troubled by those press reports.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me supplement Reed's answer and say, if with perfect foresight, we had been able to forecast the profit performance of the business and the subscriber growth, we would have landed within the range of guidance. And we would have spent to acquire conten
componenttext: Let me supplement Reed's answer and say, if with perfect foresight, we had been able to forecast the profit performance of the business and the subscriber growth, we would have landed within the range of guidance. And we would have spent to acquire content roughly the amount of money we had forecast. The business outperformed and we weren't able to forecast that accurately. And as a consequence, we dropped more profit to the bottom line in Q4 than we had planned. If we planned for it, we would've managed to the 10% number and spent more on content. So perhaps your question in part comes, is related to the outperformance in the quarter and that narrowly is planning-related issue.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's a great point, Barry. And for investors, it's typically, I mean it's all a little variable. But it's at least six months from when we start to talk with a studio or network about a particular set of content to win, a deal is signed and the cont
componenttext: And that's a great point, Barry. And for investors, it's typically, I mean it's all a little variable. But it's at least six months from when we start to talk with a studio or network about a particular set of content to win, a deal is signed and the content is flowing. So it's not stuff that you call up and 30 days later, you spent more money on a P&L basis. So these are long-term deals and they take -- each one takes quite a while to negotiate. And at any point in time, we're in negotiation on a very broad range of content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Aaron. How did PS3 launch compared to Xbox 360, realizing you can't give any specific numbers?
componenttext: Next question from Aaron. How did PS3 launch compared to Xbox 360, realizing you can't give any specific numbers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Aaron, PS3 was a huge success for us. Its advantages are that its Wi-Fi built in to every unit, and you can use Netflix without being part of add-on subscription like Live Gold. Its disadvantages are that it's got a disc and that we have to mail the disc
componenttext: Aaron, PS3 was a huge success for us. Its advantages are that its Wi-Fi built in to every unit, and you can use Netflix without being part of add-on subscription like Live Gold. Its disadvantages are that it's got a disc and that we have to mail the disc to the consumer. Once they've got the disc, it's very easy to use, but that does introduce a delay. But we're super happy with the traction that the PS3 is at. And then in the fall, we'll be offering downloaded option directly in the PS3 to the PSN network.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And finally from Aaron. What data are you looking at that suggests streaming is the big reason for lower churn, i.e. x[excluding] the surveys?
componenttext: And finally from Aaron. What data are you looking at that suggests streaming is the big reason for lower churn, i.e. x[excluding] the surveys?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. We're actually looking at retention data of the inverse return for a specific cohorts of customers segmented by behavior. So there's some portion that don't stream, there's some portion that are engaged in hybrid behavior, there's some portion that st
componenttext: No. We're actually looking at retention data of the inverse return for a specific cohorts of customers segmented by behavior. So there's some portion that don't stream, there's some portion that are engaged in hybrid behavior, there's some portion that stream only. And I'm looking at year-over-year comparisons in Q4 of retention behavior by subscriber period, first month and the individual months after that over their entire life.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Daniel Ernst at Hudson Square Research. Roku said this week, they have sold 500,000 boxes, an impressive number. I assume most of those have connected to Netflix. If I added up all of the direct-to-TV options you have, Roku, LG,
componenttext: The next question is from Daniel Ernst at Hudson Square Research. Roku said this week, they have sold 500,000 boxes, an impressive number. I assume most of those have connected to Netflix. If I added up all of the direct-to-TV options you have, Roku, LG, Samsung, Sony, Xbox et cetera, can you give me a sense of how many direct-to-TV Netflix homes there are?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, I can't give you a direct sense. For one thing, there are many people who use a laptop and then use a HDMI cable to a TV, and that shows up as laptop usage. Then there is the class of Mac Minis, where people do a similar thing, which shows up to u
componenttext: Daniel, I can't give you a direct sense. For one thing, there are many people who use a laptop and then use a HDMI cable to a TV, and that shows up as laptop usage. Then there is the class of Mac Minis, where people do a similar thing, which shows up to us as computer-based usage and it goes to the TV. So you really don't want to think about it as the screen size. If the screen size is 12-inch, it's one category; if the screen size is 36-inch, it's a different category. So when we thought about this over the last year, it's where we came up with a metric for your benefit, from benefit of investors, which is the percentage of subscribers that we're streaming in the quarter and taking advantage of it. And again, the actual screen size is not the main factor.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Michael Pachter at Wedbush Securities. Subscribers grew by 2.88 million in 2009, yet guidance for subscriber growth ranges from 3.23 million to 4.03 million. Does guidance incorporate the introduction of the streaming-only servic
componenttext: The next question is from Michael Pachter at Wedbush Securities. Subscribers grew by 2.88 million in 2009, yet guidance for subscriber growth ranges from 3.23 million to 4.03 million. Does guidance incorporate the introduction of the streaming-only service during the year? And if so, would you please break out by mail subscribers expected compared to streaming only?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, there's no formal plan, nor is it included in our guidance to introduce streaming only, but nor do I think it would change the forecast. In other words, if we thought it would open up an entire new market, of course we would do it. So we look at
componenttext: Michael, there's no formal plan, nor is it included in our guidance to introduce streaming only, but nor do I think it would change the forecast. In other words, if we thought it would open up an entire new market, of course we would do it. So we look at it and from our work with our subscribers and at $8.99, the hybrid is just so incredibly powerful. But for now, we're just going to ride that horse and concentrate the brand proposition on that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: But there is one minor caveat by way of cleanup. The sub-guidance is for domestic and international. International is very small. International will be streaming only domestic will not have a streaming only product. And I want to reemphasize international
componenttext: But there is one minor caveat by way of cleanup. The sub-guidance is for domestic and international. International is very small. International will be streaming only domestic will not have a streaming only product. And I want to reemphasize international, it's very, very small.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Mario Cibelli at Marathon Partners. Could you break down at all where streaming is coming from PC, Xbox, Blu-ray players, Roku et cetera? If not, are there any standouts in the mix that might be of interest to [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Next question is from Mario Cibelli at Marathon Partners. Could you break down at all where streaming is coming from PC, Xbox, Blu-ray players, Roku et cetera? If not, are there any standouts in the mix that might be of interest to [indiscernible]?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mario, all of the devices that you would think are significant that have big install basis which are laptops, Windows and Macintosh and game consoles are very big, the next big category are Blu-ray, because we got sorted early and that's continuing to gro
componenttext: Mario, all of the devices that you would think are significant that have big install basis which are laptops, Windows and Macintosh and game consoles are very big, the next big category are Blu-ray, because we got sorted early and that's continuing to grow really well for us. When we look at the three or five-year picture being built into the TV, it's an obvious winner. We think that most TVs -- almost all Blu-ray players sold next year, but this year, 2010, we'll have internet connectivity and Netflix. A substantial fraction of TVs will have Internet connectivity in almost all of those will have Netflix. And within two or three years, my sense is Wi-Fi is so inexpensive to add to TVs that they'll be in every screen. And we believe that Netflix will be part of that. So long-term picture, really driven by TVs, Blu-rays, but in the short term, video game and laptops are a big contributors also.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Will Netflix simply absorb the gross margin improvements that occur through a rising percentage of streaming versus DVD shipments? Or can we expect the purchase of new Hollywood productions to of
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Will Netflix simply absorb the gross margin improvements that occur through a rising percentage of streaming versus DVD shipments? Or can we expect the purchase of new Hollywood productions to offset such growth margin gain?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hopefully, we'll see it coming in which case, we'll reinvest it, in improving the quality of the user experience in more content.
componenttext: Hopefully, we'll see it coming in which case, we'll reinvest it, in improving the quality of the user experience in more content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next, at least this year, we're targeting 11% operating margins and we'll take it year-by-year but there's a pretty big prize out there. And if we can reinvest additional margin, essentially saved into more content that seems the smarter thing for us
componenttext: And next, at least this year, we're targeting 11% operating margins and we'll take it year-by-year but there's a pretty big prize out there. And if we can reinvest additional margin, essentially saved into more content that seems the smarter thing for us to do in the next few years.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Marianne Wolk at Susquehanna. The year-over-year declined in SAC was much lower than we've seen in the last few years. Should we anticipate positive growth in marketing spend per subscriber going forward? And how does the marketi
componenttext: The next question is from Marianne Wolk at Susquehanna. The year-over-year declined in SAC was much lower than we've seen in the last few years. Should we anticipate positive growth in marketing spend per subscriber going forward? And how does the marketing for Wii affect this?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look over the last three or four years, marketings declined as a percentage of revenue each year. And as our revenue grows, we think that will continue to happen including the special Wii marketing that we'll be doing. So that's included in our mod
componenttext: If you look over the last three or four years, marketings declined as a percentage of revenue each year. And as our revenue grows, we think that will continue to happen including the special Wii marketing that we'll be doing. So that's included in our model.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then linking back to Reed's comments earlier in the call, he observed that one of the drivers of declining SAC was organic growth which was tied to the quality of the service. So to the extent that we're able to improve the content offering and be a b
componenttext: And then linking back to Reed's comments earlier in the call, he observed that one of the drivers of declining SAC was organic growth which was tied to the quality of the service. So to the extent that we're able to improve the content offering and be a beneficiary of more platforms capable of streaming content to TV sets, and that should be a boost for organic growth which will be a plus for subscriber acquisition costs.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next couple of questions are from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. It looks like your DVD library is pretty consistent at about 100,000 titles, while streaming titles are up from roughly 12,000 in the summer to 17,000. How should we expect that to grow going
componenttext: The next couple of questions are from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. It looks like your DVD library is pretty consistent at about 100,000 titles, while streaming titles are up from roughly 12,000 in the summer to 17,000. How should we expect that to grow going forward? Would you expect 30,000 by year end?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, I should've avoided publishing the 17,000 update, because it gets everyone focused on title count and as you can imagine, we could quickly license if we wanted to, 100,000 irrelevant titles. So you really don't want to use title count as a proxy fo
componenttext: Brian, I should've avoided publishing the 17,000 update, because it gets everyone focused on title count and as you can imagine, we could quickly license if we wanted to, 100,000 irrelevant titles. So you really don't want to use title count as a proxy for attractiveness of the service. If we had 1,000 of the biggest titles, that will make a much bigger difference than 10,000 others. The substitute for title count that is more valid to think about, is the percentage of our subs that are streaming. The way that increases is by adding more content, more platforms, better user interface, all of those coming together and. Of course that metric moved up from 41% a quarter ago to 48% this quarter. So we're really thrilled with the progress of that and we're going to continue to push content in. So think of it as, as we put in content in the streaming content as we get the user interface better, the platforms, all of those drive that up, and we're trying to back off with title count as a significant metric.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Brian. Regarding the outlook for content acquisition, are the discussions with Showtime, HBO or Epix for their film content?
componenttext: Second question from Brian. Regarding the outlook for content acquisition, are the discussions with Showtime, HBO or Epix for their film content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the question is are there discussions ongoing, and we have discussions with everybody. So a very broad range. But that doesn't imply that there's anything close on any of them. It's just an ongoing set of conversations with a wide range of network
componenttext: I guess the question is are there discussions ongoing, and we have discussions with everybody. So a very broad range. But that doesn't imply that there's anything close on any of them. It's just an ongoing set of conversations with a wide range of networks and studios.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Imran Khan at JPMorgan. You've bought back $7.4 million shares last year. Do you have any optimal numbers in your mind going forward?
componenttext: The next question is from Imran Khan at JPMorgan. You've bought back $7.4 million shares last year. Do you have any optimal numbers in your mind going forward?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry, I'm trying to think how we want to answer that. But we're going to be active acquirers of stock this quarter, and I anticipate that we'll continue to purchase shares throughout the year. I have in mind we, as a management team and our board, think
componenttext: Sorry, I'm trying to think how we want to answer that. But we're going to be active acquirers of stock this quarter, and I anticipate that we'll continue to purchase shares throughout the year. I have in mind we, as a management team and our board, think about using cash like we would to any other productive asset. There's some minimum amount of cash we want to keep on the balance sheet, and then we want to smartly deploy all the rest of it. I mean, if we can't deploy it in the business, then we will deploy it to repurchase shares provided that the share price, at which we would repurchase, makes sense from an IRR perspective. Now if you are optimistic about our ability to grow the size of the market and the subscriber base and future profits, you probably got some pretty aggressive price expectations for the stock. And if you don't, you probably don't. And I don't -- I mean, obviously, we're pretty bullish on our ability to continue to grow subscribers, revenue, profit, free cash flow. So it's some pretty aggressive price points at which we're willing to acquire.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. To what extent do you believe the ability to update one cue via iFlix Flixster and most CE partner interfaces has or will change Netflix website traffic patterns as measured by third-party services
componenttext: The next question is from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. To what extent do you believe the ability to update one cue via iFlix Flixster and most CE partner interfaces has or will change Netflix website traffic patterns as measured by third-party services?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure how much. We'll get more and more viewing from devices. There's not that much cue additions per se from devices, but your point is right, which is if someone is only measuring web interaction for Netflix, they're going to miss more and more o
componenttext: I'm not sure how much. We'll get more and more viewing from devices. There's not that much cue additions per se from devices, but your point is right, which is if someone is only measuring web interaction for Netflix, they're going to miss more and more of the picture overtime, and that may contribute to a difficulty for web measurement firms in terms of measuring Netflix accurately.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Nat Schindler at BofA Merrill Lynch. What was the cause of the large Q-over-Q step up in CapEx? And what are your expectations for capital expenditures in 2010?
componenttext: The next question is from Nat Schindler at BofA Merrill Lynch. What was the cause of the large Q-over-Q step up in CapEx? And what are your expectations for capital expenditures in 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the 2010 question first. I think they'll be roughly flat. They are flat '08 to '09 and '09 to '10. I think they'll be roughly flat. It depends a great deal on how successfully or not pushing some of our IT infrastructure into the cloud. The an
componenttext: Let me take the 2010 question first. I think they'll be roughly flat. They are flat '08 to '09 and '09 to '10. I think they'll be roughly flat. It depends a great deal on how successfully or not pushing some of our IT infrastructure into the cloud. The answer with respect to Q4 is, as I said in my comments, we're busy investing in Rent the Return, a lot of Asian for op centers or hubs. And that was the largest single CapEx expenditure in the quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question, what do you expect for the quarterly interest expense going forward?
componenttext: Second question, what do you expect for the quarterly interest expense going forward?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the interest expense is fixed and the yield on the bond was 8% and we sell them at par.
componenttext: Well, the interest expense is fixed and the yield on the bond was 8% and we sell them at par.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's three questions from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. First, what kind of response, if any, have you sensed from your subscriber base with regards to the 28 days sales window? Any complaints?
componenttext: There's three questions from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. First, what kind of response, if any, have you sensed from your subscriber base with regards to the 28 days sales window? Any complaints?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, no material complaints. Again, subscribers are just not that aware of when DVDs come out relative to theatrical. The first title that says so affected is The Invention of Lying, which is just hitting. So even if there were complaints, they wouldn't
componenttext: Mark, no material complaints. Again, subscribers are just not that aware of when DVDs come out relative to theatrical. The first title that says so affected is The Invention of Lying, which is just hitting. So even if there were complaints, they wouldn't come up yet. But from everything we've done before deciding to do this and seeing the results afterwards, we're very happy with the decision.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just chime in and say that we've frequently spoken about the rental mix of new release versus catalog. And then in the most recent quarter, I think catalog was 73%, so the new release was 27%. And some people have speculated that that's not a true
componenttext: Let me just chime in and say that we've frequently spoken about the rental mix of new release versus catalog. And then in the most recent quarter, I think catalog was 73%, so the new release was 27%. And some people have speculated that that's not a true measure of demand on the subscriber base, that if we release a cue demand by street date, we'd see an entirely different picture. But in fact, we see exactly the same picture. Cue demand for new release in December was 27%, which is just the average disc shipments in the quarter. So you ought not to imagine that somehow we're frustrating demand and then that's the reason that we primarily ship back catalog. There is no data to support that conclusion.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question. Currently, what's the biggest obstacle to getting more streaming content?
componenttext: Second question. Currently, what's the biggest obstacle to getting more streaming content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Money.
componenttext: Money.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Third question. What caused the bump up in free subscribers in the quarter?
componenttext: Third question. What caused the bump up in free subscribers in the quarter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Typically, each Q4. Q4 more than all other quarters is back-loaded and so there are more subscribers out [ph] of in their two-week free trial at the end of the quarter, so that's just a timing thing that's true each Q4.
componenttext: Typically, each Q4. Q4 more than all other quarters is back-loaded and so there are more subscribers out [ph] of in their two-week free trial at the end of the quarter, so that's just a timing thing that's true each Q4.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then if you add on top of that, the year-over-year accelerating growth, you'd see a shift towards free.
componenttext: And then if you add on top of that, the year-over-year accelerating growth, you'd see a shift towards free.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Sandeep Aggarwal at Collins Stewart. As we get more subscribers signing up because of streaming, can we see churn going down even further?
componenttext: Next question from Sandeep Aggarwal at Collins Stewart. As we get more subscribers signing up because of streaming, can we see churn going down even further?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: You know, it certainly is possible that as consumers use the streaming more and more, they end up having a more consistent relationship with Netflix rather than, say, turning it off on the summer and coming back in the fall. But it's also possible that it
componenttext: You know, it certainly is possible that as consumers use the streaming more and more, they end up having a more consistent relationship with Netflix rather than, say, turning it off on the summer and coming back in the fall. But it's also possible that it's the other way, that we get a broader demographic of subscribers that come in and then they are very comfortable going out for a few months, going on, going out. So I would advise you to try to really focus on the net additions in the growth rather than the second churn because that combination isn't the most material part of the business. It's really the net additions that I focus on.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Sandeep. By when can you have streaming titles more than 35% of total titles you carry?
componenttext: Second question from Sandeep. By when can you have streaming titles more than 35% of total titles you carry?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, if we had chosen to, we could've had that years ago because we would've taken the 35 smallest titles such and such, yoga, studio, blah and had it. So again, title count could be super misleading. What you really want to ask is, when are we going
componenttext: Sandeep, if we had chosen to, we could've had that years ago because we would've taken the 35 smallest titles such and such, yoga, studio, blah and had it. So again, title count could be super misleading. What you really want to ask is, when are we going to have 2/3 of our subscribers streaming? When is the content so good that 2/3 of our subscribers choose to stream? And the answer to that question for you, I would guess about a year and a half, just based on the current trends of what we've seen in growing it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have heard you observed in the past that it's not just about the content, it's also about the platforms, so it's about building the ecosystem around streaming. And we've made a tremendous amount of progress in 2009 and we will continue to in 2010 with r
componenttext: I have heard you observed in the past that it's not just about the content, it's also about the platforms, so it's about building the ecosystem around streaming. And we've made a tremendous amount of progress in 2009 and we will continue to in 2010 with respect to platform growth. And so that makes a larger investment in content economical.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next couple of questions are from Doug Anmuth of Barclays Capital. Q4 content acquisition was the highest it's been in two years. Should we think about that as a one-time step up related to the new Warner deal? Or is that more of a run rate going forw
componenttext: The next couple of questions are from Doug Anmuth of Barclays Capital. Q4 content acquisition was the highest it's been in two years. Should we think about that as a one-time step up related to the new Warner deal? Or is that more of a run rate going forward?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's more of the latter than the former. It had a lot to due with moving out of REVShare in Q4 and back into REVShare in Q1 and the timing of payables coming out of Q3.
componenttext: It's more of the latter than the former. It had a lot to due with moving out of REVShare in Q4 and back into REVShare in Q1 and the timing of payables coming out of Q3.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Doug. Curious to know why there is no on-screen presence for the Wii. I assume this is for contractual reasons with Sony.
componenttext: Second question from Doug. Curious to know why there is no on-screen presence for the Wii. I assume this is for contractual reasons with Sony.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Probably he means with Nintendo. But, yes, that's their preference on a way the system is to operate is we'll be like any other game, and we'll go off in the market for service as an incredible Internet video streaming on the Wii.
componenttext: Probably he means with Nintendo. But, yes, that's their preference on a way the system is to operate is we'll be like any other game, and we'll go off in the market for service as an incredible Internet video streaming on the Wii.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Michael Olson at Piper Jaffray, also with regards to the Wii. Wii is certainly a larger install base than the other consoles, but how do you feel about the Wii demographic versus the Xbox and PS3?
componenttext: The next question is from Michael Olson at Piper Jaffray, also with regards to the Wii. Wii is certainly a larger install base than the other consoles, but how do you feel about the Wii demographic versus the Xbox and PS3?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: You know, we'll know a lot more after we launch. But I think it's certainly true that the PS3 and Xbox, because they are more expensive higher end boxes. The two high-def has more video intensity. So the question is the Wii install base is significantly l
componenttext: You know, we'll know a lot more after we launch. But I think it's certainly true that the PS3 and Xbox, because they are more expensive higher end boxes. The two high-def has more video intensity. So the question is the Wii install base is significantly larger, then how do those washout against each other? So we look at all three as just great opportunities for us, and we're continuing to push forward on all three.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next two questions are from Jeetil Patel at Deutsche Bank Securities. What do the demographics of the new customers, added in the past year, look like relative to the existing subscriber base?
componenttext: The next two questions are from Jeetil Patel at Deutsche Bank Securities. What do the demographics of the new customers, added in the past year, look like relative to the existing subscriber base?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeetil, I don't think that we know of any own, look into Barry [ph], of any big change in the demographics. You know, it's people who love movies and TV episodes and that's pretty broad, so we're getting the benefit of that.
componenttext: Jeetil, I don't think that we know of any own, look into Barry [ph], of any big change in the demographics. You know, it's people who love movies and TV episodes and that's pretty broad, so we're getting the benefit of that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And do your newer customers have any different propensities, in other words, higher streaming usage, lower hire churn, 2DV [ph] rental plan, lower utilization?
componenttext: And do your newer customers have any different propensities, in other words, higher streaming usage, lower hire churn, 2DV [ph] rental plan, lower utilization?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say over the last three years, we continue to gain confidence that there is great competitive notes [ph] and commercial value and profits in our lower price plans. So if you look at us four years ago, we were only the $17 then $18 three out. We go
componenttext: I would say over the last three years, we continue to gain confidence that there is great competitive notes [ph] and commercial value and profits in our lower price plans. So if you look at us four years ago, we were only the $17 then $18 three out. We got into the $9 one out, we expanded. And we'd continue to do that, driving low prices, larger subscriber base and substantial profits. Because it's frankly a more defensible way to hold on to those profits. So continuing with that trend, more and more new subscribers are taking the $8.99 hybrid, get all, rent all the DVDs you want one at a time, and all the streaming you want. And you see that reflected in ARPU. And again, we see that as a competitive strength, which is we can make money at these price points, and that's hard for anyone else to attack us and be able to do the same thing so to scale advantage that we're investing in.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: But I mean, you see that advantage translate in terms of profit in the gross profit per average paying customer. I think it was $4.96 in the quarter. And you have to look back two years before you find a profit per sub-number that's actually higher. So no
componenttext: But I mean, you see that advantage translate in terms of profit in the gross profit per average paying customer. I think it was $4.96 in the quarter. And you have to look back two years before you find a profit per sub-number that's actually higher. So notwithstanding the lower price points and the investment in streaming, the profit dynamics of the model is the sub-scale advantages that we just talked about are clearly present.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer & Co. Have you started to negotiate with studios for international streaming rights? And if so, how are prices for streaming likely to compare to U.S. prices?
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer & Co. Have you started to negotiate with studios for international streaming rights? And if so, how are prices for streaming likely to compare to U.S. prices?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, it's unclear how the pricing will work out of something we're still experimenting in and looking at, so we'll be able to talk more about international in the second half of the year.
componenttext: Jason, it's unclear how the pricing will work out of something we're still experimenting in and looking at, so we'll be able to talk more about international in the second half of the year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mark Harding at Maxim Group. Does full-year 2010 subscriber guidance include expectations from an international launch? If so, can you provide any color about a likely country service offering or pricing?
componenttext: The next question is from Mark Harding at Maxim Group. Does full-year 2010 subscriber guidance include expectations from an international launch? If so, can you provide any color about a likely country service offering or pricing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: To narrow a question from modeling perspective is yes, but it's really small.
componenttext: To narrow a question from modeling perspective is yes, but it's really small.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we don't plan on giving any more information about what country, what price plans, what timing until we launch in the second half of the year.
componenttext: And we don't plan on giving any more information about what country, what price plans, what timing until we launch in the second half of the year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we're doing that for competitive reasons, not to be difficult.
componenttext: And we're doing that for competitive reasons, not to be difficult.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next questions are from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. How do you balance the need for cash for digital right and repurchases? What is your willingness to increase leverage?
componenttext: The next questions are from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. How do you balance the need for cash for digital right and repurchases? What is your willingness to increase leverage?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the first party is to improve the service because that purchase cycle drives all kinds of good things, subscriber growth and revenue and profit and free cash flow. And after that, it's our surplus cash so we think about repurchasing for stock. We ar
componenttext: Well, the first party is to improve the service because that purchase cycle drives all kinds of good things, subscriber growth and revenue and profit and free cash flow. And after that, it's our surplus cash so we think about repurchasing for stock. We are growing free cash flow in round numbers, sort of 1/3 each year, and so we have ample opportunity over time to go back to the capital markets for more debt and maintain the same amount of leverage in the business as the business grows. And the streaming, I don't want to say the streaming service, as the hybrid service becomes more mature, as we acquire more content, as we gain more scale and the business becomes more predictable, then we might think more aggressively about slightly increasing the amount of leverage on the business. So we're 1.3 times, when we close the transaction is too conceivable, possibly, but I don't foresee a capital markets transaction in the foreseeable future.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then, Tony, your question implies some tension between digital content acquisition and repurchase, which doesn't exist. The digital content is not big-cash-advance-oriented, so P&L constrained in terms of generating profit as opposed to cash constrained o
componenttext: Then, Tony, your question implies some tension between digital content acquisition and repurchase, which doesn't exist. The digital content is not big-cash-advance-oriented, so P&L constrained in terms of generating profit as opposed to cash constrained on a digital content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Tony. Was the sale of Roku recorded as a gain this quarter?
componenttext: Second question from Tony. Was the sale of Roku recorded as a gain this quarter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It was recorded as gain. You can see it in the statement of cash flows and you've seen it in our SEC disclosures. Investment was carried at $5.7 million. We booked a gain pretax of about $1.7 million after tax that translates to $1,035,000 on an EPS basis
componenttext: It was recorded as gain. You can see it in the statement of cash flows and you've seen it in our SEC disclosures. Investment was carried at $5.7 million. We booked a gain pretax of about $1.7 million after tax that translates to $1,035,000 on an EPS basis, quite still roughly just shy of $0.02, around $0.72.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question's from Heath Terry at FBR Capital Markets. Are there any reasons legal, technological, et cetera, that you couldn't develop a streaming application for the iPod? Would your current streaming service work on the device?
componenttext: Next question's from Heath Terry at FBR Capital Markets. Are there any reasons legal, technological, et cetera, that you couldn't develop a streaming application for the iPod? Would your current streaming service work on the device?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Heath, we haven't yet done or submitted an iPhone application. So we're optimistic that post the Google Voice brouhaha, it would be approved. But there's really no way of knowing in advance what Apple's stance would be on that. And of course, that applica
componenttext: Heath, we haven't yet done or submitted an iPhone application. So we're optimistic that post the Google Voice brouhaha, it would be approved. But there's really no way of knowing in advance what Apple's stance would be on that. And of course, that application, if it works on the iPhone, it will work on the iPod. It's not a huge priority for us because we're so focused on the larger screens. Until we get our TV ubiquity and our Blu-ray ubiquity, then we're getting close on video game ubiquity, that we would next turn to the small screen. It's just not a primary movie watching, so it's something we will get around to, but it's not in the near term.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Heath. How many of your studio relationships come up from renewal this year?
componenttext: Second question from Heath. How many of your studio relationships come up from renewal this year?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: He think of it as there's a ton than over 50 Barry [ph] content deals, so it's not one per studio. It's hundreds of content deals. So there are individual sets of content that are negotiated and priced with varying durations. And of course, we're careful
componenttext: He think of it as there's a ton than over 50 Barry [ph] content deals, so it's not one per studio. It's hundreds of content deals. So there are individual sets of content that are negotiated and priced with varying durations. And of course, we're careful to make sure that they are fairly distributed and staggered in their expiration so that we can manage it to a fairly steady flow of content coming in and us buying more and more content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Jim Friedland at Cowen and Company. The rate of decline in ARPU has slowed over the past four quarters. Is it reasonable to assume that as the streaming catalog and Watch Instantly usage grow, ARPU will trend towards $8.89? Or will y
componenttext: Next question is from Jim Friedland at Cowen and Company. The rate of decline in ARPU has slowed over the past four quarters. Is it reasonable to assume that as the streaming catalog and Watch Instantly usage grow, ARPU will trend towards $8.89? Or will you introduce multiple pricing tiers for different usage levels of streaming content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, the thing that I think about is the Blu-ray. So we're a little over 10% with Blu-ray and that's a $2 supplement. And so there's the trend towards the $8.99. But for those subs that want Blu-ray, it's $2 more so $10.99, and that gives a little softeni
componenttext: Jim, the thing that I think about is the Blu-ray. So we're a little over 10% with Blu-ray and that's a $2 supplement. And so there's the trend towards the $8.99. But for those subs that want Blu-ray, it's $2 more so $10.99, and that gives a little softening effect on the ARPU decline.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard Capital Markets. With regards to pay-TV rights, will Netflix seek to bid against pay-TV networks, such as Starz, for exclusive rights to new movies in the pay-TV window?
componenttext: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard Capital Markets. With regards to pay-TV rights, will Netflix seek to bid against pay-TV networks, such as Starz, for exclusive rights to new movies in the pay-TV window?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Barton, at this point, we're looking to try to work with the existing pay-TV services Epix, Starz, HBO and Showtime and to be a distributor so that we are writing them big checks, partially because that includes all of their amazing original content. So t
componenttext: Barton, at this point, we're looking to try to work with the existing pay-TV services Epix, Starz, HBO and Showtime and to be a distributor so that we are writing them big checks, partially because that includes all of their amazing original content. So that's our primary strategy at this point.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from John Blackledge at Crdit Suisse. After console deals, where does growth come from in 2011 and beyond?
componenttext: The next question is from John Blackledge at Crdit Suisse. After console deals, where does growth come from in 2011 and beyond?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We ask ourself, too, which is the incredible accelerating growth that we've seen in the past three years, is that mostly linked to the expansion? First, the streaming on laptops and then to the device of it at large install bases, and we're frankly, just
componenttext: We ask ourself, too, which is the incredible accelerating growth that we've seen in the past three years, is that mostly linked to the expansion? First, the streaming on laptops and then to the device of it at large install bases, and we're frankly, just not sure. That is one thesis. The other thesis is we're on the beginning of the streaming adoption S curve, and that we'll continue to grow into the install bases that is all of our subscribers have laptops to watch movies on, and many of them have Internet-enabled Blu-ray players. So we may be able to string that together and we'll know more in the second half of this year as to the shape of those curbs. But even in a more conservative case, you know, in the midpoint of our guidance for the year, we're looking at about 30% subscriber growth annually which is phenomenal.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a settlement, Reed. Reed [ph], response?
componenttext: Just a settlement, Reed. Reed [ph], response?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, he made I think the most important point, a minor point links back to an earlier observation of his, which is that Internet Wi-Fi is becoming ubiquitously available in TV sets. And so game platforms, node devices, through gen one of the technology an
componenttext: Yes, he made I think the most important point, a minor point links back to an earlier observation of his, which is that Internet Wi-Fi is becoming ubiquitously available in TV sets. And so game platforms, node devices, through gen one of the technology and it evolves into a more general-purpose device accessible by anyone and any competitive service, but also accessible by Netflix. So with every television set purchased in the United States in 2011 can connect to the Internet. They could all be Netflix subscribers.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: But it's a great point, Barry, that in the optimistic case, we'll ride the broadband to the TV market, which will gross hugely year after year after year for the next 10 plus years.
componenttext: But it's a great point, Barry, that in the optimistic case, we'll ride the broadband to the TV market, which will gross hugely year after year after year for the next 10 plus years.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. With regards to household penetration, can you give us the updated numbers for Q4 for San Francisco Bay Area and rest of the country?
componenttext: The next question is from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. With regards to household penetration, can you give us the updated numbers for Q4 for San Francisco Bay Area and rest of the country?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bay Area in Q4 was 22.6%, up from 21.2%, and rest of country was at 10.8% in Q4, up from 9.6% in Q3.
componenttext: Bay Area in Q4 was 22.6%, up from 21.2%, and rest of country was at 10.8% in Q4, up from 9.6% in Q3.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Nat Schindler at Merrill Lynch. Long term, can you sustain unlimited streaming with an $8.99 price point?
componenttext: The next question is from Nat Schindler at Merrill Lynch. Long term, can you sustain unlimited streaming with an $8.99 price point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're not sure. It depends on how may subscribers want to have because the content is mostly fixed costs to produce and to buy. But certainly, if you had enough subscribers, you could make the content holders very happy by writing them large checks and st
componenttext: We're not sure. It depends on how may subscribers want to have because the content is mostly fixed costs to produce and to buy. But certainly, if you had enough subscribers, you could make the content holders very happy by writing them large checks and still have a big profit. So it's all about scale opportunity, and we're focused on trying to be the largest scale of this Internet commercial-free subscription services.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from George Askew with Stifel Nicolaus. You state that 48% of subscribers viewed streaming content in the fourth quarter. What is the percentage if you look only at subscribers added in 2009 or in the last few quarter?
componenttext: The next question is from George Askew with Stifel Nicolaus. You state that 48% of subscribers viewed streaming content in the fourth quarter. What is the percentage if you look only at subscribers added in 2009 or in the last few quarter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't have separate breakouts for each of the cohorts at least happened they were not doing for public disclosure. But it's certainly true that newer subscribers that are introduced to streaming, right in the beginning as part of their Netflix service,
componenttext: We don't have separate breakouts for each of the cohorts at least happened they were not doing for public disclosure. But it's certainly true that newer subscribers that are introduced to streaming, right in the beginning as part of their Netflix service, are using Netflix at slightly higher rates than someone who's been a DVD subscriber for us for six years. And in their heads, we are a DVD service. But you know that will change over time and those cohorts will come together.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: His second question is with regards to the Wii advertising. What is the nature of the advertising online compared [ph] to the offline, and what might be the range of your spend?
componenttext: His second question is with regards to the Wii advertising. What is the nature of the advertising online compared [ph] to the offline, and what might be the range of your spend?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The spend is included in our marketing plans and I don't have a breakdown for you of the type of advertising. We'll do what we view is most effective.
componenttext: The spend is included in our marketing plans and I don't have a breakdown for you of the type of advertising. We'll do what we view is most effective.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Guy-Charles Valois at Galliant Capital. Would you expect operating margin to be higher or lower than current levels on a 100% streaming business model?
componenttext: The next question is from Guy-Charles Valois at Galliant Capital. Would you expect operating margin to be higher or lower than current levels on a 100% streaming business model?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Guy, I think the long-term operating margins will be determined more by the amount of competition. If there's three or four fairly equal players in a large market, you would expect the operating margins to be lower. If there's one or two, you'd expect the
componenttext: Guy, I think the long-term operating margins will be determined more by the amount of competition. If there's three or four fairly equal players in a large market, you would expect the operating margins to be lower. If there's one or two, you'd expect the operating margins to be higher. So the actual streaming costs are quite low. The content costs are -- there's no hard costs, it's just what we pay for it. I think the way to think about it is what will be the likely competitive structure of the future market? And from that, you can get a model of what the long-term operating margins will be.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: But along the way, for competitive reasons definitely playing on market share gain and driving hard for growth. We could, in the alternative, pursue a scheming strategy and take operating margins up. And it's a conscious decision to do the former, and not
componenttext: But along the way, for competitive reasons definitely playing on market share gain and driving hard for growth. We could, in the alternative, pursue a scheming strategy and take operating margins up. And it's a conscious decision to do the former, and not the latter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Correct. To deepen our competitive modes with large scale in low prices.
componenttext: Correct. To deepen our competitive modes with large scale in low prices.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. Any color or numbers you can share with us on the average number of Netflix streaming devices in the household? How has that penetration been trending?
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. Any color or numbers you can share with us on the average number of Netflix streaming devices in the household? How has that penetration been trending?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I know the average number of laptops in a house in America is probably 1/2 for them. I'm just making up numbers. I don't really know. So you got every laptop, you got the Rokus, you got the video game consoles, I guess, that don't have any value to
componenttext: Well, I know the average number of laptops in a house in America is probably 1/2 for them. I'm just making up numbers. I don't really know. So you got every laptop, you got the Rokus, you got the video game consoles, I guess, that don't have any value to add on that answer.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the last question at which is a related question, are you seeing any substitution within the household from one device, say, a Sony TV over another, an Xbox or a TiVo?
componenttext: And the last question at which is a related question, are you seeing any substitution within the household from one device, say, a Sony TV over another, an Xbox or a TiVo?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. Our main focus is on streaming per se, and it doesn't really matter to us if it's streaming to a laptop, streaming to a laptop plugged in to a TV, streaming to a Blu-ray plugged in to a TV, streaming directly to the TV. That's all a great consumer exp
componenttext: No. Our main focus is on streaming per se, and it doesn't really matter to us if it's streaming to a laptop, streaming to a laptop plugged in to a TV, streaming to a Blu-ray plugged in to a TV, streaming directly to the TV. That's all a great consumer experience, so we're just trying to make all of those experiences better and better.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Operator, that was the last question that I have.
componenttext: Great. Operator, that was the last question that I have.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, everyone for joining us on the call. Q4 was a record-setting quarter and a capped off a great year in which we saw accelerating subscriber growth powered by streaming. We expect the growth to continue, which you'll see reflected in our gu
componenttext: Well, thank you, everyone for joining us on the call. Q4 was a record-setting quarter and a capped off a great year in which we saw accelerating subscriber growth powered by streaming. We expect the growth to continue, which you'll see reflected in our guidance. And I look forward to reporting on our progress with you on our next quarter's call. Thank you very much.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and we'll conclude today's conference call. But thank you, all for joining us and have a good afternoon. Goodbye.
componenttext: Thank you, and we'll conclude today's conference call. But thank you, all for joining us and have a good afternoon. Goodbye.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter Earnings conference call. At this time, I'll turn things over to Ms. Deborah Crawford, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter Earnings conference call. At this time, I'll turn things over to Ms. Deborah Crawford, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to Netflix Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Call. We released earnings for the fourth quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The earnings press release and the webcast of this conference call a
componenttext: Thank you, thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to Netflix Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Call. We released earnings for the fourth quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The earnings press release and the webcast of this conference call are available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. In addition, as noted in the earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's result is also available at our Investor Relations website. This conference call will consist solely of Q&A. As we have done for the past several quarters, we are going to conduct Q&A via email. Please email your questions to me at dcrawford@netflix.com. We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the commission on February 25, 2009. A rebroadcast of this call will be available at the Netflix website after 6 p.m. Pacific time today. Before moving into Q&A, I would like to turn the call over to Reed for some brief opening remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Deborah and welcome everyone to today's call. As you can tell from our press release and from the commentary we posted on our website, Q4 was a great quarter. Over 1 million net new subscribers, strong earnings and a significant expansion in strea
componenttext: Thanks, Deborah and welcome everyone to today's call. As you can tell from our press release and from the commentary we posted on our website, Q4 was a great quarter. Over 1 million net new subscribers, strong earnings and a significant expansion in streaming. And as our guidance for 2010 indicates, we expect the momentum to continue. So with that, let's go directly to Q&A.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question is from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Is the bounty paid to the game platform manufacturers materially different, than that paid to other customer acquisition channels. Is it higher or is it lower?
componenttext: The first question is from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Is the bounty paid to the game platform manufacturers materially different, than that paid to other customer acquisition channels. Is it higher or is it lower?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steven, we don't disclose the individual deals as you probably would expect. But what you can see is that as we've expanded with the various CE platforms including the game platforms, that our subscriber acquisition cost has continued to come down nicely.
componenttext: Steven, we don't disclose the individual deals as you probably would expect. But what you can see is that as we've expanded with the various CE platforms including the game platforms, that our subscriber acquisition cost has continued to come down nicely. So from that, you can intuit that there's no significant model shift.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question also from Steven Frankel. is the decline in SAC, driven by more declining ad rates, increased brand awareness or reduction in the bounties you are paying for customer acquisition?
componenttext: Next question also from Steven Frankel. is the decline in SAC, driven by more declining ad rates, increased brand awareness or reduction in the bounties you are paying for customer acquisition?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
