headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As instant watch viewing increases are you starting to see subscribers change from multi-out to single-out subscription?  If so, will lower operating costs from streaming offset the churn and if so, over what time horizon should we think about this leveli
componenttext: As instant watch viewing increases are you starting to see subscribers change from multi-out to single-out subscription?  If so, will lower operating costs from streaming offset the churn and if so, over what time horizon should we think about this leveling out?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Its not so much people who have been with us for a couple of years on a two-out or three-out switch down.  There is a little bit of that, but its not material.  Its mostly that as we grow, the new people coming in are differentially choosing our
componenttext: Its not so much people who have been with us for a couple of years on a two-out or three-out switch down.  There is a little bit of that, but its not material.  Its mostly that as we grow, the new people coming in are differentially choosing our one-out, $9 per month plan.  That is where you get the majority of the ASB effect from.  We are very happy with the margin structure that, that generates for us and on the earning stream.  So I hope that that answers your question.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that the backfill on the switching the migration by price point, roughly 1% of subscriptions per month migrates down, while 1% migrates up; 1.1 or 1.2.  On balance for the last quarter, we had 4500 more subscriptions migrate up than migrate down.
componenttext:
I think that the backfill on the switching the migration by price point, roughly 1% of subscriptions per month migrates down, while 1% migrates up; 1.1 or 1.2.  On balance for the last quarter, we had 4500 more subscriptions migrate up than migrate down.  
So in part we said if it happens a little bit on balance more than up, then that remains the current trend in the business.  It just isnt a dominant consumer behavior.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Of the $200 million in leverage, which was forced late last year, can you say what portion has gone to source streaming rights, what portion has gone towards stock buy-backs and what portion has gone towards working capital?
componenttext: Of the $200 million in leverage, which was forced late last year, can you say what portion has gone to source streaming rights, what portion has gone towards stock buy-backs and what portion has gone towards working capital?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The question refers to the $200 million debt that we closed in November of last year.  As you know from Q4 and Q1 results, cash flow from operations is positive and free cash flow has been positive.  So all of the working capital needs of the business are
componenttext: The question refers to the $200 million debt that we closed in November of last year.  As you know from Q4 and Q1 results, cash flow from operations is positive and free cash flow has been positive.  So all of the working capital needs of the business are self-funding and cash flow from operations includes all of the expenses and investments in content related to streaming.  So that has been self-funding.  So by default all of the proceeds have gone for either stock buyback or to replenish cash on the balance sheet and its been a combination of both.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next questions are from Doug Anmuth - Barclays Capital
componenttext: The next questions are from Doug Anmuth - Barclays Capital

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Why shift marketing expense to conference in the second half when you really have the opportunity to grow the subscriber base and can clearly fund the content funds other ways?
componenttext: Why shift marketing expense to conference in the second half when you really have the opportunity to grow the subscriber base and can clearly fund the content funds other ways?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Doug, that is a legitimate question and I think probably either one would get us great growth.  I just want to point out that when we invest in streaming content, that also attracts more subscribers because it improves the service.  So they are both vehic
componenttext:
Doug, that is a legitimate question and I think probably either one would get us great growth.  I just want to point out that when we invest in streaming content, that also attracts more subscribers because it improves the service.  So they are both vehicles for growth.  We make judgment calls between the two, but on the margin our results are not that sensitive to it.  That is if it were $10 million or $15 million one way or the other, we would get really the same growth.  Think of it as that we are continuing to invest adequately in marketing and generously in terms of streaming content, which is a strategy decision. 
Our approach and objective with respect to the streaming is to improve the overall quality of the service by year-end.  That serves the long-term strategic objective of improving the value proposition, which increases life-time value by lower return and improved word-of-mouth, which lowers SAC and the combination if you play in the most recent quarter than in the prior quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question from Doug.
componenttext: The second question from Doug.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: What is your view of the iPad, more of a new subscriber driver or another device for subscribers that will improve value, proposition, reduce return, etc.?
componenttext: What is your view of the iPad, more of a new subscriber driver or another device for subscribers that will improve value, proposition, reduce return, etc.?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Its a little of both.  I think its a great device that will grow over time in both its impact and usage.  As weve mentioned, we will expand onto the iPhone also.  Of course thats a much bigger install base, but a smaller screen.  Both of those
componenttext: Its a little of both.  I think its a great device that will grow over time in both its impact and usage.  As weve mentioned, we will expand onto the iPhone also.  Of course thats a much bigger install base, but a smaller screen.  Both of those will be good.  I would say that both are a relatively small part of video viewing.  Most of our focus is on television, either directly with Wi-Fi TV or through the BluRay player or through the video game console, but it is easy enough to support mobile so we are doing that also.

Were continuing to grow our total content and we are confident we will be able to continue to grow that content this year, next year and going forward as we are able to invest more money in it, which we have been.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Historically what weve seen is seasonality effects in counter Q1 and counter Q4 with growth just after the Christmas holiday season.  So back end loaded in Q4 and front-end loaded in Q1 and then growth during Q2 was back-end loaded and during Q3 it is
componenttext:
Historically what weve seen is seasonality effects in counter Q1 and counter Q4 with growth just after the Christmas holiday season.  So back end loaded in Q4 and front-end loaded in Q1 and then growth during Q2 was back-end loaded and during Q3 it is pretty linear across the quarter.  
Our growth patterns this quarter were less pronounced, with the growth in partners and the appeal of streaming.  With the launch of Wii, weve seen sort of the non-traditional growth pattern during the 2nd quarter and incremental marketing spending around that growth as well.

componenttext: It is a pretty small number, almost everybody watches DVDs also of our subscriber base.  We dont have any plans to break that out.  What we are focused on is driving up the percentage that does some screenings.  We see that as our key metrics and that is why we developed it and I appreciate doing an update for everyone on it.

componenttext: The next question is from Wayne Chang - Canaccord Adams.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you speak a little bit more extensively concerning the levels of activation you have seen on all of the various connective devices, be it television, set top boxes, and portable devices such as the iPad?
componenttext: Could you speak a little bit more extensively concerning the levels of activation you have seen on all of the various connective devices, be it television, set top boxes, and portable devices such as the iPad?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Not particularly in terms of the levels of activation that we are going to talk about, but probably underlying the question is trying to get some insight as to how people are using the service.  A key insight for you is that there is a significant amount
componenttext:
Not particularly in terms of the levels of activation that we are going to talk about, but probably underlying the question is trying to get some insight as to how people are using the service.  A key insight for you is that there is a significant amount of people who are watching on a PC and are watching with a PC hooked to a TV, which to us looks like a PC.  
So dont think about it as the only thing that matters is the Xbox or the PS3.  It is really a very broad usage pattern across a whole lot of devices, even in a given household.  You will have people accessing Netflix from multiple devices and thats part of the strength of our service in really being an internet video service is to be on all of the devices that the internet is on and have consumers think of them as internet service across all of those devices.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Melinda Davies - Susquehanna Investment Group
componenttext: The next question is from Melinda Davies - Susquehanna Investment Group

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: A question about the new distribution deal with Warner Brothers.  Now that you have, Blind Side for example, do you have enough to fill the demand for DVDs?  Are demands for Blind Side, 28 days after the DVD release, similar to what you have been seeing f
componenttext: A question about the new distribution deal with Warner Brothers.  Now that you have, Blind Side for example, do you have enough to fill the demand for DVDs?  Are demands for Blind Side, 28 days after the DVD release, similar to what you have been seeing for new releases of this type in the past.  We are trying to understand pent-up demand from Netflix subscribers or are Netflix subscribers shifting to Pay-Per-View and/or buying DVDs for the new releases and using Netflix for other content like older movies, TV shows, etc.?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Melinda there is a little bit of both as you would expect.  There are people who, in terms of the 28-day, are turning to buying the DVD, especially because it is a widely promoted at Wal-Mart and other places.  There are some that take Pay-Per-View becaus
componenttext:
Melinda there is a little bit of both as you would expect.  There are people who, in terms of the 28-day, are turning to buying the DVD, especially because it is a widely promoted at Wal-Mart and other places.  There are some that take Pay-Per-View because Warner Brothers is aggressive on the Pay-Per-View licensing.  Thats really the intent of the deal. 
In terms of the backlog, once it comes to the 28-day, we try to target to have enough DVDs to quickly clear that back wall pretty quickly.  There is a little bit of guesswork based on that.  We are still learning together with Warner Brothers and how to predict that, but thats the goal and intent.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ralph Scharkar - William Blair
componenttext: The next question is from Ralph Scharkar - William Blair

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Why is Netflix committed to staying out of the 40 billion plus, transaction-based Pay-Per-View market if we include DVD rentals and sales?  Why wouldnt content owners want me to sell new releases with the Netflix strong brand and digital distribution c
componenttext: Why is Netflix committed to staying out of the 40 billion plus, transaction-based Pay-Per-View market if we include DVD rentals and sales?  Why wouldnt content owners want me to sell new releases with the Netflix strong brand and digital distribution channel, but there will be multiple different storefronts going forward?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That is an interesting question.  I would say at times that content owners have wanted us to do that.  I would say that we dont see that we dont see much added value in that.  That is when we buy DVDs, we buy them from Wal-Mart, as consumers; from W
componenttext:
That is an interesting question.  I would say at times that content owners have wanted us to do that.  I would say that we dont see that we dont see much added value in that.  That is when we buy DVDs, we buy them from Wal-Mart, as consumers; from Wal-Mart or Amazon because they do a great job and that is what their main focus is.  Our focus is on subscription and it is hard and it takes us a lot of work.  That is probably the main reason that we dont do the selling of DVDs. 
In terms of Pay-Per-View, then there is a very specific thing, which is, for example Xbox has for years had a big Pay-Per-View business.  If we had also had Pay-Per-View as part of our service, it would have been a lot harder to get distribution on the Xbox.  Similarly with PS3, then of course you see now with Wal-Mart entering the Pay-Per-View market online with Voodoo that many of those firms want to go after that business.  So it is really much smarter for us, we think, to be out of that and not in a position of conflict and just to be focused on our subscription business.

componenttext: I think that it doesnt change it, Edward.  As I said a few minutes ago, we look at mobile for video viewing as a nice extra because it is pretty easy as opposed to fundamental and the TV based and laptop based screens; like a primary screen is the focus.

componenttext:
Probably so.  Yes the margin low on new employee hiring during the year.  The thing that should give you comfort that is likely to be true is that it was relevantly flat, plus or minus a couple hundred, thousand dollars last year and the year before that.  The big drivers of incremental expense would be entries volatility both implied and actual and employee growth.  
We are on a calendar year of review cycle.  Generally it will be stable during the year and then shift over the calendar year boundary.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next set of questions is from Scott Devitt - Morgan Stanley
componenttext: The next set of questions is from Scott Devitt - Morgan Stanley

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to growth margin, the recent week coupons you sent out offering 10% off the next monthly bill to users who install Watch Instantly on their Wii leads us to believe that streaming users are materially higher margin than non-streaming use
componenttext: With regards to growth margin, the recent week coupons you sent out offering 10% off the next monthly bill to users who install Watch Instantly on their Wii leads us to believe that streaming users are materially higher margin than non-streaming users given they watch less DVDs.  Can you give us any idea of the margin difference between streaming and non-streaming users?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, we are not commenting on gross margin for streamers versus non-streamers.  You are right that if there is a shift, at a high level you are right that all things being equal, if there is a shift away from DVD towards streaming it could be an acceler
componenttext: Scott, we are not commenting on gross margin for streamers versus non-streamers.  You are right that if there is a shift, at a high level you are right that all things being equal, if there is a shift away from DVD towards streaming it could be an accelerated gross margin, but you should also remember that we have explicitly said that all things will not be equal.  To the extent that there is more profit in the business, our objective is to re-invest the profit and improving the user experience so in that way margins are a managed outcome.  Our objective is to take what would have been at higher margins reinvested in the business in order to drive faster subscriber growth and move over churn and lower SAC and increase competitive motes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Then specifically on the Wii test, that was just ever aggressive product and marketing thats testing various [inaudible] the program you had referred to is just at this point?
componenttext: Then specifically on the Wii test, that was just ever aggressive product and marketing thats testing various [inaudible] the program you had referred to is just at this point?

componenttext: Second question from Scott Devitt.  With Redbox considering a streaming service at a lower pr ice point than your $8.99 per month subscription, are you revisiting the idea of offering a streaming only subscription plan at a lower price point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No, Scott, Redbox does many things incredibly well but were not worried about them particularly as a streaming competitor.  So anything they do in streaming doesnt affect how we think about that space.
componenttext: No, Scott, Redbox does many things incredibly well but were not worried about them particularly as a streaming competitor.  So anything they do in streaming doesnt affect how we think about that space.

componenttext: Finally, given the ever-expanding number of Netflix enabled devices, have you seen or do you expect to see consumers trading up to higher priced subscription plans in order to watch multiple videos simultaneously.  Either multiple people in different rooms in the house, mobile users watching while others at home are as well, or to have Netflix enabled on greater than 6 devices.

componenttext: In the next year or two we dont anticipate much of that.  Its pretty much one account per family model I the near term.

componenttext: Next questions are from Andy Hargreaves - Pacific Crest.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: To your knowledge, are cable satellite subscribers who cancel citing your service in increasing numbers, if so, could that impact your ability to gain access to TV content?
componenttext: To your knowledge, are cable satellite subscribers who cancel citing your service in increasing numbers, if so, could that impact your ability to gain access to TV content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Theres been a bunch of stories about so called cord cutting but we havent seen a lot of it.  Netflix has a subset of the content available on [inaudible] in particular no sports so its not much of a substitute for the packages that MSOs offer.
componenttext: Theres been a bunch of stories about so called cord cutting but we havent seen a lot of it.  Netflix has a subset of the content available on [inaudible] in particular no sports so its not much of a substitute for the packages that MSOs offer.

componenttext: Two contributing factors primarily on the comp side.  [CEO] swapped a very large percentage of its comp this year versus last year in the options and has a higher rate of expense so at least doubling down is [inaudible] the business that way.  I find that encouraging and secondly the brand has grown.  The [plaintiffs bar] has become more active and legal expenses as a consequence are up on a year-over-year and quarter over quarter basis.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Barton Crockett - Lazard Capital Markets
componenttext: Your next question comes from Barton Crockett - Lazard Capital Markets

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: First, theres a long term content question.  As Netflix subscriber base grows and seemingly gets closer and closer to total subscribers for premium and paid TV networks such as HBO, Showtime, and Starz, does the company ever need to think about borrowi
componenttext: First, theres a long term content question.  As Netflix subscriber base grows and seemingly gets closer and closer to total subscribers for premium and paid TV networks such as HBO, Showtime, and Starz, does the company ever need to think about borrowing a page from their strategy and investing in unique, original content?  Over the long term, it seems that for a video network to remain relevant to consumers, and ward off competition, it needs unique content.  Otherwise, the check book becomes the main barrier to [entry] which is not sustainable.  Do you agree or disagree with that thought?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Its a deep analysis but I would disagree.  Your premises that video services such as HBO and Starz need original content to differentiate, and Im not in disagreement with that part, but what Netflix has to differentiate is the user interface, person
componenttext:
Its a deep analysis but I would disagree.  Your premises that video services such as HBO and Starz need original content to differentiate, and Im not in disagreement with that part, but what Netflix has to differentiate is the user interface, personalization on demand aspect of the internet, and [lab].
Our view is that we can remain a packager and be significantly differentiated from other services because our value add is not just the content, its all of the recommendations, how people interact with them, helping them match with content theyre going to end up loving.
So our view is that we wont ever need to go into original series.  I would certainly say that if we ever did, we would probably have the wrong CEO and we shouldnt be based in [Silicon] Valley and theres a number of other things that make that an unpromising avenue.
So instead what were focused on is can we license the content as we have with Starz?  We have some content from Showtime.  Not yet anything from FX or HBO, and as those firms look at us, they can look at us two ways.  One is geez, were another packager of movies and another potential competitor, or they can look at it as were a natural distributor for their original series.
When you see the enormous success that Starz is having with Spartacus, that Showtime has had with Weeds, Californication and others, and of course HBO has for many years.  You can see that those services are differentially good at the original series and so well be hopeful these lines of partnership will be us as a great distributor writing them big checks for their original content.  We focus on packaging and they focus on the original series.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ill let Barry talk about the gross margins as a whole, but you remember that what were doing is saving money on DVD and then plugging it into streaming.  So if you ask a question are we saving money on DVD, the answer is yes.  If were saving mone
componenttext: Ill let Barry talk about the gross margins as a whole, but you remember that what were doing is saving money on DVD and then plugging it into streaming.  So if you ask a question are we saving money on DVD, the answer is yes.  If were saving money on content, the answer is no because were making a choice to put the additional money into more streaming content which is a perfect preamble to remind everyone that gross margin in that way is a managed outcome.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You say you intend to remain active this year in share repurchases.  Your repurchase volume doesnt seem to have been affected much by the meteoric rise in Netflix stock.  Are we anywhere near the price of Netflix shares that was what prompted you to sc
componenttext: You say you intend to remain active this year in share repurchases.  Your repurchase volume doesnt seem to have been affected much by the meteoric rise in Netflix stock.  Are we anywhere near the price of Netflix shares that was what prompted you to scale back your share repurchase volumes?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No.  To expand on the answer, I would say that if you look at it in the rear view mirror, the stock looks expensive.  I can remember when we were [inaudible] and the Wall Street Journal back in January and in the middle of last year for repurchasing at re
componenttext: No.  To expand on the answer, I would say that if you look at it in the rear view mirror, the stock looks expensive.  I can remember when we were [inaudible] and the Wall Street Journal back in January and in the middle of last year for repurchasing at record high prices which now in retrospect look pretty [inaudible] so whether you think the stock is expensive or cheap depends entirely on your view [inaudible] the business and [inaudible] Netflix is a winner in a very large market than probably the target price at which youre willing to acquire the stock is relatively high and if in the alternative you think we get trampled or our margins get trampled in this space then perhaps its a low price that youre willing to buy and we have been and continue to be an optimistic view about our likely success in this space and as a result we have pretty aggressive targets at which were willing to buy stock and so far so good.

componenttext: The generous tens of millions that you refer to in devices, maybe two in the fall, as more devices sell and come to market with Netflix included in them.  Thats a little aggressive for the current situation.  In  mobile I would say not sure if its a sign up vehicle or just one of the many platforms that someone watches.  My intuition would be that its one of the many platforms that someone accesses Netflix with and that it helps, but either way its not that much work to put a client together for a mobile device so it makes sense for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The beautiful thing about Netflix is that its adaptive to the individual pace.  So if a subscriber really likes comedy, it will start featuring lots of comedy.  If a subscriber likes drama, TV shows, horror, it adapts to their tastes.  Thats our fun
componenttext: The beautiful thing about Netflix is that its adaptive to the individual pace.  So if a subscriber really likes comedy, it will start featuring lots of comedy.  If a subscriber likes drama, TV shows, horror, it adapts to their tastes.  Thats our fundamental focus, which is learning the taste of each of our members and presenting them an experience that makes them feel how Netflix has all the stuff that I really want to watch so we really dont focus on programming for categories or types.  Its really a broad set of content and then the real focus is on learning and adapting in the user interface for the particular case.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Still teasing that out and not prepared to talk about it publicly.  We could very comfortably support 1.5 turns of debt.  There is [inaudible] currently less than 0.8 to 1 but I would want the capital structure to be conservative enough so that the compan
componenttext:
Still teasing that out and not prepared to talk about it publicly.  We could very comfortably support 1.5 turns of debt.  There is [inaudible] currently less than 0.8 to 1 but I would want the capital structure to be conservative enough so that the company, if we were ever challenged competitively, would never be constrained on the operating decisions we made to confront competition and I wouldnt want that leverage to get in the way of any decisions we might want to make in the future.  
On the other hand, the business is growing rapidly. The competitive motes seem well established.  Were very optimistic about their future, so why dont we put some calls in the context of our interests in using proceeds from [inaudible] financing to repurchase shares.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The bigger driver than how much leverage is just that were clearly not in a mode of trying to build our cash out.  If we had not done any buyback over the last three years, wed have a $1 billion on the balance sheet. That sounds good, its a nice
componenttext: The bigger driver than how much leverage is just that were clearly not in a mode of trying to build our cash out.  If we had not done any buyback over the last three years, wed have a $1 billion on the balance sheet. That sounds good, its a nice dress up line, but we are really happy with the decisions that weve made to keep cash pretty steady and to return that money to shareholders.  That part we are happy to talk about.

componenttext: Im not sure on the savings. Architecturally were big believers in the public cloud for any company that doesnt have Google or Facebooks scale.  As you know, you get the big advantage of their vast resources.  So we think it will help us with cost and it will help with reliability.  Its obviously early in the public [cloud] movement. Well see a lot of new companies enter that space and the vigorous competition will help draw the prices down which will benefit for us if were architected for the public cloud.

componenttext: Barrys got a good anecdote in that one.  We moved our encoding facility out of our internal data center in Amazon about six months ago and when we got the sudden ability to do the Apple iPad and we had to do a very large encoding job, we would never have been able - it would have taken six months in our prior internal data center. Because of the elasticity of the public cloud, we were able to spin up thousands and thousands of encoding [inaudible] and do it in parallel.  So youre right Barry that weve already seen good progress from that.

componenttext: Mario, I will personally deliver that last DVD in 2030 and yes, thats still our best guess on when we look at the DVD market.  Our DVD shipments are continuing to climb throughout the country, even in the Bay area where you see this astounding, up to 24% of bay area households subscribing to Netflix, and our DVD shipments, DVD and Bluray combined are continuing to grow.  So DVDs got a lot of legs there and 2030 is still the target.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On the web, the basic model is that youre a web based or internet based service available on devices that have web browsers and speak internet.  So thats the basic paradigm.  As opposed to well, its one price on this type of PC, its another on
componenttext: On the web, the basic model is that youre a web based or internet based service available on devices that have web browsers and speak internet.  So thats the basic paradigm.  As opposed to well, its one price on this type of PC, its another on a different machine, and were very much a webcentric internet video firm in that way and because of that we tend not to think about things like extra charges for certain modalities of access.  We do think about charges for HD or more content, but thats across all of the devices that are simply to us internet access devices.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relatio
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We released earnings for the first quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's r
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We released earnings for the first quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com.  Like last quarter, this call will consist solely of Q&A, and we're going to conduct the Q&A via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to ir@netflix.com, and please note that this is a new e-mail address from previous quarters.
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 22, 2010. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific time today.
Before moving into the Q&A, I would like to turn the call over to Reed for opening remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Deborah, and welcome, everyone, to today's Q&A session. Q1 was another outstanding quarter. We saw record net sales [id 1:48] additions, the lowest SAC and churn in our history and EPS grew 59% year-over-year. At the same time, the percentage o
componenttext: Thank you, Deborah, and welcome, everyone, to today's Q&A session. Q1 was another outstanding quarter. We saw record net sales [id 1:48] additions, the lowest SAC and churn in our history and EPS grew 59% year-over-year. At the same time, the percentage of our subscribers streaming movies and TV episodes in the last 90 days grew to 55%. This was driven by the progress we've made in enhancing our streaming content offering, expanding breadth of Netflix-enabled devices and improving the user interface.  And as our guidance for the remainder of 2010 indicates, we expect our momentum to continue. So with that, let's go over to questions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. The first question is from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Can you share any insights into the viewing habits of Watch Instantly customers? How many times per month does a typical user stream? Have you seen any material impact on disc usage?
componenttext: Great. The first question is from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Can you share any insights into the viewing habits of Watch Instantly customers? How many times per month does a typical user stream? Have you seen any material impact on disc usage? Is the viewing skewed materially to TV content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Steven, it's Reed here. Think it's a distribution of instant-watching users like any normal distribution. Theres some people who barely use it; theres some who use it a lot; theres -- it's a pretty typical normal distribution. TV and movies, it's
componenttext: Steven, it's Reed here. Think it's a distribution of instant-watching users like any normal distribution. Theres some people who barely use it; theres some who use it a lot; theres -- it's a pretty typical normal distribution. TV and movies, it's more towards TV than on DVD, but movies are still the majority. We're continuing to strengthen the TV side. What's the last part, related to usage? And on the usage question, it appears that we're seeing some substitution of DVD rental for streaming.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And the second question, what is the largest competitive threat facing Netflix today, kiosk vendors, digital VOD or traditional cable VOD?
componenttext: And the second question, what is the largest competitive threat facing Netflix today, kiosk vendors, digital VOD or traditional cable VOD?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Steven, there's a lot of competitive threats, and it's always hard to figure out what the biggest ones are. Certainly, cable satellite, Telco, MSO, just improving their product is the biggest one. The better, more on-demand, more HDTV everywhere, th
componenttext: Well, Steven, there's a lot of competitive threats, and it's always hard to figure out what the biggest ones are. Certainly, cable satellite, Telco, MSO, just improving their product is the biggest one. The better, more on-demand, more HDTV everywhere, theyre continuing to improve that, and that's a competitor a time [? 3:58] at least. And then, theres the potential emergence of direct competitors we refer to who well see what they do, potentially others over time. But TV shows and movies, that's a very, very broad competitive set, but the up side is it's a very big market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next questions are from Youssef Squali of Jefferies & Co. What do you believe is the likely impact of the Postal Service going from six-day delivery to five days on your DVD-by-mail business?
componenttext: Next questions are from Youssef Squali of Jefferies & Co. What do you believe is the likely impact of the Postal Service going from six-day delivery to five days on your DVD-by-mail business?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yousseff, it's Reed here. We're not particularly concerned as our streaming grows. We will be less and less sensitive to particular postal variations. The soonest they're talking about it actually taking effect would be the middle of next year. So it's no
componenttext: Yousseff, it's Reed here. We're not particularly concerned as our streaming grows. We will be less and less sensitive to particular postal variations. The soonest they're talking about it actually taking effect would be the middle of next year. So it's not a good thing for us. We hope they hold off as long as possible, but we're also cognizant that the total health of the USPS is at stake and they may need to make changes that they need to make.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: He had a second question. What kind of adoption are you seeing on the Wii platform since its launch? Would the cost be higher or lower than your average?
componenttext: He had a second question. What kind of adoption are you seeing on the Wii platform since its launch? Would the cost be higher or lower than your average?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On the Wii, we're real happy with the first two weeks here. The application's working great. We're shipping more discs every day, so we couldn't be happier on it. And there's no particular cost difference from any of our other platforms.
componenttext: On the Wii, we're real happy with the first two weeks here. The application's working great. We're shipping more discs every day, so we couldn't be happier on it. And there's no particular cost difference from any of our other platforms.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next questions are from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. Can you provide any more color on the HBO deal mentioned in the transcript? How broad is this deal?
componenttext: Next questions are from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. Can you provide any more color on the HBO deal mentioned in the transcript? How broad is this deal?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, it's Reed. The 28-day deal or the HBO deal is in reference to our DVD and Blu-ray purchasing; that is, we figured out a 28-day dial deal with them like we have with Warner Bros.
componenttext: Mark, it's Reed. The 28-day deal or the HBO deal is in reference to our DVD and Blu-ray purchasing; that is, we figured out a 28-day dial deal with them like we have with Warner Bros.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question, do you have any indications yet as to whether the 28-day windows are causing any satisfaction problems with your customers?
componenttext: Second question, do you have any indications yet as to whether the 28-day windows are causing any satisfaction problems with your customers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, our indication is our record-low churn. Weve continued to improve our service, taking all of the savings from the 28-day DVD, importing it into more streaming, and you see the net benefit in our record-low churn.
componenttext: Yes, our indication is our record-low churn. Weve continued to improve our service, taking all of the savings from the 28-day DVD, importing it into more streaming, and you see the net benefit in our record-low churn.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. As instant-watch viewing increases, are you starting to see subscribers change from multi-out to single-out subscription? If so, will lower operating costs from streaming offset the churn, and over what
componenttext: Next question is from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. As instant-watch viewing increases, are you starting to see subscribers change from multi-out to single-out subscription? If so, will lower operating costs from streaming offset the churn, and over what time horizon should we think about this leveling out?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let's see, Ryan. It's not so much that people who have been with us for a couple years on a two-out or three-out switch down. There's a little bit of that, but it's not material. It's mostly that as we grow the new people coming in are differentially choo
componenttext: Let's see, Ryan. It's not so much that people who have been with us for a couple years on a two-out or three-out switch down. There's a little bit of that, but it's not material. It's mostly that as we grow the new people coming in are differentially choosing our one-out, $9-a-month plan. So that's where you get the majority of the ASP effect from. We're very happy with the margin structure that, that generates for us and on the earning stream. So I hope that, that answers your question.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that apparently we had a backfill [id 7:19] on the switching migration by price point, roughly 1% of subs a month migrate down, roughly 1% migrates up, like 1.2, 1.2. And on balance for the last quarter, we had 4,500 more subs migrate up than migr
componenttext: I think that apparently we had a backfill [id 7:19] on the switching migration by price point, roughly 1% of subs a month migrate down, roughly 1% migrates up, like 1.2, 1.2. And on balance for the last quarter, we had 4,500 more subs migrate up than migrate down. So in prior quarter we've said it happens a little bit on balance slightly more than up, and that remains the current trend in the biz. So it just isnt a dominant considerable behavior.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: He had a second question. vitaminwater recently aired an ad that mentioned searching Netflix for a guilty pleasure marathon. Is there a formal relationship or is this an example of Netflix becoming more a part of social vernacular?
componenttext: He had a second question. vitaminwater recently aired an ad that mentioned searching Netflix for a guilty pleasure marathon. Is there a formal relationship or is this an example of Netflix becoming more a part of social vernacular?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The latter, Ryan.
componenttext: The latter, Ryan.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from David Miller of Caris & Company. Of the $200 million in leverage which was sourced late last year, can you say what portion has gone to source streaming rights, what portion has gone towards stock buybacks and what portion has gone t
componenttext: Next question is from David Miller of Caris & Company. Of the $200 million in leverage which was sourced late last year, can you say what portion has gone to source streaming rights, what portion has gone towards stock buybacks and what portion has gone towards working capital?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The question refers to the $200 million debt deal we closed in November of last year. As you know from the Q4 and Q1 results, cash flow from operations is positive and free cash flow has been positive. And so what the working capital needs of the business
componenttext: The question refers to the $200 million debt deal we closed in November of last year. As you know from the Q4 and Q1 results, cash flow from operations is positive and free cash flow has been positive. And so what the working capital needs of the business are self-funding, and cash flow from operations includes all of the expenses and investments in contact related to streaming, and so that has been self-funding. So by default, the bulk of the proceeds have gone for either stock buyback or to replenish cash on the balance sheet, and its actually been a combination of both.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next questions are from Doug Anmuth of Barclays Capital. Why shift marketing spend to content in the second half when you really have the opportunity to grow the subscriber base and can clearly fund the content spend other ways?
componenttext: The next questions are from Doug Anmuth of Barclays Capital. Why shift marketing spend to content in the second half when you really have the opportunity to grow the subscriber base and can clearly fund the content spend other ways?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Doug, it's a legitimate question. I think probably either one would get us great growth. I just want to point out that when we invest in streaming content, that also attracts more subscribers because it improves the service. So they're both vehicles for g
componenttext: Doug, it's a legitimate question. I think probably either one would get us great growth. I just want to point out that when we invest in streaming content, that also attracts more subscribers because it improves the service. So they're both vehicles for growth, and we make judgment calls between the two. But on the margin, our results are not that sensitive to it. That is, if it were $10 million or $15 million, one way or the other, wed get really the same growth. So think of it as we're continuing to invest adequately in marketing and generously in terms of the streaming content, which was a strategy decision.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So our approach and objective, youd say, with respect to the streaming is to improve the overall quality of the service by year end. And that serves the long-term strategic objectives of improving the value proposition, which increases lifetime value b
componenttext: So our approach and objective, youd say, with respect to the streaming is to improve the overall quality of the service by year end. And that serves the long-term strategic objectives of improving the value proposition, which increases lifetime value by lowering churn and improved word of mouth, which lowers SAC and the combination you see at play in the most recent quarter and in the prior quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Doug. What is your view of the iPad, more of a new-subscriber driver or another device for subscribers that will improve value proposition, reduce churn, et cetera?
componenttext: Second question from Doug. What is your view of the iPad, more of a new-subscriber driver or another device for subscribers that will improve value proposition, reduce churn, et cetera?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, a little of both, Doug. I mean, it's a great device. Itll grow over time in both its impact and usage. And as we've mentioned, we'll expand under the iPhone also and, of course, that's a much bigger install base but a smaller screen. So both of tho
componenttext: Oh, a little of both, Doug. I mean, it's a great device. Itll grow over time in both its impact and usage. And as we've mentioned, we'll expand under the iPhone also and, of course, that's a much bigger install base but a smaller screen. So both of those will be good. I would say overall its a relatively small part of video viewing. Most of our focus is on television, either directly with Wi-Fi TV or through the Blu-Ray player or through the video game console. But it's easy enough to support mobile, so we're doing that also.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. The next question is from Tony Wible of Janney Montgomery Scott. When does the Starz contract come up for renewal?
componenttext: Great. The next question is from Tony Wible of Janney Montgomery Scott. When does the Starz contract come up for renewal?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tony, it's Reed. We don't talk about the details of any of the contracts, but we're not overly dependent on any single piece of content. We're continuing to grow our total content, and we're confident we'll be able to continue to grow that content this ye
componenttext: Tony, it's Reed. We don't talk about the details of any of the contracts, but we're not overly dependent on any single piece of content. We're continuing to grow our total content, and we're confident we'll be able to continue to grow that content this year, next year and going forward as we are able to invest more money in it, which we have been.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next couple of questions are from Mark Harding at Maxim Group. First, could you comment on the linearity of subscriber adds during the quarter?
componenttext: The next couple of questions are from Mark Harding at Maxim Group. First, could you comment on the linearity of subscriber adds during the quarter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let's see. Mark, historically what we've seen is seasonality effects in calendar Q1 and calendar Q4. We've growth just after the Christmas holiday season, so back-end loaded in Q4 and front-end loaded in Q1. And then growth during Q2 was relatively
componenttext: Well, let's see. Mark, historically what we've seen is seasonality effects in calendar Q1 and calendar Q4. We've growth just after the Christmas holiday season, so back-end loaded in Q4 and front-end loaded in Q1. And then growth during Q2 was relatively back-end loaded and during Q3 its pretty linear across the quarter. Our growth patterns this quarter were less pronounced with the growth in partners and repeal [ph] streaming and with the launch of Wii, we have seen sort of a non-traditional growth pattern during the second quarter and incremental margin spending around that growth as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question. Can you update us on the split between new releases and catalog DVDs? And can you provide any similar metrics for streaming, perhaps newer releases through your Starz relationship versus older title?
componenttext: Second question. Can you update us on the split between new releases and catalog DVDs? And can you provide any similar metrics for streaming, perhaps newer releases through your Starz relationship versus older title?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, on DVD, we haven't seen any material changes in years, so that's been a pretty consistent story. And on streaming, we haven't provided any color on the breakout between different types of content or images.
componenttext: Mark, on DVD, we haven't seen any material changes in years, so that's been a pretty consistent story. And on streaming, we haven't provided any color on the breakout between different types of content or images.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Can the company share the number of subscribers who are utilizing streaming for virtually all of their Netflix consumption? If not, might you share that percentage in the future?
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Can the company share the number of subscribers who are utilizing streaming for virtually all of their Netflix consumption? If not, might you share that percentage in the future?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a pretty small number. Almost everybody watches DVDs also, of our subscriber base, and we don't have any plans to break that out. What we are focused on is driving up the percentage of people who do some screening and see that as the key metric, whic
componenttext: It's a pretty small number. Almost everybody watches DVDs also, of our subscriber base, and we don't have any plans to break that out. What we are focused on is driving up the percentage of people who do some screening and see that as the key metric, which is why we developed it and are continuing to update everyone on it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord Adams. Could you speak a little bit more extensively concerning the levels of activation you have seen on all the various connected devices via television, set-top boxes and portable devices such as the i
componenttext: The next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord Adams. Could you speak a little bit more extensively concerning the levels of activation you have seen on all the various connected devices via television, set-top boxes and portable devices such as the iPad?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Not particularly in terms of the levels of activation that we're going to talk about, but probably underlying the question is trying to get some insight into how people are using the service. And a key insight for you is that there's a significant amount
componenttext: Not particularly in terms of the levels of activation that we're going to talk about, but probably underlying the question is trying to get some insight into how people are using the service. And a key insight for you is that there's a significant amount of people that are hooking or watching on a PC and are watching with a PC hooked to a TV, which to us looks like a PC. And so don't think about it as the only thing that matters is the Xbox or the PS3. It's really a very broad usage pattern across a whole lot of devices, even in a given single household has people accessing Netflix from multiple devices. And that's part of the strength of our service in really being an Internet video service is to be on all the devices that the Internet is on and have consumers think about us as an Internet service across all of our devices.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Melinda Davies of Susquehannah Financial Group. A question about the new distribution deal with Warner Bros. Now that you have Blind Side, for example, do you have enough to fulfill demand for DVDs, our demand sense for Blind Side 28
componenttext: Next question is from Melinda Davies of Susquehannah Financial Group. A question about the new distribution deal with Warner Bros. Now that you have Blind Side, for example, do you have enough to fulfill demand for DVDs, our demand sense for Blind Side 28 days after the DVD release similar to what you've been seeing for new releases of this type in the past? We are trying to understand if there is "pent-up demand" from Netflix subscribers, or are Netflix subscribers shifting to pay-per-view and/or buying DVDs for the new releases and using Netflix for other content like older movies, TV shows, et cetera.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Melinda, there's a little bit of both, as you would expect. There are people who, because of the 28-day, are turned to buying the DVDs, first because it's widely promoted at Wal-Mart and other places. There are some that take pay-per-view because Warner B
componenttext: Melinda, there's a little bit of both, as you would expect. There are people who, because of the 28-day, are turned to buying the DVDs, first because it's widely promoted at Wal-Mart and other places. There are some that take pay-per-view because Warner Bros. is aggressive on the pay-per-view licensing, and that's really the intent of the deal. In terms of the backlog, once it comes to the 28-day, we try to target to have enough DVDs to clear that backlog pretty quickly. There's a little bit of guesswork based on that, but we're still learning together with Warner Bros. on how to predict that, but that's the goal and intent.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. The next question is from Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Why is Netflix committed to staying out of the $40 billion-plus transaction-based pay-per-view market if we include DVD rental and sales? Why wouldn't content owners want me to sell new re
componenttext: Great. The next question is from Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Why is Netflix committed to staying out of the $40 billion-plus transaction-based pay-per-view market if we include DVD rental and sales? Why wouldn't content owners want me to sell new releases with the Netflix's strong brand and digital distribution channel if there will be multiple digital storefronts going forward?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's an interesting question. I would say at times content owners have wanted us to do that. I would say we don't see how we add much value in that. That is, when we buy DVDs, we buy them from Wal-Mart -- as consumers, from Wal-Mart or Amazon beca
componenttext: Well, that's an interesting question. I would say at times content owners have wanted us to do that. I would say we don't see how we add much value in that. That is, when we buy DVDs, we buy them from Wal-Mart -- as consumers, from Wal-Mart or Amazon because they do a great job at it. That's what their main focus is. And our focus is on subscription and, in part, to put or [id 17:50] it takes us a lot of work. So that's probably the main reason we don't do the, for example, selling DVDs. In terms of pay-per-view, then it's a very specific thing, which is, for example, Xbox has, and has had for years, a big pay-per-view business and if we had also had pay-per-view as part of our service, it would have been a lot harder to get distribution on the Xbox, similarly with PS3. And then, of course, you've seen now with Wal-Mart entering the pay-per-view market online with voodoo that many of those firms want to go after that business. And so it's really much smarter for us, we think, to be out of that, not in a position of conflict and just to be focused on our subscription business.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Edward Williams at BMO Capital Markets. In terms of the iPad app, how does it affect your view of the mobile market for Watch Instantly?
componenttext: The next question is from Edward Williams at BMO Capital Markets. In terms of the iPad app, how does it affect your view of the mobile market for Watch Instantly?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it doesn't change it, Edward. As I said a few minutes ago, we look at mobile for video viewing as a nice extra because it's pretty easy as opposed to fundamental. And the really TV-based and laptop-based screen, sort of a primary screen, is what w
componenttext: I think it doesn't change it, Edward. As I said a few minutes ago, we look at mobile for video viewing as a nice extra because it's pretty easy as opposed to fundamental. And the really TV-based and laptop-based screen, sort of a primary screen, is what we're focused on.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His second question, how much of your share buyback program is left? And on top of that, another modeling question, what should we assume for a tax rate in 2010?
componenttext: His second question, how much of your share buyback program is left? And on top of that, another modeling question, what should we assume for a tax rate in 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, with respect to the second part of the answer, probably 41% for the tax rate. And we upped levels, at least in response to the question on the buyback program. You should imagine that as we -- if we exhaust the current buyback authorization that the
componenttext: Well, with respect to the second part of the answer, probably 41% for the tax rate. And we upped levels, at least in response to the question on the buyback program. You should imagine that as we -- if we exhaust the current buyback authorization that therell be additional authorizations, and you should expect that to continue to be active in repurchasing the stock.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer & Co. As you begin to acquire content for international streaming, would you expect the subscriber economics to be different from the U.S. business, and how could this impact margin?
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer & Co. As you begin to acquire content for international streaming, would you expect the subscriber economics to be different from the U.S. business, and how could this impact margin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, we'll be able to talk more about international at the end of the year. In our guidance is built in the modest expenditures we have planned for this year.
componenttext: Jason, we'll be able to talk more about international at the end of the year. In our guidance is built in the modest expenditures we have planned for this year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: A question from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Is the increase in stock-based compensation that we saw in Q1 a level that will be sustained throughout the year?
componenttext: A question from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Is the increase in stock-based compensation that we saw in Q1 a level that will be sustained throughout the year?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Probably so, yes, a modulo on new employee hiring during the year and the thing that should give you comfort that's likely to be true is that it was relatively flat plus or minus a couple hundred thousand dollars last year and the year before that. So the
componenttext: Probably so, yes, a modulo on new employee hiring during the year and the thing that should give you comfort that's likely to be true is that it was relatively flat plus or minus a couple hundred thousand dollars last year and the year before that. So the big drivers of incremental expense would be increased volatility, both implied and actual, and employee growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And we're on a calendar-year review cycle. So generally, it'll be stable during the year and then on the shift over the calendar-year boundary.
componenttext: And we're on a calendar-year review cycle. So generally, it'll be stable during the year and then on the shift over the calendar-year boundary.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next set of questions are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. With regards to gross margin, the recent meet sheet [ph 21:05] coupons you sent out offering 10% off the next monthly bill to users to install Watch Instantly on their Wii lead us to belie
componenttext: The next set of questions are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. With regards to gross margin, the recent meet sheet [ph 21:05] coupons you sent out offering 10% off the next monthly bill to users to install Watch Instantly on their Wii lead us to believe that streaming users are materially higher margin than non-streaming users given they watch less DVDs. Can you give us any idea of some margin difference between streaming and non-streaming users?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, we're not commenting on gross margin for streamers versus non-streamers. You're right that if there's a shift at a high level -- you're right that all things being equal if there's a shift away from DVD towards streaming, it could be an accelerant
componenttext: Scott, we're not commenting on gross margin for streamers versus non-streamers. You're right that if there's a shift at a high level -- you're right that all things being equal if there's a shift away from DVD towards streaming, it could be an accelerant of gross margin. But you should also remember that we've explicitly said that all things will not be equal and that to the extent that there's more profit in the business, our objective is to reinvest the profit in improving the user experience. So in that way, margins is a managed outcome. And our objective is to take what would have been higher margins, reinvest it in the business in order to drive faster subscriber growth and lower churn and lower SAC and increased competitive modes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then specifically on the Wii test, that was just our ever aggressive product and marketing new testing various things so that the program you refer to is just a test at this point.
componenttext: And then specifically on the Wii test, that was just our ever aggressive product and marketing new testing various things so that the program you refer to is just a test at this point.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Scott Devitt. With Redbox considering a streaming service at a lower price point than your $8.99 per month subscription, are you revisiting the idea of offering a streaming-only subscription plan at a lower price point?
componenttext: Second question from Scott Devitt. With Redbox considering a streaming service at a lower price point than your $8.99 per month subscription, are you revisiting the idea of offering a streaming-only subscription plan at a lower price point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No, Scott. Redbox does many things incredibly well, but we're not worried about them particularly as a streaming competitor. So anything they do with streaming doesn't affect how we think about that space.
componenttext: No, Scott. Redbox does many things incredibly well, but we're not worried about them particularly as a streaming competitor. So anything they do with streaming doesn't affect how we think about that space.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, given the ever-expanding number of Netflix-enabled devices, have you seen or do you expect to see consumers trading up to higher-price subscription plans in order to watch multiple videos simultaneously, either multiple people in different ro
componenttext: And finally, given the ever-expanding number of Netflix-enabled devices, have you seen or do you expect to see consumers trading up to higher-price subscription plans in order to watch multiple videos simultaneously, either multiple people in different rooms in the house, mobile users watching while others at home are as well, or to have Netflix enabled on greater than six devices?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: In the next year or two, we don't anticipate much of that. It's pretty much a one-account-per-family model in the near term.
componenttext: In the next year or two, we don't anticipate much of that. It's pretty much a one-account-per-family model in the near term.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next questions are from Andy Hargreaves at Pacific Crest Securities. To your knowledge, are cable satellite subscribers who cancel citing your service in increasing numbers? If so, could that impact your ability to gain access to TV content?
componenttext: Next questions are from Andy Hargreaves at Pacific Crest Securities. To your knowledge, are cable satellite subscribers who cancel citing your service in increasing numbers? If so, could that impact your ability to gain access to TV content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Andy, there's been a bunch of stories about so-called cord cutting, but we haven't seen a lot of it. Netflix has a subset of the content available on a typical MSO system, but were seeing no historics. So it's not much of a substitute for the packages
componenttext: Andy, there's been a bunch of stories about so-called cord cutting, but we haven't seen a lot of it. Netflix has a subset of the content available on a typical MSO system, but were seeing no historics. So it's not much of a substitute for the packages that MSOs offer.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: He had a second question with regards to G&A. What drove the increase in the quarter and should G&A stay around the Q1 level through 2010?[

He had a second question with regards to G&A. What drove the increase in the quarter and should G&A stay around the Q1 level through 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Two contributing factors primarily. On the comp side, the CEO swapped a very large percentage of his comp this year versus last year into options and that has a higher rate of expense. So he's doubling down his investment in the business in that way. That
componenttext: Two contributing factors primarily. On the comp side, the CEO swapped a very large percentage of his comp this year versus last year into options and that has a higher rate of expense. So he's doubling down his investment in the business in that way. Thats encouraging. And then secondly, as the brand has grown, the Plaintiffs Bar has become more active, and legal expenses, as a consequence, are up on a year-over-year and Q-over-Q basis.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next set of questions are from Barton Crockett at Lazard. The first is a long-term content question. As Netflix subscriber base grows and seemingly gets closer and closer to total subscribers for premium pay-TV network, like HBO, Showtime and Stazr, d
componenttext: The next set of questions are from Barton Crockett at Lazard. The first is a long-term content question. As Netflix subscriber base grows and seemingly gets closer and closer to total subscribers for premium pay-TV network, like HBO, Showtime and Stazr, does the company ever need to think about borrowing a page from their strategy and investing in unique original content? Over the long term, it seems that for a video network to remain relevant to consumers and ward off competition, it needs unique content. Otherwise, the checkbook becomes the main barrier to entry, which is not sustainable. Do you agree or disagree with that thought?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Barton, its a good, deep analysis, but I would disagree. And your premise is that video services such as HBO and Starz need original content to differentiate, and I'm not in disagreement with that part. But what Netflix has to differentiate is the user
componenttext: Barton, its a good, deep analysis, but I would disagree. And your premise is that video services such as HBO and Starz need original content to differentiate, and I'm not in disagreement with that part. But what Netflix has to differentiate is the user-interface personalization on-demand aspect of the Internet and lap [ph 41:43]. And our view is that we can remain a packager and be significantly differentiated from other services because our value add is not just the content, it's all of the recommendations, how people interact with them, helping them match with content they're going to end up loving. So our view is we won't ever need to go into original series. I would certainly say if we ever did, we probably have the wrong CEO, and we shouldn't be based in Silicon Valley, and there's a number of other things that make that an unpromising avenue. So instead, what we're focused on is can we license the content as we have with Starz. We have some content from Showtime, not yet anything from FX or HBO. And as those firms look at us, they can look at us two ways. One is, geez, were another packager of movies and a potential competitor, or they can look at it as we're a natural distributor for their original series. And when you see the enormous success that Starz is having with Spartacus, that Showtime has had with Weeds, Californication and others and, of course, HBO has for many years, you can see that those services are differentially good at the original series. And so we'll be hopeful these alliances and partnerships will view us as a great distributor writing them big checks for their original content. We focus on packaging and they focus on the original series.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is related to gross margin on the 28-day window. Did the new 28-day window deal with Warner Bros. have a meaningful impact on Q1 gross margin? Can you discuss whether it helped or hurt gross margins and the materiality of the impact? How
componenttext: The next question is related to gross margin on the 28-day window. Did the new 28-day window deal with Warner Bros. have a meaningful impact on Q1 gross margin? Can you discuss whether it helped or hurt gross margins and the materiality of the impact? How do you see the 28-day window deal with Warner Bros. and other studios affecting gross margin for the balance of the year?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll let Barry talk about the gross margin as a whole, but you remember that what we're doing is saving money on DVD and then putting it into streaming.  Okay, so if you ask the question, are we saving money on DVD, the answer is yes. As for saving money
componenttext: I'll let Barry talk about the gross margin as a whole, but you remember that what we're doing is saving money on DVD and then putting it into streaming.  Okay, so if you ask the question, are we saving money on DVD, the answer is yes. As for saving money on content, the answer is no, because we're making a choice to put additional money into more streaming content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Which is a perfect preamble to remind everyone that gross margin in that way is a managed outcome.
componenttext: Which is a perfect preamble to remind everyone that gross margin in that way is a managed outcome.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The last question from Barton. You say you intend to remain active this year in share repurchases. Your repurchase volume doesn't seem to have been affected much by the meteoric rise in Netflix stock. Are we anywhere near a price of Netflix shares that wo
componenttext: The last question from Barton. You say you intend to remain active this year in share repurchases. Your repurchase volume doesn't seem to have been affected much by the meteoric rise in Netflix stock. Are we anywhere near a price of Netflix shares that would prompt you to scale back your share repurchase volume?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No. To expand on the answer, I would say that if you look at it in the rearview mirror, the stock looks expensive. I can remember when we were charted by the Heard on the Street, the Wall Street Journal back in January and in the middle of last year for r
componenttext: No. To expand on the answer, I would say that if you look at it in the rearview mirror, the stock looks expensive. I can remember when we were charted by the Heard on the Street, the Wall Street Journal back in January and in the middle of last year for repurchasing at record-high prices, which in now retrospect look pretty attractive. So whether you think the stock is expensive or cheap depends entirely on your view of the value of the business. And if you could imagine that Netflix is a winner in a very large market, then probably the target price at which you're willing to acquire the stock is relatively high and if, in the alternative, you think we get trampled or margins get trampled in this space, then you feel perhaps a small price of which you're willing to buy the stock.
