We basically -- as you know, you get to take advantage of their vast resources. So we think itll help us with costs, itll help with reliability. Its obviously early in the public Cloud movement. We'll see a lot of new companies enter that space and the vigorous competition will help draw the prices down, which should benefit for us if we're architected for the public Cloud.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Generally, its made us more nimble, our ability to encode the library for new platform launches in short periods of time.
componenttext: Generally, its made us more nimble, our ability to encode the library for new platform launches in short periods of time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That's right. Barrys got a good anecdote in that one. We moved our encoding facility out of our internal data center into Amazon about six months ago. And when we got the sudden ability to do the Apple iPad and we had to do a very large encoding job, w
componenttext: That's right. Barrys got a good anecdote in that one. We moved our encoding facility out of our internal data center into Amazon about six months ago. And when we got the sudden ability to do the Apple iPad and we had to do a very large encoding job, we would never have been able to  it would've taken six months in our prior internal data center. But because of the elasticity of the public Cloud, we were able to spin up thousands and thousands of encoding codes and do it in parallel. So youre right, Barry, we've already seen good progress from that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mario Cibelli at Marathon Partners. Will Netflix still deliver its last DVD in 2030?
componenttext: The next question is from Mario Cibelli at Marathon Partners. Will Netflix still deliver its last DVD in 2030?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mario, I will personally deliver that last DVD in 2030. And yes, that's still our best guess on when we look at the DVD market. Our DVD shipments are continuing to climb throughout the country, even in the Bay Area where you see this astounding up of 24%
componenttext: Mario, I will personally deliver that last DVD in 2030. And yes, that's still our best guess on when we look at the DVD market. Our DVD shipments are continuing to climb throughout the country, even in the Bay Area where you see this astounding up of 24% of Bay Area households subscribing to Netflix. And our DVD shipments, DVD and Blu-Ray combined, are continuing to grow. So DVD has got a lot of legs here and 2030 is still the target.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Last couple of questions, and they are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Now that Netflix is available on the iPad and is expected on the iPhone, what is the likelihood that the Netflix app lands on Apple TV someday?
componenttext: Last couple of questions, and they are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Now that Netflix is available on the iPad and is expected on the iPhone, what is the likelihood that the Netflix app lands on Apple TV someday?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You know, Apple declared themselves about two months ago to be a mobile company, theyre focused on mobile, mobile, mobile, so I'm not sure how much going forward that they're going to spend on Apple TV. If they decide to invest in it, it's something th
componenttext: You know, Apple declared themselves about two months ago to be a mobile company, theyre focused on mobile, mobile, mobile, so I'm not sure how much going forward that they're going to spend on Apple TV. If they decide to invest in it, it's something that would make sense for us. But at this point, it's not their focus. Their focus is on mobile, and well work with them on all of those mobile platforms as we have been.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, given the increased focused on mobile devices and the incremental engineering costs associated with developing products for these platforms, do you see any opportunity to monetize this customer base differently? For example, offering a higher
componenttext: And finally, given the increased focused on mobile devices and the incremental engineering costs associated with developing products for these platforms, do you see any opportunity to monetize this customer base differently? For example, offering a higher-priced plan that includes mobile access similar to Blu-Ray?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No. On the web, the basic model is that youre a web-based or Internet-based service available on devices that have web browsers and speak Internet. So that's the basic paradigm as opposed to , well, it's one price on this type of PC, another price on a
componenttext: No. On the web, the basic model is that youre a web-based or Internet-based service available on devices that have web browsers and speak Internet. So that's the basic paradigm as opposed to , well, it's one price on this type of PC, another price on a  different machine. And we're very much a web-centric, Internet-video firm in that way and because of that, we tend not to think about things like extra charges for certain modalities of access. We do think about charges for HD, or we think about more content, but that's across all of the devices that are simply, to us, Internet-access devices.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Operator, that's the last question I have. Before we conclude the call, I would like to turn the call back over to Reed Hastings for some closing remarks.
componenttext: Great. Operator, that's the last question I have. Before we conclude the call, I would like to turn the call back over to Reed Hastings for some closing remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Deborah, and thanks all of you for joining us on the call. Q1 was another great quarter. And as you can see from our guidance, we're well positioned for continued growth and I look forward to reporting to you on our progress on next quarter's call
componenttext: Thanks, Deborah, and thanks all of you for joining us on the call. Q1 was another great quarter. And as you can see from our guidance, we're well positioned for continued growth and I look forward to reporting to you on our progress on next quarter's call.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: This does conclude your program. Thank you for your participation, and have a wonderful day. You may disconnect your lines at this time.
componenttext: This does conclude your program. Thank you for your participation, and have a wonderful day. You may disconnect your lines at this time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relatio
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We released earnings for the first quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's r
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We released earnings for the first quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. Like last quarter, this call will consist solely of Q&A, and we're going to conduct the Q&A via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to ir@netflix.com, and please note that this is a new e-mail address from previous quarters.
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 22, 2010. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific Time today.
Before moving into the Q&A, I would like to turn the call over to Reed for opening remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Deborah, and welcome, everyone, to today's Q&A session. Q1 was another outstanding quarter. We saw record net sub [subscriber] additions, the lowest SAC [subscriber acquisition costs] and churn in our history and EPS grew 59% year-over-year. At th
componenttext: Thanks, Deborah, and welcome, everyone, to today's Q&A session. Q1 was another outstanding quarter. We saw record net sub [subscriber] additions, the lowest SAC [subscriber acquisition costs] and churn in our history and EPS grew 59% year-over-year. At the same time, the percentage of our subscribers streaming movies and TV episodes in the last 90 days grew to 55%. This was driven by the progress we've made in enhancing our streaming content offering, expanding the breadth of Netflix-enabled devices and improving the user interface. And as our guidance for the remainder of 2010 indicates, we expect our momentum to continue. So with that, let's go over to questions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. The first question is from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Can you share any insights into the viewing habits of Watch Instantly customers? How many times per month does a typical user stream? Have you seen any material impact on disc usage?
componenttext: Great. The first question is from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Can you share any insights into the viewing habits of Watch Instantly customers? How many times per month does a typical user stream? Have you seen any material impact on disc usage? Is the viewing skewed materially to TV content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Steven, it's Reed here. Think it's a distribution of instant-watching users like any normal distribution. Theres some people who barely use it, theres some who use it a lot. Theres -- it's a pretty typical normal distribution. TV and movies, it's
componenttext: Steven, it's Reed here. Think it's a distribution of instant-watching users like any normal distribution. Theres some people who barely use it, theres some who use it a lot. Theres -- it's a pretty typical normal distribution. TV and movies, it's more towards TV than on DVD, but movies are still the majority. We're continuing to strengthen the TV side. What's the last part, related to usage? And on the usage question, it appears that we're seeing some substitution of DVD rental for streaming.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: He had a second question. What is the largest competitive threat facing Netflix today, kiosk vendors, digital VOD [video-on-demand] or traditional cable VOD?
componenttext: He had a second question. What is the largest competitive threat facing Netflix today, kiosk vendors, digital VOD [video-on-demand] or traditional cable VOD?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Steven, there's a lot of competitive threats, and it's always hard to figure out what the biggest ones are. Certainly, cable, satellite, Telco, MSO [Multiple System Operator], just improving their product is the biggest one. The better, more on-dema
componenttext: Well, Steven, there's a lot of competitive threats, and it's always hard to figure out what the biggest ones are. Certainly, cable, satellite, Telco, MSO [Multiple System Operator], just improving their product is the biggest one. The better, more on-demand, more HDTV everywhere, theyre continuing to improve that, and that's a competitor for a time [ph] at least. And then, theres the potential emergence of direct competitors, we refer to Hulu, well see what they do, potentially others over time. But TV shows and movies, that's a very, very broad competitive set, but the upside is it's a very big market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next questions are from Youssef Squali of Jefferies & Company. What do you believe is the likely impact of the Postal Service going from six-day delivery to five days on your DVD by mail business?
componenttext: Next questions are from Youssef Squali of Jefferies & Company. What do you believe is the likely impact of the Postal Service going from six-day delivery to five days on your DVD by mail business?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yousseff, it's Reed here. We're not particularly concerned as our streaming grows. We'll be less and less sensitive to particular postal variations. The soonest they're talking about it actually taking effect would be the middle of next year. So it's not
componenttext: Yousseff, it's Reed here. We're not particularly concerned as our streaming grows. We'll be less and less sensitive to particular postal variations. The soonest they're talking about it actually taking effect would be the middle of next year. So it's not a good thing for us. We hope they hold off as long as possible, but we're also cognizant that the total health of the USPS is at stake and they may need to make changes that they need to make.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: He had a second question. What kind of adoption are you seeing on the Wii platform since its launch? Would the cost be higher or lower than your average?
componenttext: He had a second question. What kind of adoption are you seeing on the Wii platform since its launch? Would the cost be higher or lower than your average?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On the Wii, we're real happy with the first two weeks here. The application's working great. We're shipping more discs every day, so we couldn't be happier on it. And there's no particular cost difference from any of our other platforms.
componenttext: On the Wii, we're real happy with the first two weeks here. The application's working great. We're shipping more discs every day, so we couldn't be happier on it. And there's no particular cost difference from any of our other platforms.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next questions are from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. Can you provide any more color on the HBO deal mentioned in the transcript? How broad is this deal?
componenttext: Next questions are from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. Can you provide any more color on the HBO deal mentioned in the transcript? How broad is this deal?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, it's Reed. The 28-day deal or the HBO deal is in reference to our DVD and Blu-ray purchasing, that is, we figured out a 28-day style deal with them like we have with Warner Bros.
componenttext: Mark, it's Reed. The 28-day deal or the HBO deal is in reference to our DVD and Blu-ray purchasing, that is, we figured out a 28-day style deal with them like we have with Warner Bros.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question, do you have any indications yet as to whether the 28-day windows are causing any satisfaction problems with your customers?
componenttext: Second question, do you have any indications yet as to whether the 28-day windows are causing any satisfaction problems with your customers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, our indication is our record low churn. Weve continued to improve our service, taking all of the savings from the 28-day DVD and pouring it into more streaming. And you see the net benefit in our record low churn.
componenttext: Yes, our indication is our record low churn. Weve continued to improve our service, taking all of the savings from the 28-day DVD and pouring it into more streaming. And you see the net benefit in our record low churn.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. As instant-watch viewing increases, are you starting to see subscribers change from multi-out to single-out subscription? If so, will lower operating costs from streaming offset the churn, and over what
componenttext: Next question is from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. As instant-watch viewing increases, are you starting to see subscribers change from multi-out to single-out subscription? If so, will lower operating costs from streaming offset the churn, and over what time horizon should we think about this leveling out?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let's see, Ryan. It's not so much that people who have been with us for a couple years on a two-out or three-out switch down. There's a little bit of that, but it's not material. It's mostly that as we grow the new people coming in are differentially choo
componenttext: Let's see, Ryan. It's not so much that people who have been with us for a couple years on a two-out or three-out switch down. There's a little bit of that, but it's not material. It's mostly that as we grow the new people coming in are differentially choosing our one-out, $9-a-month plan. So that's where you get the majority of the ASP effect from. We're very happy with the margin structure that, that generates for us and on the earning stream. So I hope that, that answers your question. How do you think about it [ph], Barry?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the backfill, on the switching, the migration by price point, roughly 1% of subs a month migrates down, roughly 1% migrates up, like 1.2, 1.2. And on balance for the last quarter, we had 4,500 more subs migrate up than migrate down. So in prior quart
componenttext: Yes, the backfill, on the switching, the migration by price point, roughly 1% of subs a month migrates down, roughly 1% migrates up, like 1.2, 1.2. And on balance for the last quarter, we had 4,500 more subs migrate up than migrate down. So in prior quarter, we've said it happens a little bit on balance slightly more than up, and that remains the current trend in the biz. So it just isnt a dominant consumer behavior.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: He had a second question. vitaminwater recently aired an ad that mentioned searching Netflix for a guilty pleasure marathon. Is there a formal relationship, or is this an example of Netflix becoming more a part of social vernacular?
componenttext: He had a second question. vitaminwater recently aired an ad that mentioned searching Netflix for a guilty pleasure marathon. Is there a formal relationship, or is this an example of Netflix becoming more a part of social vernacular?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The latter, Ryan.
componenttext: The latter, Ryan.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from David Miller of Caris & Company. Of the $200 million in leverage, which was sourced late last year, can you say what portion has gone to source streaming rights, what portion has gone towards stock buybacks and what portion has gone
componenttext: Next question is from David Miller of Caris & Company. Of the $200 million in leverage, which was sourced late last year, can you say what portion has gone to source streaming rights, what portion has gone towards stock buybacks and what portion has gone towards working capital?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The question refers to the $200 million debt deal we closed in November of last year. As you know from the Q4 and Q1 results, cash flow from operations is positive and free cash flow has been positive. And so all of the working capital needs of the busine
componenttext: The question refers to the $200 million debt deal we closed in November of last year. As you know from the Q4 and Q1 results, cash flow from operations is positive and free cash flow has been positive. And so all of the working capital needs of the business are self funding. And cash flow from operations includes all of the expenses and investments in content related to streaming, and so that has been self funding. So by default, all of the of the proceeds have gone for either stock buyback or to replenish cash on the balance sheet, and its actually been a combination of both.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next questions are from Doug Anmuth of Barclays Capital. Why shift marketing spend to content in the second half when you really have the opportunity to grow the subscriber base and can clearly fund the content spend other ways?
componenttext: The next questions are from Doug Anmuth of Barclays Capital. Why shift marketing spend to content in the second half when you really have the opportunity to grow the subscriber base and can clearly fund the content spend other ways?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Doug, it's a legitimate question. I think probably either one would get us great growth. I just want to point out that when we invest in streaming content, that also attracts more subscribers because it improves the service. So they're both vehicles for g
componenttext: Doug, it's a legitimate question. I think probably either one would get us great growth. I just want to point out that when we invest in streaming content, that also attracts more subscribers because it improves the service. So they're both vehicles for growth, and we make judgment calls between the two. But on the margin, our results are not that sensitive to it. That is if it were $10 million or $15 million, one way or the other, wed get really the same growth. So think of it as we're continuing to invest adequately in marketing and generously in terms of the streaming content, which is a strategy decision.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So our approach and objective, youd say with respect to the streaming, is to improve the overall quality of the service by year end. And that serves the long-term strategic objectives of improving the value proposition, which increases lifetime value b
componenttext: So our approach and objective, youd say with respect to the streaming, is to improve the overall quality of the service by year end. And that serves the long-term strategic objectives of improving the value proposition, which increases lifetime value by lowering churn and improved word of mouth, which lowers SAC, and the combination you see at play in the most recent quarter and in the prior quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Doug. What is your view of the iPad, more of a new subscriber driver or another device for subscribers that will improve value proposition, reduce churn, et cetera?
componenttext: Second question from Doug. What is your view of the iPad, more of a new subscriber driver or another device for subscribers that will improve value proposition, reduce churn, et cetera?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, a little of both, Doug. I mean, it's a great device. Itll grow over time in both its impact and usage. And as we've mentioned, we'll expand under the iPhone also and, of course, that's a much bigger installed base but a smaller screen. So both of t
componenttext: Oh, a little of both, Doug. I mean, it's a great device. Itll grow over time in both its impact and usage. And as we've mentioned, we'll expand under the iPhone also and, of course, that's a much bigger installed base but a smaller screen. So both of those will be good. I would say overall, its a relatively small part of video viewing. Most of our focus is on television, either directly with Wi-Fi TV or through the Blu-ray player or through the video game console. But it's easy enough to support mobile, so we're doing that also.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. The next question is from Tony Wible of Janney Montgomery Scott. When does the Starz contract come up for renewal?
componenttext: Great. The next question is from Tony Wible of Janney Montgomery Scott. When does the Starz contract come up for renewal?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tony, it's Reed. We don't talk about the details of any of the contracts, but we're not overly dependent on any single piece of content. We're continuing to grow our total content, and we're confident we'll be able to continue to grow that content this ye
componenttext: Tony, it's Reed. We don't talk about the details of any of the contracts, but we're not overly dependent on any single piece of content. We're continuing to grow our total content, and we're confident we'll be able to continue to grow that content this year, next year and going forward as we are able to invest more money in it, which we have been.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next couple of questions are from Mark Harding at Maxim Group. First, could you comment on the linearity of subscriber adds during the quarter?
componenttext: The next couple of questions are from Mark Harding at Maxim Group. First, could you comment on the linearity of subscriber adds during the quarter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let's see. Mark, historically, what we've seen is seasonality effects in calendar Q1 and calendar Q4 with growth just after the Christmas holiday season. So back-end loaded in Q4 and front-end loaded in Q1. And then growth during Q2 was relatively b
componenttext: Well, let's see. Mark, historically, what we've seen is seasonality effects in calendar Q1 and calendar Q4 with growth just after the Christmas holiday season. So back-end loaded in Q4 and front-end loaded in Q1. And then growth during Q2 was relatively back-end loaded, and during Q3, its pretty linear across the quarter. Our growth patterns this quarter were less pronounced with the growth in partners and appeal of streaming. And with the launch of Wii, we'll see sort of a non-traditional growth pattern during the second quarter and incremental marketing spending around that growth as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question. Can you update us on the split between new releases and catalog DVDs? And can you provide any similar metrics for streaming, perhaps newer releases through your Starz relationship versus older title?
componenttext: Second question. Can you update us on the split between new releases and catalog DVDs? And can you provide any similar metrics for streaming, perhaps newer releases through your Starz relationship versus older title?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, on DVD, we haven't seen any material changes in years, so that's been a pretty consistent story. And on streaming, we haven't provided any color on the breakout between different types of content or ages.
componenttext: Mark, on DVD, we haven't seen any material changes in years, so that's been a pretty consistent story. And on streaming, we haven't provided any color on the breakout between different types of content or ages.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Can the company share the number of subscribers who are utilizing streaming for virtually all of their Netflix consumption? If not, might you share that percentage in the future?
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Can the company share the number of subscribers who are utilizing streaming for virtually all of their Netflix consumption? If not, might you share that percentage in the future?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a pretty small number. Almost everybody watches DVDs also of our subscriber base. And we don't have any plans to break that out. What we are focused on is driving up the percentage of people who do some screening and see that as the key metric, which
componenttext: It's a pretty small number. Almost everybody watches DVDs also of our subscriber base. And we don't have any plans to break that out. What we are focused on is driving up the percentage of people who do some screening and see that as the key metric, which is why we developed it and are continuing to update everyone on it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord Adams. Could you speak a little bit more extensively concerning the levels of activation you have seen on all the various connected devices via television, set-top boxes and portable devices such as the i
componenttext: The next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord Adams. Could you speak a little bit more extensively concerning the levels of activation you have seen on all the various connected devices via television, set-top boxes and portable devices such as the iPad?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Not particularly in terms of the levels of activation that we're going to talk about, but probably underlying the question is trying to get some insight into how people are using the service. And a key insight for you is that there's a significant amount
componenttext: Not particularly in terms of the levels of activation that we're going to talk about, but probably underlying the question is trying to get some insight into how people are using the service. And a key insight for you is that there's a significant amount of people that are hooking or watching on a PC and are watching with a PC hooked to a TV, which to us looks like a PC. And so don't think about it as the only thing that matters is the Xbox or the PS3. It's really a very broad usage pattern across a whole lot of devices, even in a given single household has people accessing Netflix from multiple devices. And that's part of the strength of our service in really being an Internet video service is to be on all the devices that the Internet is on and have consumers think about us as an Internet service across all of our devices.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Melinda Davies of Susquehannah Financial Group. A question about the new distribution deal with Warner Bros. Now that you have Blind Side, for example, do you have enough to fulfill demand for DVDs, our demand sense for Blind Side 28
componenttext: Next question is from Melinda Davies of Susquehannah Financial Group. A question about the new distribution deal with Warner Bros. Now that you have Blind Side, for example, do you have enough to fulfill demand for DVDs, our demand sense for Blind Side 28 days after the DVD release similar to what you've been seeing for new releases of this type in the past? We are trying to understand if there is "pent-up demand" from Netflix subscribers, or are Netflix subscribers shifting to pay-per-view and/or buying DVDs for the new releases and using Netflix for other content like older movies, TV shows, et cetera.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Melinda, there's a little bit of both, as you would expect. There are people who, because of the 28-day, are turned to buying the DVDs, first because it's widely promoted at Wal-Mart and other places. There are some that take pay-per-view because Warner B
componenttext: Melinda, there's a little bit of both, as you would expect. There are people who, because of the 28-day, are turned to buying the DVDs, first because it's widely promoted at Wal-Mart and other places. There are some that take pay-per-view because Warner Bros. is aggressive on the pay-per-view licensing, and that's really the intent of the deal. In terms of the backlog, once it comes to the 28-day, we try to target to have enough DVDs to clear that backlog pretty quickly. There's a little bit of guesswork based on that, but we're still learning together with Warner Bros. on how to predict that, but that's the goal and intent.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. The next question is from Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Why is Netflix committed to staying out of the $40 billion-plus transaction-based pay-per-view market if we include DVD rental and sales? Why wouldn't content owners want me to sell new re
componenttext: Great. The next question is from Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Why is Netflix committed to staying out of the $40 billion-plus transaction-based pay-per-view market if we include DVD rental and sales? Why wouldn't content owners want me to sell new releases with the Netflix's strong brand and digital distribution channel if there will be multiple digital storefronts going forward?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's an interesting question. I would say at times content owners have wanted us to do that. I would say we don't see how we add much value in that. That is, when we buy DVDs, we buy them from Wal-Mart -- as consumers, from Wal-Mart or Amazon beca
componenttext: Well, that's an interesting question. I would say at times content owners have wanted us to do that. I would say we don't see how we add much value in that. That is, when we buy DVDs, we buy them from Wal-Mart -- as consumers, from Wal-Mart or Amazon because they do a great job at it. That's what their main focus is. And our focus is on subscription and, its hard and it takes us a lot of work. So that's probably the main reason we don't do the, for example, selling DVDs. In terms of pay-per-view, then it's a very specific thing, which is, for example, Xbox has, and has had for years, a big pay-per-view business and if we had also had pay-per-view as part of our service, it would have been a lot harder to get distribution on the Xbox, similarly with PS3. And then, of course, you've seen now with Wal-Mart entering the pay-per-view market online with voodoo that many of those firms want to go after that business. And so it's really much smarter for us, we think, to be out of that, not in a position of conflict and just to be focused on our subscription business.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Edward Williams at BMO Capital Markets. In terms of the iPad app, how does it affect your view of the mobile market for Watch Instantly?
componenttext: The next question is from Edward Williams at BMO Capital Markets. In terms of the iPad app, how does it affect your view of the mobile market for Watch Instantly?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it doesn't change it, Edward. As I said a few minutes ago, we look at mobile for video viewing as a nice extra because it's pretty easy as opposed to fundamental. And the really TV-based and laptop-based screen, sort of a primary screen, is what w
componenttext: I think it doesn't change it, Edward. As I said a few minutes ago, we look at mobile for video viewing as a nice extra because it's pretty easy as opposed to fundamental. And the really TV-based and laptop-based screen, sort of a primary screen, is what we're focused on.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His second question, how much of your share buyback program is left? And on top of that, another modeling question, what should we assume for a tax rate in 2010?
componenttext: His second question, how much of your share buyback program is left? And on top of that, another modeling question, what should we assume for a tax rate in 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, with respect to the second part of the answer, probably 41% for the tax rate. And we upped levels, at least in response to the question on the buyback program. You should imagine that as we -- if we exhaust the current buyback authorization that the
componenttext: Well, with respect to the second part of the answer, probably 41% for the tax rate. And we upped levels, at least in response to the question on the buyback program. You should imagine that as we -- if we exhaust the current buyback authorization that therell be additional authorizations, and you should expect that to continue to be active in repurchasing the stock.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer & Co. As you begin to acquire content for international streaming, would you expect the subscriber economics to be different from the U.S. business, and how could this impact margin?
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer & Co. As you begin to acquire content for international streaming, would you expect the subscriber economics to be different from the U.S. business, and how could this impact margin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, we'll be able to talk more about international at the end of the year. In our guidance is built in the modest expenditures we have planned for this year.
componenttext: Jason, we'll be able to talk more about international at the end of the year. In our guidance is built in the modest expenditures we have planned for this year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: A question from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Is the increase in stock-based compensation that we saw in Q1 a level that will be sustained throughout the year?
componenttext: A question from Steven Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Is the increase in stock-based compensation that we saw in Q1 a level that will be sustained throughout the year?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Probably so, yes, a modulo on new employee hiring during the year and the thing that should give you comfort that's likely to be true is that it was relatively flat plus or minus a couple hundred thousand dollars last year and the year before that. So the
componenttext: Probably so, yes, a modulo on new employee hiring during the year and the thing that should give you comfort that's likely to be true is that it was relatively flat plus or minus a couple hundred thousand dollars last year and the year before that. So the big drivers of incremental expense would be increased volatility, both implied and actual, and employee growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And we're on a calendar-year review cycle. So generally, it'll be stable during the year and then on the shift over the calendar-year boundary.
componenttext: And we're on a calendar-year review cycle. So generally, it'll be stable during the year and then on the shift over the calendar-year boundary.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next set of questions are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. With regards to gross margin, the recent sheet [ph] coupons you sent out offering 10% off the next monthly bill to users to install Watch Instantly on their Wii lead us to believe that str
componenttext: The next set of questions are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. With regards to gross margin, the recent sheet [ph] coupons you sent out offering 10% off the next monthly bill to users to install Watch Instantly on their Wii lead us to believe that streaming users are materially higher margin than non-streaming users given they watch less DVDs. Can you give us any idea of some margin difference between streaming and non-streaming users?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, we're not commenting on gross margin for streamers versus non-streamers. You're right that if there's a shift at a high level -- you're right that all things being equal if there's a shift away from DVD towards streaming, it could be an accelerant
componenttext: Scott, we're not commenting on gross margin for streamers versus non-streamers. You're right that if there's a shift at a high level -- you're right that all things being equal if there's a shift away from DVD towards streaming, it could be an accelerant of gross margin. But you should also remember that we've explicitly said that all things will not be equal and that to the extent that there's more profit in the business, our objective is to reinvest the profit in improving the user experience. So in that way, margins is a managed outcome. And our objective is to take what would have been higher margins, reinvest it in the business in order to drive faster subscriber growth and lower churn and lower SAC and increased competitive modes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then specifically on the Wii test, that was just our ever aggressive product and marketing new testing various things so that the program you refer to is just a test at this point.
componenttext: And then specifically on the Wii test, that was just our ever aggressive product and marketing new testing various things so that the program you refer to is just a test at this point.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Scott Devitt. With Redbox considering a streaming service at a lower price point than your $8.99 per month subscription, are you revisiting the idea of offering a streaming-only subscription plan at a lower price point?
componenttext: Second question from Scott Devitt. With Redbox considering a streaming service at a lower price point than your $8.99 per month subscription, are you revisiting the idea of offering a streaming-only subscription plan at a lower price point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No, Scott. Redbox does many things incredibly well, but we're not worried about them particularly as a streaming competitor. So anything they do with streaming doesn't affect how we think about that space.
componenttext: No, Scott. Redbox does many things incredibly well, but we're not worried about them particularly as a streaming competitor. So anything they do with streaming doesn't affect how we think about that space.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, given the ever-expanding number of Netflix-enabled devices, have you seen or do you expect to see consumers trading up to higher-price subscription plans in order to watch multiple videos simultaneously, either multiple people in different ro
componenttext: And finally, given the ever-expanding number of Netflix-enabled devices, have you seen or do you expect to see consumers trading up to higher-price subscription plans in order to watch multiple videos simultaneously, either multiple people in different rooms in the house, mobile users watching while others at home are as well, or to have Netflix enabled on greater than six devices?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: In the next year or two, we don't anticipate much of that. It's pretty much a one-account-per-family model in the near term.
componenttext: In the next year or two, we don't anticipate much of that. It's pretty much a one-account-per-family model in the near term.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next questions are from Andy Hargreaves at Pacific Crest Securities. To your knowledge, are cable satellite subscribers who cancel citing your service in increasing numbers? If so, could that impact your ability to gain access to TV content?
componenttext: Next questions are from Andy Hargreaves at Pacific Crest Securities. To your knowledge, are cable satellite subscribers who cancel citing your service in increasing numbers? If so, could that impact your ability to gain access to TV content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Andy, there's been a bunch of stories about so-called cord cutting, but we haven't seen a lot of it. Netflix has a subset of the content available on a typical MSO system, but were seeing no historics. So it's not much of a substitute for the packages
componenttext: Andy, there's been a bunch of stories about so-called cord cutting, but we haven't seen a lot of it. Netflix has a subset of the content available on a typical MSO system, but were seeing no historics. So it's not much of a substitute for the packages that MSOs offer.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: He had a second question with regards to G&A. What drove the increase in the quarter and should G&A stay around the Q1 level through 2010?
componenttext: He had a second question with regards to G&A. What drove the increase in the quarter and should G&A stay around the Q1 level through 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Two contributing factors primarily. On the comp side, the CEO swapped a very large percentage of his comp this year versus last year into options and that has a higher rate of expense. So he's doubling down his investment in the business in that way. That
componenttext: Two contributing factors primarily. On the comp side, the CEO swapped a very large percentage of his comp this year versus last year into options and that has a higher rate of expense. So he's doubling down his investment in the business in that way. Thats encouraging. And then secondly, as the brand has grown, the Plaintiffs Bar has become more active, and legal expenses, as a consequence, are up on a year-over-year and Q-over-Q basis.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next set of questions are from Barton Crockett at Lazard. The first is a long-term content question. As Netflix subscriber base grows and seemingly gets closer and closer to total subscribers for premium pay-TV network, like HBO, Showtime and Starz, d
componenttext: The next set of questions are from Barton Crockett at Lazard. The first is a long-term content question. As Netflix subscriber base grows and seemingly gets closer and closer to total subscribers for premium pay-TV network, like HBO, Showtime and Starz, does the company ever need to think about borrowing a page from their strategy and investing in unique original content? Over the long term, it seems that for a video network to remain relevant to consumers and ward off competition, it needs unique content. Otherwise, the checkbook becomes the main barrier to entry, which is not sustainable. Do you agree or disagree with that thought?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Barton, its a good, deep analysis, but I would disagree. And your premise is that video services such as HBO and Starz need original content to differentiate, and I'm not in disagreement with that part. But what Netflix has to differentiate is the user
componenttext: Barton, its a good, deep analysis, but I would disagree. And your premise is that video services such as HBO and Starz need original content to differentiate, and I'm not in disagreement with that part. But what Netflix has to differentiate is the user-interface personalization on-demand aspect of the Internet and lap [ph]. And our view is that we can remain a packager and be significantly differentiated from other services because our value add is not just the content, it's all of the recommendations, how people interact with them, helping them match with content they're going to end up loving. So our view is we won't ever need to go into original series. I would certainly say if we ever did, we probably have the wrong CEO, and we shouldn't be based in Silicon Valley, and there's a number of other things that make that an unpromising avenue. So instead, what we're focused on is can we license the content as we have with Starz. We have some content from Showtime, not yet anything from FX or HBO. And as those firms look at us, they can look at us two ways. One is, geez, were another packager of movies and a potential competitor, or they can look at it as we're a natural distributor for their original series. And when you see the enormous success that Starz is having with Spartacus, that Showtime has had with Weeds, Californication and others and, of course, HBO has for many years, you can see that those services are differentially good at the original series. And so we'll be hopeful these alliances and partnerships will view us as a great distributor writing them big checks for their original content. We focus on packaging and they focus on the original series.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is related to gross margin on the 28-day window. Did the new 28-day window deal with Warner Bros. have a meaningful impact on Q1 gross margin? Can you discuss whether it helped or hurt gross margins and the materiality of the impact? How
componenttext: The next question is related to gross margin on the 28-day window. Did the new 28-day window deal with Warner Bros. have a meaningful impact on Q1 gross margin? Can you discuss whether it helped or hurt gross margins and the materiality of the impact? How do you see the 28-day window deal with Warner Bros. and other studios affecting gross margin for the balance of the year?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll let Barry talk about the gross margin as a whole, but you remember that what we're doing is saving money on DVD and then putting it into streaming.  Okay, so if you ask the question, are we saving money on DVD, the answer is yes. As for saving money
componenttext: I'll let Barry talk about the gross margin as a whole, but you remember that what we're doing is saving money on DVD and then putting it into streaming.  Okay, so if you ask the question, are we saving money on DVD, the answer is yes. As for saving money on content, the answer is no, because we're making a choice to put additional money into more streaming content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Which is a perfect preamble to remind everyone that gross margin in that way is a managed outcome.
componenttext: Which is a perfect preamble to remind everyone that gross margin in that way is a managed outcome.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The last question from Barton. You say you intend to remain active this year in share repurchases. Your repurchase volume doesn't seem to have been affected much by the meteoric rise in Netflix stock. Are we anywhere near a price of Netflix shares that wo
componenttext: The last question from Barton. You say you intend to remain active this year in share repurchases. Your repurchase volume doesn't seem to have been affected much by the meteoric rise in Netflix stock. Are we anywhere near a price of Netflix shares that would prompt you to scale back your share repurchase volume?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No. To expand on the answer, I would say that if you look at it in the rearview mirror, the stock looks expensive. I can remember when we were charted by the Heard on the Street, the Wall Street Journal back in January and in the middle of last year for r
componenttext: No. To expand on the answer, I would say that if you look at it in the rearview mirror, the stock looks expensive. I can remember when we were charted by the Heard on the Street, the Wall Street Journal back in January and in the middle of last year for repurchasing at record-high prices, which in now retrospect look pretty attractive. So whether you think the stock is expensive or cheap depends entirely on your view of the value of the business. And if you could imagine that Netflix is a winner in a very large market, then probably the target price at which you're willing to acquire the stock is relatively high and if, in the alternative, you think we get trampled or margins get trampled in this space, then you feel perhaps a small price of which you're willing to buy the stock. We have been and continue to have an optimistic view about our likely success in the space, and as a result, we have pretty aggressive targets at  which were willing to buy the stock, and so far, so good.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray. What do you think tax rates are on the tens of millions of devices Netflix is now integrated with? And are mobile-device partnerships incremental for new sub additions or are mobile devices just churn
componenttext: The next question is from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray. What do you think tax rates are on the tens of millions of devices Netflix is now integrated with? And are mobile-device partnerships incremental for new sub additions or are mobile devices just churn reducers for subleasing Watch Instantly through other devices?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, the generous tens of millions that you referred to for devices may be true in the fall as more devices sell and come to market with Netflix included in them, but that's a little aggressive for the current situation. In mobile, I would say not sure i
componenttext: Mike, the generous tens of millions that you referred to for devices may be true in the fall as more devices sell and come to market with Netflix included in them, but that's a little aggressive for the current situation. In mobile, I would say not sure if it's a sign-up vehicle or just one of the many platforms that someone watches. My intuition would be that it's one of the many platforms that someone actions Netflix with and that, that helps. But either way, it's not that much work to put a client together for a mobile device and it makes sense for us to do.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Dan Ernst at Hudson Square. With regards to the Netflix iPad app, can you talk about any trend in terms of subscriber viewing that you have seen with the iPad -- or subscribers or viewing?
componenttext: The next question is from Dan Ernst at Hudson Square. With regards to the Netflix iPad app, can you talk about any trend in terms of subscriber viewing that you have seen with the iPad -- or subscribers or viewing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, I can say the wonderful thing about the Apple ecosystem is that it gets so much press and attention, and so it brings a lot of press and attention to the company, obviously to this call, in excess of its short-term contribution to viewing  or subscri
componenttext: Dan, I can say the wonderful thing about the Apple ecosystem is that it gets so much press and attention, and so it brings a lot of press and attention to the company, obviously to this call, in excess of its short-term contribution to viewing  or subscribers. Now in the long term, the iPad is a very exciting device that has a great potential. But in the short term, in comparison to the nearly 30 million households that have a Wii, it's not a major contributor.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next two questions are from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. What are the most popular content categories on the streaming service?
componenttext: The next two questions are from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. What are the most popular content categories on the streaming service?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The beautiful thing about Netflix is that it's adaptive to the individual taste. So if a subscriber really likes comedy, it'll start featuring lots of comedy. If a subscriber likes drama, TV shows, horror, it adapts to their taste. And that's our fundamen
componenttext: The beautiful thing about Netflix is that it's adaptive to the individual taste. So if a subscriber really likes comedy, it'll start featuring lots of comedy. If a subscriber likes drama, TV shows, horror, it adapts to their taste. And that's our fundamental focus, which is learning the taste of each of our members and presenting them an experience that makes them feel how Netflix has all the stuff that I really want to watch. So we really don't focus on programming for categories or types. It's really a broad set of content and then real focuses on learning and adapting in the user interface for the particular taste.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question from Brian at UBS, regarding Netflix relationship with TiVo and their new premiere set-top box, this box will be deployed as the set-top box for RCN users. Will Netflix have to remove Starz contents for their users so not to conflict wit
componenttext: The next question from Brian at UBS, regarding Netflix relationship with TiVo and their new premiere set-top box, this box will be deployed as the set-top box for RCN users. Will Netflix have to remove Starz contents for their users so not to conflict with RCN's offering?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: To tell you the truth, I didn't know about the TiVo RCN deal, so I'm not sure. I haven't heard anything to that and I think I probably wouldve if there was such a conflict. So I imagine there isnt one.
componenttext: To tell you the truth, I didn't know about the TiVo RCN deal, so I'm not sure. I haven't heard anything to that and I think I probably wouldve if there was such a conflict. So I imagine there isnt one.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Nat Schindler of BofA. Your spend on the DVD library of just $37 million is down 21% year-over-year and 35% year-over-year  oh, hes got year-over-year, one of them must be Q-over-Q -- despite the steep rise in subscribers. Is t
componenttext: Next question is from Nat Schindler of BofA. Your spend on the DVD library of just $37 million is down 21% year-over-year and 35% year-over-year  oh, hes got year-over-year, one of them must be Q-over-Q -- despite the steep rise in subscribers. Is this decline driven by their recent better library management and back catalog marketing, Time Warner contract users substituting streaming content for DVDs or simply a lack of big Hollywood hits in Q1 to buy?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say none of the above. It reflects the shift in purchasing to rev share and the way Ive shared it is expensed in the P&L. And if you dont see it, it flowed through the statement of cash flows, like CapEx for content purchasing on DVD spends.
componenttext: I would say none of the above. It reflects the shift in purchasing to rev share and the way Ive shared it is expensed in the P&L. And if you dont see it, it flowed through the statement of cash flows, like CapEx for content purchasing on DVD spends.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Imran Khan of JPMorgan. Could you please give us some color on your churn rate for customers who are using streaming predominantly?
componenttext: The next question is from Imran Khan of JPMorgan. Could you please give us some color on your churn rate for customers who are using streaming predominantly?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We're not going to break out the individual churn rates for different sectors. I would say on overall, we're very happy with where current is trending, and you're seeing churn coming down and streaming rising, so that's a good thing.
componenttext: We're not going to break out the individual churn rates for different sectors. I would say on overall, we're very happy with where current is trending, and you're seeing churn coming down and streaming rising, so that's a good thing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry, just to amplify comments I made on last quarter's call and in my commentary on the website. I attributed the record-low churn to the pockets of growth in streaming and I made similar comments last quarter, and so you should infer that the subscribe
componenttext: Sorry, just to amplify comments I made on last quarter's call and in my commentary on the website. I attributed the record-low churn to the pockets of growth in streaming and I made similar comments last quarter, and so you should infer that the subscribers who are engaged in streaming are incrementally happy and staying longer.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from John Blackledge of CS [Credit Suisse]. Would you expect to raise additional debt in 2010?
componenttext: The next question is from John Blackledge of CS [Credit Suisse]. Would you expect to raise additional debt in 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Not likely, although we could. I think we've had something like 0.74 turns of debt on the business, but we have no immediate plans.
componenttext: Not likely, although we could. I think we've had something like 0.74 turns of debt on the business, but we have no immediate plans.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Richard Skaggs at Loomis Sayles. Share repurchase was substantial in the quarter, increasing balance sheet leverage on the surface. What do you see as an optimal debt-to-capital ratio given the predictability of cash flows and ot
componenttext: The next question is from Richard Skaggs at Loomis Sayles. Share repurchase was substantial in the quarter, increasing balance sheet leverage on the surface. What do you see as an optimal debt-to-capital ratio given the predictability of cash flows and other investment opportunities?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Still choosing that out and not prepared to talk about it publicly. I believe we could very comfortably support 1.5 turns of debt on the business. Were currently at less than 0.821. But I would want the capital structure to be conservative enough so th
componenttext: Still choosing that out and not prepared to talk about it publicly. I believe we could very comfortably support 1.5 turns of debt on the business. Were currently at less than 0.821. But I would want the capital structure to be conservative enough so that the company, if we were ever challenged competitively, would never be constrained on the operating decisions we've made to confront competition. I wouldn't want that leverage to get in the way of any decisions we might want to make in the future. On the other hand, the business is growing rapidly, the competitive moats seem well established, and we're very optimistic about their future. So we might want to put some calls in the context of our interest in using proceeds from additional debt financing to repurchased shares.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And really, the bigger driver than how much leverage is just that we're clearly not in a mode of trying to build our cash up to -- if we had not done any buyback over the last three years, wed have $1 billion on the balance sheet. And that sounds good,
componenttext: And really, the bigger driver than how much leverage is just that we're clearly not in a mode of trying to build our cash up to -- if we had not done any buyback over the last three years, wed have $1 billion on the balance sheet. And that sounds good, its a nice press headline, but we're really happy with the decisions that we've made to keep cash pretty steady, and to return that money to shareholders. So that part we have been willing to talk about.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies. Can you explain the reasons for moving to Amazon's AWS? Can you quantify potential savings?
componenttext: The next question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies. Can you explain the reasons for moving to Amazon's AWS? Can you quantify potential savings?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, I'm not sure on the savings. Architecturally, we're big believers in the public Cloud for any company that doesn't have Google or Facebook's scale. We basically -- as you know, you get to take advantage of their vast resources. So we think itl
componenttext: Youssef, I'm not sure on the savings. Architecturally, we're big believers in the public Cloud for any company that doesn't have Google or Facebook's scale. We basically -- as you know, you get to take advantage of their vast resources. So we think itll help us with costs, itll help with reliability. Its obviously early in the public Cloud movement. We'll see a lot of new companies enter that space and the vigorous competition will help draw the prices down, which should benefit for us if we're architected for the public Cloud.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Generally, its made us more nimble, our ability to encode the library for new platform launches in short periods of time.
componenttext: Generally, its made us more nimble, our ability to encode the library for new platform launches in short periods of time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That's right. Barrys got a good anecdote in that one. We moved our encoding facility out of our internal data center into Amazon about six months ago. And when we got the sudden ability to do the Apple iPad and we had to do a very large encoding job, w
componenttext: That's right. Barrys got a good anecdote in that one. We moved our encoding facility out of our internal data center into Amazon about six months ago. And when we got the sudden ability to do the Apple iPad and we had to do a very large encoding job, we would never have been able to  it would've taken six months in our prior internal data center. But because of the elasticity of the public Cloud, we were able to spin up thousands and thousands of encoding codes and do it in parallel. So youre right, Barry, we've already seen good progress from that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mario Cibelli at Marathon Partners. Will Netflix still deliver its last DVD in 2030?
componenttext: The next question is from Mario Cibelli at Marathon Partners. Will Netflix still deliver its last DVD in 2030?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mario, I will personally deliver that last DVD in 2030. And yes, that's still our best guess on when we look at the DVD market. Our DVD shipments are continuing to climb throughout the country, even in the Bay Area where you see this astounding up of 24%
componenttext: Mario, I will personally deliver that last DVD in 2030. And yes, that's still our best guess on when we look at the DVD market. Our DVD shipments are continuing to climb throughout the country, even in the Bay Area where you see this astounding up of 24% of Bay Area households subscribing to Netflix. And our DVD shipments, DVD and Blu-Ray combined, are continuing to grow. So DVD has got a lot of legs here and 2030 is still the target.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Last couple of questions, and they are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Now that Netflix is available on the iPad and is expected on the iPhone, what is the likelihood that the Netflix app lands on Apple TV someday?
componenttext: Last couple of questions, and they are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Now that Netflix is available on the iPad and is expected on the iPhone, what is the likelihood that the Netflix app lands on Apple TV someday?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You know, Apple declared themselves about two months ago to be a mobile company, theyre focused on mobile, mobile, mobile, so I'm not sure how much going forward that they're going to spend on Apple TV. If they decide to invest in it, it's something th
componenttext: You know, Apple declared themselves about two months ago to be a mobile company, theyre focused on mobile, mobile, mobile, so I'm not sure how much going forward that they're going to spend on Apple TV. If they decide to invest in it, it's something that would make sense for us. But at this point, it's not their focus. Their focus is on mobile, and well work with them on all of those mobile platforms as we have been.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, given the increased focused on mobile devices and the incremental engineering costs associated with developing products for these platforms, do you see any opportunity to monetize this customer base differently? For example, offering a higher
componenttext: And finally, given the increased focused on mobile devices and the incremental engineering costs associated with developing products for these platforms, do you see any opportunity to monetize this customer base differently? For example, offering a higher-priced plan that includes mobile access similar to Blu-Ray?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No. On the web, the basic model is that youre a web-based or Internet-based service available on devices that have web browsers and speak Internet. So that's the basic paradigm as opposed to , well, it's one price on this type of PC, another price on a
componenttext: No. On the web, the basic model is that youre a web-based or Internet-based service available on devices that have web browsers and speak Internet. So that's the basic paradigm as opposed to , well, it's one price on this type of PC, another price on a  different machine. And we're very much a web-centric, Internet-video firm in that way and because of that, we tend not to think about things like extra charges for certain modalities of access. We do think about charges for HD, or we think about more content, but that's across all of the devices that are simply, to us, Internet-access devices.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Operator, that's the last question I have. Before we conclude the call, I would like to turn the call back over to Reed Hastings for some closing remarks.
componenttext: Great. Operator, that's the last question I have. Before we conclude the call, I would like to turn the call back over to Reed Hastings for some closing remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Deborah, and thanks all of you for joining us on the call. Q1 was another great quarter. And as you can see from our guidance, we're well positioned for continued growth and I look forward to reporting to you on our progress on next quarter's call
componenttext: Thanks, Deborah, and thanks all of you for joining us on the call. Q1 was another great quarter. And as you can see from our guidance, we're well positioned for continued growth and I look forward to reporting to you on our progress on next quarter's call.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: This does conclude your program. Thank you for your participation, and have a wonderful day. You may disconnect your lines at this time.
componenttext: This does conclude your program. Thank you for your participation, and have a wonderful day. You may disconnect your lines at this time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good everyone and welcome to Netflix second quarter 2010 earnings Q&A session. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Erin Kasenchak, Director of Investor Relation. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good everyone and welcome to Netflix second quarter 2010 earnings Q&A session. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Erin Kasenchak, Director of Investor Relation. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix second quarter 2010, earnings Q&A session. We released earnings for the second quarter at approximately 1.05 PM Pacific Time today. Earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's resul
componenttext:
Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix second quarter 2010, earnings Q&A session. We released earnings for the second quarter at approximately 1.05 PM Pacific Time today. Earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's results and the webcast of this Q&A are available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. 
Like last quarter, this call consists solely of Q&A and we are going to conduct the Q&A via email. Please email your questions to ir@netflix.com. We may make forward looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. 
A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our Annual Report on Form 10-K filed with the commission on February 22nd, 2010. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6.00 PM Pacific Time today. Before moving into Q&A, I would like to turn the call over to Reed for a few opening remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome everyone and let's just jump in with question Erin.
componenttext: Welcome everyone and let's just jump in with question Erin.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, first question is from Steve Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Will the recent content deal with Relativity Media signal a material increase in the overall content expenditures or a continuation of the trend of shifting investment from physical to di
componenttext: Great, first question is from Steve Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Will the recent content deal with Relativity Media signal a material increase in the overall content expenditures or a continuation of the trend of shifting investment from physical to digital?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Even it's a little above, we have been investing more in streaming content, quarter-after-quarter, year-after-year as we had revenue growth and confirmation that the streaming content and investment is a smart one. And Relativity does indicate a material
componenttext: Even it's a little above, we have been investing more in streaming content, quarter-after-quarter, year-after-year as we had revenue growth and confirmation that the streaming content and investment is a smart one. And Relativity does indicate a material step up in that, most of that doesn't come in until Relativity of others to films so that would be next year and beyond. So it's a material step up this year after Relativity, but we are out-looking for more content and the need to Relativity is that its completely exclusive for internet subscription to Netflix, so it's the first essentially a shift in our strategy which is due also a likely thing exclusive content in addition to non-exclusive content. We don't see a big radical shift. It's as if they were doing some of the content on movies and TV shows exclusive now which as you know is open to new parts of content of the availability because much of the content in the pay-TV window is sold exclusively.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And second question is what is the percentage of subscribers on Blu-ray plan?
componenttext: And second question is what is the percentage of subscribers on Blu-ray plan?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve it's a little over 10%.
componenttext: Steve it's a little over 10%.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, next question from Dave Miller of Caris & Company. Can you confirm whether or not the introduction of the iPad app has resulted in additional subs on your expectation or whether the netbooks app has pre-resulted in already existing sub acquiring iP
componenttext: Great, next question from Dave Miller of Caris & Company. Can you confirm whether or not the introduction of the iPad app has resulted in additional subs on your expectation or whether the netbooks app has pre-resulted in already existing sub acquiring iPad?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well Dave, every new platform whether that's the Wii, the iPad, all of the platforms, do both. They help us with existing subscribers getting more value from the netbook service and they help us attract new subscribers and the iPad is as big successful as
