componenttext: Well Dave, every new platform whether that's the Wii, the iPad, all of the platforms, do both. They help us with existing subscribers getting more value from the netbook service and they help us attract new subscribers and the iPad is as big successful as the Wii was and as really all of our platforms have been.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Youssef Squali at Jeffries & Company. How is the rate of activations on the Wii versus what you have seen for the Xbox in the first 90 days?
componenttext: Next question from Youssef Squali at Jeffries & Company. How is the rate of activations on the Wii versus what you have seen for the Xbox in the first 90 days?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, we don't break out platforms specifics. But I would say that we were very happy with Xbox when it came out and we've been very happy with the PS3 and now we're very happy with Wii. They all have large install bases and that's a meaningful way for
componenttext: Youssef, we don't break out platforms specifics. But I would say that we were very happy with Xbox when it came out and we've been very happy with the PS3 and now we're very happy with Wii. They all have large install bases and that's a meaningful way for our subscribers to get value from our service, and watch great movies and TV shows.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question, is there a subscriber segment? Is there a sub-segment of subscribers who only stream the service and stop ordering DVDs? If so, can you quantify?
componenttext: The second question, is there a subscriber segment? Is there a sub-segment of subscribers who only stream the service and stop ordering DVDs? If so, can you quantify?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The majority of subscribers do both stream and take DVDs.
componenttext: The majority of subscribers do both stream and take DVDs.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. Are marketing expenses associated with the Canadian expansion already factored into your operating margin guidance for 2010?
componenttext: Next question from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. Are marketing expenses associated with the Canadian expansion already factored into your operating margin guidance for 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is.
componenttext: Yes, it is.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And what percentage of your CDM partners will support Canadian subscribers?
componenttext: And what percentage of your CDM partners will support Canadian subscribers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Assuming that you meant CDM, in which case there is no real issue of the internet, our providers such as Akamai and Limelight and others that's out in Canada.
componenttext: Assuming that you meant CDM, in which case there is no real issue of the internet, our providers such as Akamai and Limelight and others that's out in Canada.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great next question's from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. As Netflix gears up to enter the Canadian market and for similarly other foreign markets, what is the most significant content delivery challenge facing the company? Do you expect higher content
componenttext: Great next question's from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. As Netflix gears up to enter the Canadian market and for similarly other foreign markets, what is the most significant content delivery challenge facing the company? Do you expect higher content delivery unit costs than you have in the US?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: If by delivery one means the cost of streaming, that's a fairly small part of the total picture. So, I would say in Canada the challenges are licensing the right content, the right cost and then taking advantage of the right marketing channels at the righ
componenttext: If by delivery one means the cost of streaming, that's a fairly small part of the total picture. So, I would say in Canada the challenges are licensing the right content, the right cost and then taking advantage of the right marketing channels at the right cost. Those are the two primary drivers, the content in the market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Dan Ernst at Hudson Square. Questions on accessing rights for digital content for instant watch. So the size of your subscriber base relative to large cable and satellite carriers factor at all into your ability to gain such rights. And
componenttext: Next question from Dan Ernst at Hudson Square. Questions on accessing rights for digital content for instant watch. So the size of your subscriber base relative to large cable and satellite carriers factor at all into your ability to gain such rights. And if you looked at your top 500 titles across the year, what percentages of those are now available for instant watch?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our relative size is into direct impact, Dan. It's more the absolute size of our checks. So, if the biggest check we can write for a piece of content is $10,000, you know it's a long shot to get it. If the biggest is $20 million for some piece of content,
componenttext:
Our relative size is into direct impact, Dan. It's more the absolute size of our checks. So, if the biggest check we can write for a piece of content is $10,000, you know it's a long shot to get it. If the biggest is $20 million for some piece of content, we're pretty likely to be out there with anybody else. So, it's as you would expect in that way. So there is an indirect influence around our revenue or our content spending budget, larger that it is to more effective we can be. 
And then you ask about the top 500, I'm not sure how to answer that exactly. But I would say that the power of Netflix is to take a lot of content, it may not be the hottest content and make it feel like it's an incredible service to subscribers. That's where we add value as a service and that one is nearly carrying the hottest content on the planet. There is not as much of a profit opportunity in that, because you got to pay the content owner. Well the content owner has earned most of the value generated as you extract that. So our key is not around top 500, our key is direct, and what percent of our subscribers are streaming. We keep them actively streaming because if they are actively streaming and taking DVDs, then they will be paying better and you can see that in the year-over-year improvements in the tension that we have generated.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question is related to churn. Churn, my second are of interest is on churn. What are the top two areas a customer goes to instead of Netflix when they leave also are the customers you have added over the last year, what percentage of those have
componenttext: The second question is related to churn. Churn, my second are of interest is on churn. What are the top two areas a customer goes to instead of Netflix when they leave also are the customers you have added over the last year, what percentage of those have been Netflix customers previously?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's usually around the third, and plus you're paying five points. And on the first part of the question, what's that Erin?
componenttext: It's usually around the third, and plus you're paying five points. And on the first part of the question, what's that Erin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: What are the top two places that people go when they churn?
componenttext: What are the top two places that people go when they churn?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You know when we ask them, it's a little bit of choppy exactly because you ask about movies, where did you get movies from? This is going to be different answer than where you get TV shows from. But when you ask where we get movies from, consumers say tha
componenttext: You know when we ask them, it's a little bit of choppy exactly because you ask about movies, where did you get movies from? This is going to be different answer than where you get TV shows from. But when you ask where we get movies from, consumers say that kiosk, the $1 rental. That's the big one and is still rising. Almost everything else is in the noise.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Next question from Jeff Rath at Canaccord. Free subscribers as a percentage of paying subscribers have reached the highest level ever for Netflix, what's causing this and how should we expect just the trend for the remainder of 2010?
componenttext: Great. Next question from Jeff Rath at Canaccord. Free subscribers as a percentage of paying subscribers have reached the highest level ever for Netflix, what's causing this and how should we expect just the trend for the remainder of 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: There is kind a huge difference. In general, that's a reflection of our growth rates. So our growth rates astoundingly have been moving up all year long and we expect them to continue to grow and a higher growth rate will be associated with a higher rate
componenttext:
There is kind a huge difference. In general, that's a reflection of our growth rates. So our growth rates astoundingly have been moving up all year long and we expect them to continue to grow and a higher growth rate will be associated with a higher rate or free trials at any point in time.
That's pretty much, it. Seasonality contributes end results slightly to the number of revenue months generated in a quarter which bears on the likes of free and paid. And Q2 tends to be slightly backend loaded. Q3 is pretty much flat along through the quarter. Q4 is backend loaded. But we described the predominant influence, which is sub-growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Next question from Nat Schindler. BofA-Merrill. Dramatic increase in subscriber guidance, up 1.2 million on top and bottom end of guidance for year end, coupled with limited increase in revenue guidance which absolutely in our view are coming down
componenttext: Great. Next question from Nat Schindler. BofA-Merrill. Dramatic increase in subscriber guidance, up 1.2 million on top and bottom end of guidance for year end, coupled with limited increase in revenue guidance which absolutely in our view are coming down much faster than it did before, what has changed?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say not so much. The only thing that's changed in the business and it's quite a significant change is the accelerated growth and we attribute that to streaming, and streaming implies for 1-out unlimited price point. So I said on Q3 call a year ago
componenttext: I would say not so much. The only thing that's changed in the business and it's quite a significant change is the accelerated growth and we attribute that to streaming, and streaming implies for 1-out unlimited price point. So I said on Q3 call a year ago that if prices decline rapidly towards that 1-out unlimited plan, we'll be very excited. That's great news for the business because it means that streaming is resonating with consumers and likely we will see accelerating growth. And in fact we are seeing accelerated growth. So if you're doing year-over-year comp, it helps to remember that we initiated in part of Blu-ray price increase in Q2 a year ago for two months of the quarter and then three months of the quarter in Q3, and so that dampens the fact of the shift towards 1-out plan. But tax in that effect we're tracking year-over-year say Q3, Q4, I think will be on par, one to another.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And now we do expect streaming continues to be successful. It has been for us, that our $8.99 one-year plan will be a larger and larger percentage both the sign ups and therefore the installed base. We're not seeing any material migration of the installed
componenttext: And now we do expect streaming continues to be successful. It has been for us, that our $8.99 one-year plan will be a larger and larger percentage both the sign ups and therefore the installed base. We're not seeing any material migration of the installed base. That has stayed pretty constant. When people come in on a certain plan they stay with it. I have said that new subscribers are predominately coming in on the unlimited streaming one DVD at a time plan.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to remind everyone that I think the pure indicator of the growth potential of the business is subscriber growth. We've had lots of discussion about ASP overtime and it's declined, and because of that discussion we added a metric which was gross pro
componenttext: I want to remind everyone that I think the pure indicator of the growth potential of the business is subscriber growth. We've had lots of discussion about ASP overtime and it's declined, and because of that discussion we added a metric which was gross profit per paying sub. So on a year-over-year basis, we actually saw an increase of about $0.30 in that metric. So even though ASP is going down and revenues are growing slower than subscribers are growing in terms of gross profit dollar, we are adding more prudent sub in Q2 of this year than we did a year ago.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question. I think visibility into Q4 subscriber growth or in other words how do you get comfortable without quarter guidance?
componenttext: The second question. I think visibility into Q4 subscriber growth or in other words how do you get comfortable without quarter guidance?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We have lots of confidence about next week's outcome, declining less ability to be accurate next month and as we point out declining less ability the following quarter. It's really a continuum. The trend lines that are propelling Netflix' acceleration hav
componenttext: We have lots of confidence about next week's outcome, declining less ability to be accurate next month and as we point out declining less ability the following quarter. It's really a continuum. The trend lines that are propelling Netflix' acceleration have been a very steady, strong acceleration since the beginning of the year at least and that's what gives us confidence that it's not one short term aspect. And while we're not able to, we are choosing not to predict continued acceleration of growth in Q4, that is our model, our expectation and guidance is that growth will remain at a very strong 48%, 49% subscriber growth in Q4. Its because of the continuity and steadiness of our acceleration to date as opposed to say we are banking on CPM rates or some specific aspect of Q4.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Can you update us on our three to five year outlook for operating margins?
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Can you update us on our three to five year outlook for operating margins?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason my update that implies that we said something about that in the past, except I don't believe we have. In general we would hold the domestic business. We would want that to steadily improve, probably at a fairly modest rate, because the top line is e
componenttext: Jason my update that implies that we said something about that in the past, except I don't believe we have. In general we would hold the domestic business. We would want that to steadily improve, probably at a fairly modest rate, because the top line is expanding so dramatically. The global operating margin would depend upon international and at what rate it was prudent to invest.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, next question from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given that the three largest devices' install bases, Xbox, PS3 and Wii have already launched, how should we think about the subscriber contribution from the initial launches versus follow-on contri
componenttext: Great, next question from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given that the three largest devices' install bases, Xbox, PS3 and Wii have already launched, how should we think about the subscriber contribution from the initial launches versus follow-on contribution from the existing installed base versus incremental growth in the console install base?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott we've been very happy that the Xbox which is our longest standing device relationship, we continue to see substantial growth in the number of Xbox users and Xbox activations for Netflix and that's partially because they're continuing to sell more, n
componenttext: Scott we've been very happy that the Xbox which is our longest standing device relationship, we continue to see substantial growth in the number of Xbox users and Xbox activations for Netflix and that's partially because they're continuing to sell more, new devices in to the market at a considerable rate. And it's partially because we are marketing our service to people who include current Xbox owners. So, both install bases, Netflix and Xbox are growing. And from that we're seeing continued growth. So, we look at it and we think that we will continue to generate substantial growth from all three of the gate platforms, because all three are growing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: While Netflix may have the skill to aggressively acquire streaming content, availability of content appears limited due to the exclusivity agreement between premium TV networks and most major studios. Are there other buckets of content similar to Relativi
componenttext: While Netflix may have the skill to aggressively acquire streaming content, availability of content appears limited due to the exclusivity agreement between premium TV networks and most major studios. Are there other buckets of content similar to Relativity Media that are not tied up in exclusive agreements or is Netflix made to pursue another stars like distribution deal the likes of Epics or Showtime in order to dramatically expand the content library.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Again want to separate that out between TV shows and movies. So in movies there are a small number of makers and as you've said and mentioned a number of exclusive deals and so we are definitely interested in licensing from HBO, from Epics, from Showtime.
componenttext:
Again want to separate that out between TV shows and movies. So in movies there are a small number of makers and as you've said and mentioned a number of exclusive deals and so we are definitely interested in licensing from HBO, from Epics, from Showtime. In addition, there are pockets of content like Relativity, therefore on the movie sides. 
On the TV network side, there is a vast array of content and providers and exclusives are of the type that movies are much less common and there is a lot of incremental ability for us to generate new profits for those networks. Because we focus on the prior season, we try to be particularly careful about not conflicting with cable networks which focus on the newest episode. And we focus on the prior season in generating incremental view better than anyone from that prior season viewing and you will see us continue to expand on that in the coming years.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, our next question is from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. They are changing until now from three months ago in terms of shifting sense from marketing content spending. Seems like you're more definitive about the second half contents spend increase after Q
componenttext: Great, our next question is from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. They are changing until now from three months ago in terms of shifting sense from marketing content spending. Seems like you're more definitive about the second half contents spend increase after Q1 than now.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: There was intended shift in tone Doug. We expect to significantly increase the spending streaming in the second half of the year as compared to the first half of the year and the first half was a big increase over the second half of the prior year. So as
componenttext:
There was intended shift in tone Doug. We expect to significantly increase the spending streaming in the second half of the year as compared to the first half of the year and the first half was a big increase over the second half of the prior year. So as the business scales in terms of subscribers we have, it generates more and more capacity to reallocate spending and so that's our plan. 
You probably are referring to the language in my commentary which said that if we're not successful in licensing additional contents then we will spend that money in marketing and grow this sub-growth and I was kind of inoculate us against creating expectations on the part of investors that in the absence of increased content spending, it would all fall at bottom-line. They didn't want earnings expectations to run away from us. It was another way of reminding folks that earnings is a managed outcome and we consciously every quarter make a choice between how much earnings to deliver on the bottom-line and how much to invest quarterly and glorify them in the form of marketing or making the service better to drive additional (inaudible).

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And Doug I would say that after the same which is about a consistent strategy which is content gets first-ins on the budget and marketing spends, what's left over and content thrives only by efficiently. What they don't want to do is spend inefficiently a
componenttext: And Doug I would say that after the same which is about a consistent strategy which is content gets first-ins on the budget and marketing spends, what's left over and content thrives only by efficiently. What they don't want to do is spend inefficiently and so that combination works well for us in Q2 and works well for us for the rest of the year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great and second question. In deals like Relativity and others, how does the timing of content payments work in terms of cash payment and financial statement recognition? How lumpy are payments here and when was would you start to actively begin talking t
componenttext: Great and second question. In deals like Relativity and others, how does the timing of content payments work in terms of cash payment and financial statement recognition? How lumpy are payments here and when was would you start to actively begin talking to (inaudible) without renewing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the accounting and cash flow part of the question. Of course, we don't make disclosures on a deal-by-deal basis but in general and by way of reminder, if we negotiate a multi-year deal for streamed content and if we are not able to allocate va
componenttext: Let me take the accounting and cash flow part of the question. Of course, we don't make disclosures on a deal-by-deal basis but in general and by way of reminder, if we negotiate a multi-year deal for streamed content and if we are not able to allocate value for the deal's individual titles then when we amortize the cost of the license agreement on a straight line basis over the term. And the cash flow aspects of the deals are uniquely and individual deals and can vary quite a bit. Nothing about any of the deals that we've negotiated and they changes in length significant way. So our cash flow contributes to the business. And what's the second part?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: When might you start discussions about our [renewal]?
componenttext: When might you start discussions about our [renewal]?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On these Hollywood type deals, they are always in discussions that never end, so no particular time does this begin or end.
componenttext: On these Hollywood type deals, they are always in discussions that never end, so no particular time does this begin or end.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, next question from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. The slowdown in growth of DVD shipments are at an inflection point where we could start to see DVD shipment growth flat lined or even start to decline and it really starts to take off or is this more of
componenttext: Great, next question from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. The slowdown in growth of DVD shipments are at an inflection point where we could start to see DVD shipment growth flat lined or even start to decline and it really starts to take off or is this more of a function of limited content acquired during the quarter as DVD shipments continue to grow and/or even accelerate.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well Mark DVD shipments are growing. We don't expect them to flatten this year. Yes, as we said, that growth was less than we thought. So, that would imply the peak would be here earlier that we had the last. [Well no more], each quarter on do those tre
componenttext:
Well Mark DVD shipments are growing. We don't expect them to flatten this year. Yes, as we said, that growth was less than we thought. So, that would imply the peak would be here earlier that we had the last. 
[Well no more], each quarter on do those trends continue and yes there is great news in this which is if churn stays low and DVD shipments grow slower than revenue then frees up a lot of money for marketing, for content, both growth oriented investments or for earnings. So, good outcomes in all cases is essentially streaming and substituting for DVD as it seems to be happening for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question. You said over the next two quarters you will spend on content and marketing especially streaming content in order to drive subscriber growth, what metrics we'll be looking at in order to determine where you focused your spend? Could we
componenttext: The next question. You said over the next two quarters you will spend on content and marketing especially streaming content in order to drive subscriber growth, what metrics we'll be looking at in order to determine where you focused your spend? Could we expect other forms of marketing spend like more TV, print, mobile advertising?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We are very happy with the mix of marketing that we are doing and if we said more you would be doing more online and more TV, but no radical changes. It's simply getting more impressions of the great advertising that we've got.
componenttext: We are very happy with the mix of marketing that we are doing and if we said more you would be doing more online and more TV, but no radical changes. It's simply getting more impressions of the great advertising that we've got.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Next question from George Askew at Stifel Nicolaus. You state in your commentary that you see TV shows that's equally important to the franchise as movies, within the [watched instantly] library, could you share with us the mix of content between T
componenttext: Great. Next question from George Askew at Stifel Nicolaus. You state in your commentary that you see TV shows that's equally important to the franchise as movies, within the [watched instantly] library, could you share with us the mix of content between TV shows and movies?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: George, we don't break it out, the mix of content, because TV shows are a smaller unit. You get unit viewables, hours of viewing, hours of viewables, all different kinds of measures. But what I can tell you is they are both very big for us and both very s
componenttext: George, we don't break it out, the mix of content, because TV shows are a smaller unit. You get unit viewables, hours of viewing, hours of viewables, all different kinds of measures. But what I can tell you is they are both very big for us and both very substantial and we continue to expand both on the movie side and on the TV show side.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is based on what you know about the movie plus subscription offering, do you view it as a substitute or a complement to the Netflix streaming program?
componenttext: The next question is based on what you know about the movie plus subscription offering, do you view it as a substitute or a complement to the Netflix streaming program?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a potential significant competitor and it is a direct competitor, movies and TV shows streaming; so subscription, and we take it seriously as a direct competitor.
componenttext: It's a potential significant competitor and it is a direct competitor, movies and TV shows streaming; so subscription, and we take it seriously as a direct competitor.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Next question from Ralph Scharkart at William Blair. Does the Digital Entertainment Content Ecosystem's recent branding campaign and stated goal of rolling out a standard digital platform for new released movies change Netflix' stand on offering ne
componenttext: Great. Next question from Ralph Scharkart at William Blair. Does the Digital Entertainment Content Ecosystem's recent branding campaign and stated goal of rolling out a standard digital platform for new released movies change Netflix' stand on offering new digital movies/VoD? If not, what is the rationale given Netflix' membership in the DECE.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well we've often addressed this topic which is sort of what's our relationship to pay-per-view and sometimes called download-to-own, which are two variants, a $4 variant and a $20 variant. And that is that there are many companies in that business; Amazon
componenttext: Well we've often addressed this topic which is sort of what's our relationship to pay-per-view and sometimes called download-to-own, which are two variants, a $4 variant and a $20 variant. And that is that there are many companies in that business; Amazon, Apple, Sony, Microsoft, CinemaNow and others. It's well addressed. We don't know how to add any particular value to that space. And we are really focused on subscription and we've got such a big opportunity in subscription that this year our growth is accelerating dramatically, and so we don't see any need or desire to expand our available market. We're just very focused on subscription.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Tony Wible of Janney Montgomery Scott. Will Netflix have exclusive access to all of their Relativity films or only the single production films, would the joint production films still go to HBO and Starz.
componenttext: Next question from Tony Wible of Janney Montgomery Scott. Will Netflix have exclusive access to all of their Relativity films or only the single production films, would the joint production films still go to HBO and Starz.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tony, Relativity does as you know a broad range of production and then we did at a deal for some of the content but we are not the sole distribution partner or sole PayTV partner for Relativity produced films.
componenttext: Tony, Relativity does as you know a broad range of production and then we did at a deal for some of the content but we are not the sole distribution partner or sole PayTV partner for Relativity produced films.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Justin Patterson at Morgan Keegan. You mentioned then the Playstation user interface coming this fall, will that require access to the premium Playstation Plus subscription service, should we think about a new user interface probably in
componenttext: Next question from Justin Patterson at Morgan Keegan. You mentioned then the Playstation user interface coming this fall, will that require access to the premium Playstation Plus subscription service, should we think about a new user interface probably in the coming months too?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On the PS3, we'll have more to say about that when we roll it out and that will be before or expected to be before the next call. In terms of re-user interface like all of our user interfaces, we're working on improvements but we have nothing to announce
componenttext: On the PS3, we'll have more to say about that when we roll it out and that will be before or expected to be before the next call. In terms of re-user interface like all of our user interfaces, we're working on improvements but we have nothing to announce today.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord. Could you speak both qualitatively and quantitatively on the success you are seeing with regards to activations on web-enabled televisions from manufacturers you mentioned i.e., Samsung, Sony VIZIO et cetera
componenttext: Next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord. Could you speak both qualitatively and quantitatively on the success you are seeing with regards to activations on web-enabled televisions from manufacturers you mentioned i.e., Samsung, Sony VIZIO et cetera.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Wayne, we focus on three broad categories, the videogame consoles that have large installed bases and upgradeability over the internet, so like gives them a big advantage. Second category is Blu-ray. And that advantage is they are all internet connected b
componenttext:
Wayne, we focus on three broad categories, the videogame consoles that have large installed bases and upgradeability over the internet, so like gives them a big advantage. Second category is Blu-ray. And that advantage is they are all internet connected because it was part of the Blu-ray security spec and they are relatively low in price. So they are easy to upgrade if you got a big TV already in place. 
The third category is the one you asked about, Internet TV which is just emerging now. We've been very happy with some of the early progress from Sony and VIZIO and others, but that category in the very long term is likely to be the leading category. But at this point, it's still nascent. And that works for us fine. We're doing significant investments in all three of those broad areas.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard. Can you offer a prediction of when Netflix will be recognizing more expensive income statements from an online content when it occurs from the direct content cost of DVDs excluding of this?
componenttext: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard. Can you offer a prediction of when Netflix will be recognizing more expensive income statements from an online content when it occurs from the direct content cost of DVDs excluding of this?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're going to comment on it at this time.
componenttext: I don't think we're going to comment on it at this time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And next question regarding core cutting, do you see any evidence on Netflix subscribers are inclined to either cancel multi-channel video subscriptions or to (inaudible) back use of premium services such as Starz, Encore, HBO?
componenttext: And next question regarding core cutting, do you see any evidence on Netflix subscribers are inclined to either cancel multi-channel video subscriptions or to (inaudible) back use of premium services such as Starz, Encore, HBO?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't seen any evidence of that and there's no evidence in the total numbers of those firms in the last quarter's financials and total subscribers. Total multi-channel video subscribers is continuing to grow in the US, premium subscribers is not
componenttext: No, we haven't seen any evidence of that and there's no evidence in the total numbers of those firms in the last quarter's financials and total subscribers. Total multi-channel video subscribers is continuing to grow in the US, premium subscribers is not showing any decline, so I don't think there is any material core cutting. And I think what's happening is you know the multi-channel video is such a broad package with an incredible array of products that were a tiny little fraction of that and our subscribers view it as a supplemental service and because it's a modest cost, at nine bucks a month. It works for them and their budget.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Mike Olson at Piper Jaffray. Have you ever considered raising the price of the subscription to fund content acquisition and to [accrue] introducing a 999 a month plan that is also ad-supported change of thinking on your monthly fees?
componenttext: Next question from Mike Olson at Piper Jaffray. Have you ever considered raising the price of the subscription to fund content acquisition and to [accrue] introducing a 999 a month plan that is also ad-supported change of thinking on your monthly fees?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well who knows that we change our thinking at all? You it is early stage, too small to matter. But generally, we ask ourselves every quarter, should we cut price, should we raise price, should we add more content, shrink the content? We think through ever
componenttext: Well who knows that we change our thinking at all? You it is early stage, too small to matter. But generally, we ask ourselves every quarter, should we cut price, should we raise price, should we add more content, shrink the content? We think through every quarter, in what way should we be evolving the business model? So, nothing particularly at this point but it is always the ongoing question we ask ourselves.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is, while the various metrics were down from quarter-to-quarter and due to seasonality, is it fair to say that as long as the subscriber base continues to migrate through increased usage of streaming in favor of DVD. At gross margin chur
componenttext: The next question is, while the various metrics were down from quarter-to-quarter and due to seasonality, is it fair to say that as long as the subscriber base continues to migrate through increased usage of streaming in favor of DVD. At gross margin churn and fact should all continue to improve on a year-over-year basis in the foreseeable future? What could cause this not to happen?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As we make the service better Michael, I have every reason to believe that, if we're successful in increasing subscriber engagement with the surplus then we'll see improvements in churn and we'll stand to see improvements in SAC.I don't expect to see co
componenttext:
As we make the service better Michael, I have every reason to believe that, if we're successful in increasing subscriber engagement with the surplus then we'll see improvements in churn and we'll stand to see improvements in SAC.
I don't expect to see continuing improvements in gross margin and I think we would probably do ourselves a disservice and slow our growth if we were to stop the content spend and in order to manage the gross margin in the business to a higher level. So in lieu of gross margin I encourage you to think about operating margins as we're clearly making trade-offs between.
And we have through our entire history on SAC churn in gross margins offer the purpose of managing our sales to an operating margin that strikes the right balance between growth and profit. So a right example, we saw last quarter, I told you'd expect us to manage the business at 1% operating margin for the year.
Now we're going faster and having more success doing it than we imagined and to the mid-point of guidance our net income implies an operating margin of about 12.5%. So clearly business is running, at least year-to-date more profitably than we expected and at least in the current quarter on gross margin both because of plan mix shift and because of substitution behavior is more profitable than we had expected. Now in a perfect world that we can time content spending and marketing spending and align it with perfect four side in our forecast, that wouldn't have happened and we would have reinvested that money and had factors of growth still.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike to repeat what Barry said, we do look at operating margins with important discipline, but not gross margin, so if we found the right content deals, we would easily take half of the marketing budget and slip it into contents. If we thought that that's
componenttext: Mike to repeat what Barry said, we do look at operating margins with important discipline, but not gross margin, so if we found the right content deals, we would easily take half of the marketing budget and slip it into contents. If we thought that that's going to help us grow even more than that marketing budget but you know you could see big swings that way, if we think it's in our interest of terms of growth and consistent with our operating margin goals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, the next question is from Imran Khan at JPMorgan. Can you talk about how much of the increasing churn was driven by seasonality versus other factors?
componenttext: Great, the next question is from Imran Khan at JPMorgan. Can you talk about how much of the increasing churn was driven by seasonality versus other factors?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think we saw 30 basis points of seasonal increase a year ago and we saw a 20 basis points roughly of seasonal increase this year, I am talking about Q-over-Q. So on a net basis, I think we are better by about 10 basis points and all the trend lines
componenttext: Well I think we saw 30 basis points of seasonal increase a year ago and we saw a 20 basis points roughly of seasonal increase this year, I am talking about Q-over-Q. So on a net basis, I think we are better by about 10 basis points and all the trend lines for the individual plan types and usage types hybrid versus just going (inaudible) and suggest to me as my commentary indicates there will be continuously improvement in churns through the remainder of the year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. There will be a year term launch April before a user interface upgrade to the Wii and is the driver there exclusivity plus yield terms are related to R&D priorities?
componenttext: Next question is from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. There will be a year term launch April before a user interface upgrade to the Wii and is the driver there exclusivity plus yield terms are related to R&D priorities?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian there is no limit in our ability to innovate on the Wii. Once the new PS3 launches, that will convert from a disk based user interface to a downloadable user interface, which makes the cost of upgrading very small for PS3. At this point the Wii's fo
componenttext: Brian there is no limit in our ability to innovate on the Wii. Once the new PS3 launches, that will convert from a disk based user interface to a downloadable user interface, which makes the cost of upgrading very small for PS3. At this point the Wii's forecast will still remain a disk based model. And that is some practical constraints to the timing and frequency of upgrades. So, that's the only material difference going forward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Next question is from John Blackledge from Credit Suisse. What is driving streaming content purchase decisions? Is it about acquiring as much quality content, netbooks can get at fair value or the initial viewing trends from subscribers taking purchasing decisions?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The two factors are how much budget we have for streaming content. And then can we get it. You referred to fair market value, but really can we just get an agreement of a price that works for us both. And if it's so, then we do that deal.
componenttext: The two factors are how much budget we have for streaming content. And then can we get it. You referred to fair market value, but really can we just get an agreement of a price that works for us both. And if it's so, then we do that deal.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Next question is from Ed Williams at BMO. How quickly do you think you might be able to extend outside of Canada into other international markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ed we're going to take a look and see how we do in Canada with a New York streaming model. See if we've got the right amount of content, the right marketing approach. And we'll take a look at those results, and then try to figure out what that means for o
componenttext: Ed we're going to take a look and see how we do in Canada with a New York streaming model. See if we've got the right amount of content, the right marketing approach. And we'll take a look at those results, and then try to figure out what that means for our opportunity in other countries. So until we get a couple months after the launch we're going to be sitting still.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: The second question, can you provide some color on the usage patterns of launch instruments, specifically, our new subscribers using this service differently than those that have been subscribers for a longer period of time? Is there a measurable base of subscribers who are exclusively using launch instantly?

componenttextpreview: And to the last part, almost everyone takes both DVDs and streaming and partially that's because the DVDs have all the new releases, so there is a pretty sector of content there that's DVD only. But in terms of viewing patterns, newer subs as a class are
componenttext: And to the last part, almost everyone takes both DVDs and streaming and partially that's because the DVDs have all the new releases, so there is a pretty sector of content there that's DVD only. But in terms of viewing patterns, newer subs as a class are more streaming centric partially is because when they came and that's why some established their habits, we upgrade streaming, whereas if you joined us five years ago, you'll use to it as a DVD business so of a thousand people that are with us to join five years, you get a viewer that are extremely centric as you do in the new subs, pretty much as you would expect. The migration is happening in all classes and its increasing amongst all classes.

componenttext: Andy what has that potential, if we weren't focused on prior season instead of current season? On current season you do get potential competition with essentially the DDR model, the advertising model, all of those things but on prior season, we are able to create value that wasn't there before and generate incremental profits for the content owner and so there is not a conflict there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Next question from Heath Terry of FBR. Can you breakdown the components of the increase in SAC, rising ad cost, mix of higher bounty deals or lower response rates, to non-bounty deals TV, radio.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I could but I'd get skewered back (inaudible) also. I'm going to take a pass on that. Your walk away should be that there is nothing that's happening in the marketplace particularly that's increasing our cost of doing business. So the increase in SAC is s
componenttext: I could but I'd get skewered back (inaudible) also. I'm going to take a pass on that. Your walk away should be that there is nothing that's happening in the marketplace particularly that's increasing our cost of doing business. So the increase in SAC is strictly a managed outcome but we would say she starts with the lowest cost of subscriber acquisition and then layer-on-layer she builds out her acquisition channels and as the budget permits. There are quarters like Q4 when consumers are very active and the cost of acquisitions is relatively low and there are an abundance of marketing opportunities available to her, so happens and Q2 is the slowest quarter by far. And so, an aggressive spend in Q2 is a little bit my question on (inaudible).

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And so Heath if we ever drop the marketing budget on a year-over-year basis and have SAC to increase then you can worry about that case, kind of what's happening. It's harder to get subs. But when you increase marketing dramatically on a year-over-year ba
componenttext: And so Heath if we ever drop the marketing budget on a year-over-year basis and have SAC to increase then you can worry about that case, kind of what's happening. It's harder to get subs. But when you increase marketing dramatically on a year-over-year basis as Barry said, knowing how much you increase it, that's what's driving the SAC up on the margin.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Somewhere its seasonality and somewhere its growth, right. If we had slower growth and new subs churn at a much higher rate than the short subs like a 10% rate versus 1.5% rate, sort of and what it seems lower churn. componenttext: Could it continue to decline?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. Could churn continue to decline on a seasonal basis? Yes. Let's see, if we continue to improve the overall quality in the service in a way that increases subscriber engagement with the service then the answer is yes. Certainly in the curr
componenttext: Yes, I think so. Could churn continue to decline on a seasonal basis? Yes. Let's see, if we continue to improve the overall quality in the service in a way that increases subscriber engagement with the service then the answer is yes. Certainly in the current competitive environment, it's a competitive environment systematically, or if we make bad decisions about how invest in the quality of service and we are not successful in briefing engagement, the trend could reverse, no question.

componenttext: Barry and I are looking at each other like did he say that? I don't think we said that anyway. Yes and going forward what we are looking at is if we can spend it on content efficiently, we'll spent it on content, and that would have reduced marketing. If we don't find the right deals then we'll end up spending it on marketing. So if you add up to some of those marketing plus cause, now that's where, that will stay, I think lets say its not a consistent one to P&L but its a trade-off between on the margin marketing expense and streaming content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Netflix Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Erin Kasenchak, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Netflix Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Erin Kasenchak, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We release earnings for the second quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. Earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's resu
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We release earnings for the second quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. Earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. 
Like last quarter, this call will consist solely of Q&A, and we are going to conduct this Q&A via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to ir@netflix.com.
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 22, 2010. 
A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific Time today. Before moving in to Q&A, I'd like to turn the call over to Reed for a few opening remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll welcome everyone and let's jump in with the questions. Erin?
componenttext: I'll welcome everyone and let's jump in with the questions. Erin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: First question is from Steve Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Does the recent content deal with Relativity Media signal a material increase in the overall content expenditures or a continuation of the trend of shifting investments from physical to digital?
componenttext: First question is from Steve Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Does the recent content deal with Relativity Media signal a material increase in the overall content expenditures or a continuation of the trend of shifting investments from physical to digital?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Steven, it's a little of both. We have been investing more in streaming content quarter after quarter, year after year. As we get revenue growth and confirmation that the streaming content investment is a smart one and Relativity does indicate a material
componenttext: Steven, it's a little of both. We have been investing more in streaming content quarter after quarter, year after year. As we get revenue growth and confirmation that the streaming content investment is a smart one and Relativity does indicate a material step up in that, most of that doesn't come in until Relativity delivers the films, so that would be next year and beyond. So it's not a material step up this year through Relativity. But we are out looking for more content and unique to Relativity is that it's completely exclusive for Internet subscription to Netflix. So it's the first of essentially a side shift in our strategy which is due also in light of things [ph]  Exclusive content in addition to non-exclusive content. We don't see a big radical shift. It's just that we're doing some of the content on movies and TV shows exclusively now, which as you know is -- opens new positive  content availability because much of the content in the pay TV window is sold exclusively.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And second question is what is the percentage of subscribers on Blu-ray plan?
componenttext: And second question is what is the percentage of subscribers on Blu-ray plan?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Steven, it's a little over 10%.
componenttext: Steven, it's a little over 10%.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Dave Miller of Caris & Company. Can you confirm whether or not the introduction of the iPad app has resulted in additional subs beyond your expectations or whether the Netflix app has resulted in an already existing subs acquiring the i
componenttext: Next question from Dave Miller of Caris & Company. Can you confirm whether or not the introduction of the iPad app has resulted in additional subs beyond your expectations or whether the Netflix app has resulted in an already existing subs acquiring the iPad?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well Dave, having new platform, whether that's the Wii, the iPad, all the platforms do both. They help us with existing subscribers getting more value from the Netflix service, and they help us attract new subscribers. And the iPad was a big success for u
componenttext: Well Dave, having new platform, whether that's the Wii, the iPad, all the platforms do both. They help us with existing subscribers getting more value from the Netflix service, and they help us attract new subscribers. And the iPad was a big success for us as the Wii was and has really all of our platforms have been.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Youssef Squali at Jefferies & Company. How was the rate of activations on the Wii versus what you have seen for the Xbox in the first 90 days?
componenttext: Next question from Youssef Squali at Jefferies & Company. How was the rate of activations on the Wii versus what you have seen for the Xbox in the first 90 days?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, we don't break out platform specifics, but I would say that we were very happy with Xbox when it came out, and we've been very happy with the PS3, and now we're very happy with the Wii. They all have large install bases. And that's a meaningful w
componenttext: Youssef, we don't break out platform specifics, but I would say that we were very happy with Xbox when it came out, and we've been very happy with the PS3, and now we're very happy with the Wii. They all have large install bases. And that's a meaningful way for our subscribers to get value from our servers and watch great movies and TV shows.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question, is there a subsegment of subscribers who only stream the service and stop ordering DVDs? If so, can you quantify?
componenttext: The second question, is there a subsegment of subscribers who only stream the service and stop ordering DVDs? If so, can you quantify?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The majority of subscribers do both, stream and take DVDs.
componenttext: The majority of subscribers do both, stream and take DVDs.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. Are the marketing expense associated with the Canadian expansion already factored into your operating margin guidance for 2010?
componenttext: Next question from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. Are the marketing expense associated with the Canadian expansion already factored into your operating margin guidance for 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is.
componenttext: Yes, it is.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And what percentage of your CDM partners will support Canadian subscribers?
componenttext: And what percentage of your CDM partners will support Canadian subscribers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Assuming that you meant CDN there, in which case, there's no real issues at Internet, our providers such as Akamai and Limelight and others work hard in Canada.
componenttext: Assuming that you meant CDN there, in which case, there's no real issues at Internet, our providers such as Akamai and Limelight and others work hard in Canada.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. As Netflix gears up to enter the Canadian market and presumably other foreign markets, what is the most significant content delivery challenge facing the company? Do you expect higher-content deliver
componenttext: Next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. As Netflix gears up to enter the Canadian market and presumably other foreign markets, what is the most significant content delivery challenge facing the company? Do you expect higher-content delivery unit costs than you have in the U.S.?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Delivery -- by delivery, one means the cost of streaming, that's a fairly small part of the total picture. So I would say in Canada, the challenge is our licensing, the right content, the right cost, and then taking advantage of the right marketing channe
componenttext: Delivery -- by delivery, one means the cost of streaming, that's a fairly small part of the total picture. So I would say in Canada, the challenge is our licensing, the right content, the right cost, and then taking advantage of the right marketing channels at the right cost. Those are the two primary drivers, the content and the marketing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Dan Ernst at Hudson Square. Questions on accessing rights to digital content for instant watch? Does the size of your subscriber base relative to large cable and satellite carriers factor at all into your ability to gain such rights? An
componenttext: Next question from Dan Ernst at Hudson Square. Questions on accessing rights to digital content for instant watch? Does the size of your subscriber base relative to large cable and satellite carriers factor at all into your ability to gain such rights? And if you will state your top 500 titles across the year, what percentage of those are now available for instant watch?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well let's see, a relative size isn't a direct impact, Dan. It's more the absolute size of our checks. So if the biggest check we can write for a piece of content is $10,000, it's a long shot to get it. If the biggest is $20 million for some piece of cont
componenttext: Well let's see, a relative size isn't a direct impact, Dan. It's more the absolute size of our checks. So if the biggest check we can write for a piece of content is $10,000, it's a long shot to get it. If the biggest is $20 million for some piece of content, we're pretty likely to be outbid anybody else. So it's as you would expect in that way, so there's an indirect influence around our revenue or our content spending budget. The larger that it is, the more effective we can be. And then you ask about the top 500. I'm not sure how to answer that exactly, but I would say that the power of Netflix is to take a lot of content. It may not be the hottest content, and make it feel like it's an incredible service to subscribers. That's where we add value as a service, and that one is nearly carrying the hottest content on the planet. There's not as much of a trough of opportunity in that, because you'd have to pay the content owner, well, the content owner has earned most of the value generated to extract that. So our key is not around top 500, our key is breadth and what percent of our subscribers are streaming. Can we keep them actively streaming? Because if they're actively streaming, and taking DVDs, then they'll retain better. And you can see that in the year-over-year improvements in retention that we generated.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question is related to churn. Churn, a second area of interest is on churn. What are the top two areas a customer goes to instead of Netflix when they leave? Also, of the customers you've added over the last year, what percentage of those have
componenttext: The second question is related to churn. Churn, a second area of interest is on churn. What are the top two areas a customer goes to instead of Netflix when they leave? Also, of the customers you've added over the last year, what percentage of those have been Netflix customers previously?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our rejoin rate is usually around a third, plus or take five points. And on the first part of the question, what's that Erin?
componenttext: Our rejoin rate is usually around a third, plus or take five points. And on the first part of the question, what's that Erin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Where do the top two places that people go when they churn?
componenttext: Where do the top two places that people go when they churn?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: When we ask them, it's a little bit of a choppy answer I could give you, because we ask about movies, where'd you get movies from? There's just going to be different answer than the one you get TV shows from, but when if you ask where they get movies from
componenttext: When we ask them, it's a little bit of a choppy answer I could give you, because we ask about movies, where'd you get movies from? There's just going to be different answer than the one you get TV shows from, but when if you ask where they get movies from, consumers say that kiosks with $1 rental, that's the big one and it's still rising. Almost everything else is in the noise.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Jeff Rath at Canaccord. Free subscribers, as a percentage of paying subscribers, have reached the highest level ever for Netflix. What's causing this? And how should we expect this to trend for the remainder of 2010?
componenttext: Next question from Jeff Rath at Canaccord. Free subscribers, as a percentage of paying subscribers, have reached the highest level ever for Netflix. What's causing this? And how should we expect this to trend for the remainder of 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's not a huge difference in general that's a reflection of our growth rate. So our growth rates, astoundingly, have been moving up all year long, and we expect them to continue to grow higher growth rate will be associated with a higher rate of free tri
componenttext: It's not a huge difference in general that's a reflection of our growth rate. So our growth rates, astoundingly, have been moving up all year long, and we expect them to continue to grow higher growth rate will be associated with a higher rate of free trials at any point in time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That's pretty much it. There's this seasonality contributes ever so slightly to the number of revenue in months generated in a quarter, which bears on the mix of both free and paid. Q2 tends to be slightly back-end loaded, Q3 is pretty much flatlined thro
componenttext: That's pretty much it. There's this seasonality contributes ever so slightly to the number of revenue in months generated in a quarter, which bears on the mix of both free and paid. Q2 tends to be slightly back-end loaded, Q3 is pretty much flatlined through the quarter. Q4 is back-end loaded. But we describe it as predominant influence which is sub-growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Nat Schindler of BofA Merrill. Dramatic increase in subscriber guidance up $1.2 million on top and bottom end of guidance for the year end, coupled with limited increase in revenue guidance suggest that you now view ARPU coming down muc
componenttext: Next question from Nat Schindler of BofA Merrill. Dramatic increase in subscriber guidance up $1.2 million on top and bottom end of guidance for the year end, coupled with limited increase in revenue guidance suggest that you now view ARPU coming down much faster than you did before. What has changed?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, not so much. The only thing that's changed in the business, and it's quite a significant change, is the accelerated growth, and we attribute that to streaming. And streaming implies for 1-out Unlimited price point. So I said on the Q3 call a
componenttext: I would say, not so much. The only thing that's changed in the business, and it's quite a significant change, is the accelerated growth, and we attribute that to streaming. And streaming implies for 1-out Unlimited price point. So I said on the Q3 call a year ago that if prices decline rapidly towards that 1-out Unlimited plan, we'll be very excited. That's great news for the business, because it means that streaming is resonating with consumers and likely, we will see accelerating growth, and in fact we are seeing accelerated growth. So if you're doing a year-over-year comp, it helps to remember that we initiated, in part, of Blu-ray price increase in Q2 a year ago for two months of the quarter and then three months of the quarter in Q3, and so that really dampens the effect of the shift towards the 1-out plan. But absent that effect, we're tracking year-over-year, say Q3, Q4, I think will be on par, one to another.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And now we do expect as streaming continues to be successful as it has been for us, that our $8.99 1-U plan will be a larger and larger percentage, both the sign-ups and therefore the installed base. We're not seeing any material migration of the install
componenttext: And now we do expect as streaming continues to be successful as it has been for us, that our $8.99 1-U plan will be a larger and larger percentage, both the sign-ups and therefore the installed base. We're not seeing any material migration of the install base. That has stayed pretty constant when people come in on a certain plan, they stay with it. So it's just that new subscribers are predominantly coming in on the unlimited streaming one DVD at a time plan.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to remind everyone that I think the pure indicator of the growth potential of the business is subscriber growth. We've had lots of discussion about ASP over time in its decline. And because of that discussion, we added a metric which was gross prof
componenttext: I want to remind everyone that I think the pure indicator of the growth potential of the business is subscriber growth. We've had lots of discussion about ASP over time in its decline. And because of that discussion, we added a metric which was gross profit per paying sub. And on a year-over-year basis, we actually saw an increase of about $0.30 in that metrics. So even though ASP is going down, and revenues are growing slower than subscribers are growing in terms of gross profit dollars, we were adding more per new sub in Q2 of this year than we did a year ago.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His second question, how do you get visibility into Q4 subscriber growth? Or in other words, how do you get comfortable without quarter guidance?
componenttext: His second question, how do you get visibility into Q4 subscriber growth? Or in other words, how do you get comfortable without quarter guidance?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We have lots of confidence about next week's outcome, declining less ability to be accurate next month and as you point out, declining less ability the following quarter. So really, a continuum. The trend lines that are propelling Netflix is acceleration
componenttext: We have lots of confidence about next week's outcome, declining less ability to be accurate next month and as you point out, declining less ability the following quarter. So really, a continuum. The trend lines that are propelling Netflix is acceleration had been a very steady, strong acceleration since the beginning of the year, at least. And that's what gives us confidence that it's not one short-term aspect. And while we're not able to -- we're choosing not to predict continued acceleration of growth in Q4, that is our model, our expectation and guidance is that growth will remain at a very strong 48%, 49% subscriber growth in Q4. It's because of the continuity and the steadiness of our acceleration to date as opposed to, I'd say, we're banking on CPM rates or some specific aspect of Q4.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Can you update us on our three- to five-year outlook for operating margins?
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Can you update us on our three- to five-year outlook for operating margins?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, by update, that implies, which have not seen that in the past, which I don't believe we have. In general, we would hold the domestic business, we would want that to steadily improve probably at a fairly modest rate, because the top line is expandin
componenttext: Jason, by update, that implies, which have not seen that in the past, which I don't believe we have. In general, we would hold the domestic business, we would want that to steadily improve probably at a fairly modest rate, because the top line is expanding so dramatically. The global operating margin was dependent upon international. And at what rate, it was prudent to invest.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given that the three largest devices, install bases, Xbox, PS3 and Wii have already launched, how should we think about the subscriber contribution from the initial launches versus follow-on contribution
componenttext: Next question from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given that the three largest devices, install bases, Xbox, PS3 and Wii have already launched, how should we think about the subscriber contribution from the initial launches versus follow-on contribution from the existing install base versus incremental growth in the console install base?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, we've been very happy that the Xbox, which is our longest-outstanding device relationship, we continue to see substantial growth in the number of Xbox users and Xbox activations for Netflix. And that's partially because they're continuing to sell m
componenttext: Scott, we've been very happy that the Xbox, which is our longest-outstanding device relationship, we continue to see substantial growth in the number of Xbox users and Xbox activations for Netflix. And that's partially because they're continuing to sell more, new devices into the market at a considerable rate. And it's partially because we are marketing our service to people who include current Xbox owners. So both install bases, Netflix and Xbox, are growing. And from that, we're seeing continued growth. So we look at it, and we think that we will continue to generate substantial growth from all three of the game platforms because all three are growing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: While Netflix may have the scale to aggressively acquire streaming content, availability of content appears limited due to the exclusivity agreements between premium TV networks and most major studio. Are there other buckets of contents similar to Relativ
componenttext: While Netflix may have the scale to aggressively acquire streaming content, availability of content appears limited due to the exclusivity agreements between premium TV networks and most major studio. Are there other buckets of contents similar to Relativity Media but are not tied up in exclusive agreement? Or will Netflix need to pursue another Starz Live distribution deal with the likes of FX or Showtime in order to dramatically expand the content library?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, you want to separate that out between TV shows and movies. So in movies, there's a small number of makers, and as you mentioned, a number of exclusive deals. And so, we are definitely interested in licensing from HBO, from FX, from Showtime. In add
componenttext: Again, you want to separate that out between TV shows and movies. So in movies, there's a small number of makers, and as you mentioned, a number of exclusive deals. And so, we are definitely interested in licensing from HBO, from FX, from Showtime. In addition, there are pockets of content like Relativity. That's all in the movie side.
