The TV network side, there's a vast array of content and providers, and exclusives are, of the type, that are in movies are much less common, and there's a lot of incremental ability for us to generate new profits for those networks. Because we focus on the prior season, we try to be particularly careful about not conflicting with cable networks, which focus on the newest episode. And we focus on the prior season in generating incremental viewing better than anyone from the prior season viewing. And you will see us continue to expand on that in the coming years.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next questions are from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. There are change in film now from three months ago in terms of shifting sense from marketing content spending. It seems like you are more definitive about the second half content spend increase after Q1
componenttext: Our next questions are from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. There are change in film now from three months ago in terms of shifting sense from marketing content spending. It seems like you are more definitive about the second half content spend increase after Q1 than now?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: There was no intended shift in film, Doug. We expect to significantly increase the spending, streaming in the second half of the year, as compared to the first half of the year, and the first half was a big increase over the second half of the prior year.
componenttext: There was no intended shift in film, Doug. We expect to significantly increase the spending, streaming in the second half of the year, as compared to the first half of the year, and the first half was a big increase over the second half of the prior year. So as the business scales in terms of subscribers, we generate stores with more and more capacity to reallocate spending, and so that's our plan. You're probably referring to the language in my commentary which said that if we're not successful in licensing additional content, then we will spend that money in marketing and grow the sub-growth, and I was kind of inoculated us against creating expectations on the part of investors that in the absence of increased content spending, it would all fall to the bottom line. I didn't want earnings expectations to run away from us. It was another way of reminding folks that earnings is the managed outcome, and we consciously every quarter, make a choice between how much earnings to deliver on the bottom line and how much to invest quarterly in growth either in the form of marketing or making the service better to drive additional foot growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And Doug, I would say, to echo the statement is we've got a consistent strategy which is content gets first ins on the budget, marketing spends what's leftover, and contents try to only buy efficiently. What they don't want to do is send in efficiently. A
componenttext: And Doug, I would say, to echo the statement is we've got a consistent strategy which is content gets first ins on the budget, marketing spends what's leftover, and contents try to only buy efficiently. What they don't want to do is send in efficiently. And so that combination works well. It worked well for us in Q2 and worked well for us the rest of the year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His second question, in deals like Relativity and others, how does the timing of content payments work in terms of cash payments and financial statement recognition? How lumpy our payments here? And when would you start to actively begin talking to Starz
componenttext: His second question, in deals like Relativity and others, how does the timing of content payments work in terms of cash payments and financial statement recognition? How lumpy our payments here? And when would you start to actively begin talking to Starz about renewing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the accounting and cash flow part of the question. Of course, we don't make disclosures on a deal-by-deal basis. But in general, and by way of reminder, if we negotiate a multi-year deal for streamed content, and if we're not able to allocate
componenttext: Let me take the accounting and cash flow part of the question. Of course, we don't make disclosures on a deal-by-deal basis. But in general, and by way of reminder, if we negotiate a multi-year deal for streamed content, and if we're not able to allocate value for the deal to individual titles, then we amortize the cost of the license agreement on a straight-line basis over the term. And cash flow aspects of the deal are each unique to any individual deal and can vary quite a bit, nothing about any of the deals that we've negotiated. They change in a significant way, the cash flow attributes of the business.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And what's the second part?
componenttext: And what's the second part?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: When might you start discussions about the Starz renewal?
componenttext: When might you start discussions about the Starz renewal?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On these Hollywood type deals, they're always in discussions. That never ends. There's no particular time does it begin or end.
componenttext: On these Hollywood type deals, they're always in discussions. That never ends. There's no particular time does it begin or end.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. With the slowdown in growth of DVD shipments, are we at an inflection point where we could start to see DVD shipments growth flatline or even start to decline, I mean really start to take off? Or is this more
componenttext: Next question from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. With the slowdown in growth of DVD shipments, are we at an inflection point where we could start to see DVD shipments growth flatline or even start to decline, I mean really start to take off? Or is this more of a function of limited content acquired during the quarter that DVD shipments could continue to grow and/or even accelerate?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Mark, DVD shipments are growing. We don't expect them to flatten this year. It's as we said, the growth is less than we thought. So that would imply the peak would be a year earlier than we have thought. We'll know more each quarter on do those tren
componenttext: Well, Mark, DVD shipments are growing. We don't expect them to flatten this year. It's as we said, the growth is less than we thought. So that would imply the peak would be a year earlier than we have thought. We'll know more each quarter on do those trends continue. And yes, there's great news in this which is if churn stays low and DVD shipments grow slower than revenue, then that frees up a lot of money for marketing, for content, both growth-oriented investments or for earnings. So good outcomes in all cases if essentially streaming and substituting for DVD as it seems to be happening for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His next question, you said over the next two quarters you will spend on content and marketing especially streaming content in order to drive subscriber growth. What metrics will you be looking at in order to determine where you focused your spend? Could
componenttext: His next question, you said over the next two quarters you will spend on content and marketing especially streaming content in order to drive subscriber growth. What metrics will you be looking at in order to determine where you focused your spend? Could we expect other forms of marketing spend like more TV, print, mobile advertising?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We're very happy with the mix of marketing that we're doing. And if we spent more, you would see us be doing more online and more TV, but no radical changes. It's simply getting more impressions of the great advertising that we've got.
componenttext: We're very happy with the mix of marketing that we're doing. And if we spent more, you would see us be doing more online and more TV, but no radical changes. It's simply getting more impressions of the great advertising that we've got.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from George Askew at Stifel, Nicolaus. You stated in your commentary that you see TV shows that's equally important to the franchise as movies. Within the Watch Instantly Library, could you share us the mix of contents between TV shows and m
componenttext: Next question from George Askew at Stifel, Nicolaus. You stated in your commentary that you see TV shows that's equally important to the franchise as movies. Within the Watch Instantly Library, could you share us the mix of contents between TV shows and movies?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: George, we don't break it out, the mix of content. And because TV shows are a smaller unit, you have unit viewable, hours of viewing, hours of viewable, all different kinds of measures. But what I can tell you is they're both very big for us and both very
componenttext: George, we don't break it out, the mix of content. And because TV shows are a smaller unit, you have unit viewable, hours of viewing, hours of viewable, all different kinds of measures. But what I can tell you is they're both very big for us and both very substantial. And we continue to expand both on the movie side and on the TV show side.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His next question is, based on what you know about the Hulu Plus subscription offerings, do you view it as a substitute or as a complement to the Netflix streaming service?
componenttext: His next question is, based on what you know about the Hulu Plus subscription offerings, do you view it as a substitute or as a complement to the Netflix streaming service?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a potential significant competitor, and it is a direct competitor. Its movies and TV shows streaming, as well as subscription, and we take it seriously as a direct competitor.
componenttext: It's a potential significant competitor, and it is a direct competitor. Its movies and TV shows streaming, as well as subscription, and we take it seriously as a direct competitor.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Does the digital entertainment content ecosystems recent branding campaign and stated goal of rolling out a standard digital platform for new release movies changed Netflix's stand on offering new digit
componenttext: Next question from Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Does the digital entertainment content ecosystems recent branding campaign and stated goal of rolling out a standard digital platform for new release movies changed Netflix's stand on offering new digital movies/VOD? If not, what is the rationale given Netflix membership in the DECE?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've often addressed this topic. We just sort of -- what's our relationship to pay-per-view? And, sometimes called download to own, which are two variance, a $4 variance and a $20 variance. And that is that there are many companies in that business
componenttext: Well, we've often addressed this topic. We just sort of -- what's our relationship to pay-per-view? And, sometimes called download to own, which are two variance, a $4 variance and a $20 variance. And that is that there are many companies in that business: Amazon, Apple, Sony, Microsoft, CinemaNow and others. It's well addressed. We don't know how to add any particular value to that space. And we are really focused on subscription, and we've got such a big opportunity in subscription that this year, our growth is accelerating dramatically. And so we don't see any leader desire to expand our available market. We're just very focused on subscription.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Will Netflix have exclusive access to all of the Relativity films or only the single-production films? Will the joint-production films still go to HBO and Starz?
componenttext: Next question from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Will Netflix have exclusive access to all of the Relativity films or only the single-production films? Will the joint-production films still go to HBO and Starz?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tony, the Relativity does, as you know, a broad range of production. And then we did a deal for some of the content, but we're not sole distribution partners or sole pay TV partner for Relativity-produced films.
componenttext: Tony, the Relativity does, as you know, a broad range of production. And then we did a deal for some of the content, but we're not sole distribution partners or sole pay TV partner for Relativity-produced films.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Justin Patterson at Morgan Keegan. You mentioned a new PlayStation user interface coming this fall. Will that require access to the premium PlayStation Plus subscription service? Should we think about a new user interface for Wii in the
componenttext: Next question from Justin Patterson at Morgan Keegan. You mentioned a new PlayStation user interface coming this fall. Will that require access to the premium PlayStation Plus subscription service? Should we think about a new user interface for Wii in the coming months, too?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On the PS3, we'll have more to say about that when we roll it out, and we expect it to be before the next call. In terms of the Wii user interface, like all of our user interfaces, we're working on improvements, but we have nothing to announce today.
componenttext: On the PS3, we'll have more to say about that when we roll it out, and we expect it to be before the next call. In terms of the Wii user interface, like all of our user interfaces, we're working on improvements, but we have nothing to announce today.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord. Could you speak for us qualitatively and quantitatively on the success you're seeing with regards to activations on web-enabled televisions from manufacturers you mentioned, i.e., Samsung, Sony, VIZIO, et ce
componenttext: Next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord. Could you speak for us qualitatively and quantitatively on the success you're seeing with regards to activations on web-enabled televisions from manufacturers you mentioned, i.e., Samsung, Sony, VIZIO, et cetera?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Wayne, we focus on three broad categories. The video game consoles that have large install bases and upgradability over the Internet, so I'd give them a big advantage. Second category is Blu-ray, and that advantages, they're all Internet connected because
componenttext: Wayne, we focus on three broad categories. The video game consoles that have large install bases and upgradability over the Internet, so I'd give them a big advantage. Second category is Blu-ray, and that advantages, they're all Internet connected because it was part of the Blu-ray securities spec. And they're relatively low in price, so they're easy to upgrade if you've got a big TV sale already in place. The third category is the one you asked about, Internet TV, which is just emerging now. We've been very happy with some of the early progress from Sony and VIZIO and others. But that category, in the very long term, is likely to be the leading category. But at this point, it's still nascent. And that works for us fine. We're doing significant investments in all three of those broad areas.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard. Can you offer a prediction of when Netflix will be recognizing more expense in the income statement from an online content and then, of course, from the direct content cost of DVDs excluding postage?
componenttext: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard. Can you offer a prediction of when Netflix will be recognizing more expense in the income statement from an online content and then, of course, from the direct content cost of DVDs excluding postage?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're going to comment on it at this time.
componenttext: I don't think we're going to comment on it at this time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His next question regarding cord cutting. Do you see any evidence that Netflix subscribers are inclined to either cancel multichannel video subscription or to par back use of premium services such as Starz, Encore or HBO?
componenttext: His next question regarding cord cutting. Do you see any evidence that Netflix subscribers are inclined to either cancel multichannel video subscription or to par back use of premium services such as Starz, Encore or HBO?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't seen any evidence of that, and there's no evidence in the total numbers of those firms in the last quarter's financials and total subscribers. So total multichannel video subscribers is continuing to grow in the U.S. Premium subscribers is
componenttext: No, we haven't seen any evidence of that, and there's no evidence in the total numbers of those firms in the last quarter's financials and total subscribers. So total multichannel video subscribers is continuing to grow in the U.S. Premium subscribers is not showing any decline. So I don't think there's any material cord cutting. And I think what's happening is the multichannel video is such a broad package with an incredible array of products that were a tiny little fraction of that and our subscribers view us as a supplemental service, and because it's a modest cost, at $9 a month, it works for them and their budget.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Mike Olson at Piper Jaffray. Have you ever considered raising the price of the subscription to fund content acquisition? And does Hulu introducing a $9.99 a month plan that is also ad supported change your thinking on your monthly fees?
componenttext: Next question from Mike Olson at Piper Jaffray. Have you ever considered raising the price of the subscription to fund content acquisition? And does Hulu introducing a $9.99 a month plan that is also ad supported change your thinking on your monthly fees?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Hulu doesn't change our thinking at all. They just, at this early stage, too small to matter. But generally, we ask ourselves every quarter, should we cut price, should we raise price? Should we add more content, shrink the content? We think through every
componenttext: Hulu doesn't change our thinking at all. They just, at this early stage, too small to matter. But generally, we ask ourselves every quarter, should we cut price, should we raise price? Should we add more content, shrink the content? We think through every quarter in what way should we be evolving the business model. So nothing particularly at this point, but it's is always an ongoing question we ask ourselves.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His next question is, while the various metrics will bounce around from quarter-to-quarter and due to seasonality, is it fair to say that as long as the subscriber base continues to migrate to increase usage of streaming in favor of DVD, that gross margin
componenttext: His next question is, while the various metrics will bounce around from quarter-to-quarter and due to seasonality, is it fair to say that as long as the subscriber base continues to migrate to increase usage of streaming in favor of DVD, that gross margin, churn and SAC should all continue to improve on a year-over-year basis in the foreseeable future? What could cause this not to happen?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As we make this service better, Michael, I have every reason to believe that if we're successful in increasing subscriber engagement with the service, that we'll see improvements in churn and we stand to see improvements in SAC. I don't expect to see cont
componenttext: As we make this service better, Michael, I have every reason to believe that if we're successful in increasing subscriber engagement with the service, that we'll see improvements in churn and we stand to see improvements in SAC. I don't expect to see continued improvements in gross margin, and I think we would probably do ourselves a disservice and slow our growth if we were to starve the content spend in order to manage the gross margin in the business to a higher level. So in lieu of gross margin, I encourage you to think about operating margins as we're clearly making trade-offs between, as we have through our entire history, SAC, churn and gross margin all for the purpose of managing ourselves to an operating margin that strikes the right balance between growth and profit. So by way of example, last quarter, I told you to expect us to manage the business to 1% operating margin for the year. Now we're growing faster and having more success doing it than we imagined and to the midpoint of guidance, our net income implies an operating margin of about 12.5%. So clearly, business is running, at least year-to-date, more profitably than we expected. And at least in the current quarter, gross margin, both because of planned mix shift and because of substitution behavior, is more profitable than we had expected. Now in a perfect world, if we could time content spending and marketing spending and align it with perfect foresight in our forecast, that wouldn't have happened, and we would have reinvested that money and had faster sub growth still.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, to repeat what Barry said. We do look at operating margins as important discipline but not gross margins. So if we found the right content deals, we would easily take half of the marketing budget and flip it into content. If we thought that that's g
componenttext: Mike, to repeat what Barry said. We do look at operating margins as important discipline but not gross margins. So if we found the right content deals, we would easily take half of the marketing budget and flip it into content. If we thought that that's going to help us grow even more than that marketing budget. You could see big swings that way if we think it's on our interest in terms of growth and consistent with our operating margin goals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Imran Khan at JPMorgan. Can you talk about how much of the increase in churn was driven by seasonality versus other factors?
componenttext: The next question is from Imran Khan at JPMorgan. Can you talk about how much of the increase in churn was driven by seasonality versus other factors?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think we saw 30 basis points of seasonal increase a year ago, and we saw 20 basis points roughly at seasonal increase this year. I'm talking about Q-over-Q. From a net basis, I think we're better by about 10 basis points, and all the trend lines fo
componenttext: Well I think we saw 30 basis points of seasonal increase a year ago, and we saw 20 basis points roughly at seasonal increase this year. I'm talking about Q-over-Q. From a net basis, I think we're better by about 10 basis points, and all the trend lines for the individual plant types and usage types, hybrid versus just going the rest of it, suggests to me, as my commentary indicates, that we will continue to see improvement in churn through the remainder of the year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. We will be a year from launch, April, before a user interface upgrade to the Wii. Is there a driver there -- is the driver there exclusivity/deal terms or related to R&D priority?
componenttext: Next question is from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. We will be a year from launch, April, before a user interface upgrade to the Wii. Is there a driver there -- is the driver there exclusivity/deal terms or related to R&D priority?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, there's no limit on our ability to innovate on the Wii. Once the new PS3 launches, that will convert from a disk-based user interface to a downloadable user interface, which makes the cost of upgrading very small for PS3. At this point, the Wii is
componenttext: Brian, there's no limit on our ability to innovate on the Wii. Once the new PS3 launches, that will convert from a disk-based user interface to a downloadable user interface, which makes the cost of upgrading very small for PS3. At this point, the Wii is forecast to still remain a disk-based model, and that is some practical constraint to the timing and frequency of upgrades. So that's the only material difference going forward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from John Blackledge from Credit Suisse. What is driving streaming content purchase decisions? Is it about acquiring as much quality content Netflix can get at fair value, or are the initial viewing trends from subscriber shaping purchasi
componenttext: Next question is from John Blackledge from Credit Suisse. What is driving streaming content purchase decisions? Is it about acquiring as much quality content Netflix can get at fair value, or are the initial viewing trends from subscriber shaping purchasing decision?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The two factors are how much budget we have for streaming content? And then can we get it -- you referred to fair market value, but really, can we just get an agreement of a price that works for us both. And if so, then we do that deal.
componenttext: The two factors are how much budget we have for streaming content? And then can we get it -- you referred to fair market value, but really, can we just get an agreement of a price that works for us both. And if so, then we do that deal.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Ed Williams at BMO. How quickly do you think you might be able to expand outside of Canada into other international markets?
componenttext: Next question is from Ed Williams at BMO. How quickly do you think you might be able to expand outside of Canada into other international markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, we're going to take a look and see how we do in Canada with fewer streaming model, see if we've got the right amount of content, the right marketing approach, and we'll take a look at those results, and then try to figure out what that means for oppor
componenttext: Ed, we're going to take a look and see how we do in Canada with fewer streaming model, see if we've got the right amount of content, the right marketing approach, and we'll take a look at those results, and then try to figure out what that means for opportunity in other countries. So until we get a couple of months after the launch, we're going to be sitting still.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question, can you provide some color on the usage patterns of Watch Instantly, specifically our new subscribers using this service differently than those that have subscribers for a longer period of time. Is there measurable base of subscribers
componenttext: The second question, can you provide some color on the usage patterns of Watch Instantly, specifically our new subscribers using this service differently than those that have subscribers for a longer period of time. Is there measurable base of subscribers who are exclusively using Watch Instantly?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, to the last part, almost everyone takes both DVDs and streaming, and partially that's because the DVDs have all the new releases. So there's a pretty big sector of content there that's DVD only. But in terms of viewing patterns, newer subs, as a class
componenttext: Ed, to the last part, almost everyone takes both DVDs and streaming, and partially that's because the DVDs have all the new releases. So there's a pretty big sector of content there that's DVD only. But in terms of viewing patterns, newer subs, as a class, we are more streaming-centric and partially, it's because when they came to Netflix and established their habits, we have great streaming. Whereas if you joined us five years ago, you're used to us as a DVD business, so of 1,000 people that are with us that joined five years, you get a fewer than our streaming-centric as you do in the new subs. Pretty much as you would expect. The migration, though, is happening in all classes, and it's increasing amongst all classes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Andy Hargreaves from Pacific Crest. Does your increased focus on TV content change conversations with content providers than for this potentially more competitive with their broadcast rightfully at key businesses?
componenttext: Next question from Andy Hargreaves from Pacific Crest. Does your increased focus on TV content change conversations with content providers than for this potentially more competitive with their broadcast rightfully at key businesses?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Andy, it has that potential if we weren't focused on prior season instead of current season. On current season, you do get potential competition with essentially the DVR model, the advertising model, all of those things, but on prior season, we are able t
componenttext: Andy, it has that potential if we weren't focused on prior season instead of current season. On current season, you do get potential competition with essentially the DVR model, the advertising model, all of those things, but on prior season, we are able to create value that wasn't there before and generate incremental profits for the content owner. And so there's not a conflict there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Heath Terry at FBR. Can you break down the components of the increase in SAC, rising add cost, mix of higher value deals or lower response rates to non-bounty deals, TV, radio?
componenttext: Next question from Heath Terry at FBR. Can you break down the components of the increase in SAC, rising add cost, mix of higher value deals or lower response rates to non-bounty deals, TV, radio?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I could, then I'd get skewered by our CMO, so I'm going to take a pass on that. Your walkaway should be that there's nothing that's happening in the marketplace particularly that's increasing our cost of doing business. So the increase in SAC is strictly
componenttext: I could, then I'd get skewered by our CMO, so I'm going to take a pass on that. Your walkaway should be that there's nothing that's happening in the marketplace particularly that's increasing our cost of doing business. So the increase in SAC is strictly a managed outcome. Leslie [Leslie Kilgore] would say, she starts with the lowest cost of subscriber acquisition and then layer on layer, she builds out her acquisition channels and as the budget permits. And there are quarters like Q4 when consumers are very active and the cost of acquisition is relatively low, and there are an abundance of marketing opportunities available to her. It just so happens that Q2 is the slowest quarter by far. And so an aggressive spend in Q2 is a little bit like pushing on a water balloon.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And so, Heath, if we ever drop the marketing budget on a year-over-year basis and have SAC increase, then you could worry about that case kind of what's happening. It's harder to get subs. But when you increase marketing dramatically on a year-over-year b
componenttext: And so, Heath, if we ever drop the marketing budget on a year-over-year basis and have SAC increase, then you could worry about that case kind of what's happening. It's harder to get subs. But when you increase marketing dramatically on a year-over-year basis, as Barry said, depending on how much you increase it, that's what driving the SAC up on the margin.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Nat Schindler of BofA Merrill. With churn ticking up for the first time sequentially in four quarters, admittedly due to seasonality, do you think we are at or near the lowest return on a seasonally adjusted basis? Or over the long term
componenttext: Next question from Nat Schindler of BofA Merrill. With churn ticking up for the first time sequentially in four quarters, admittedly due to seasonality, do you think we are at or near the lowest return on a seasonally adjusted basis? Or over the long term, will continued streaming will just drive this churn even lower?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well some of it is seasonality and some it is growth, right? If we had, had slower growth and new subs churn at a much higher rate than mature subs like a 10% rate versus a 1.5% rate, with slow growth we would have seen slower churn. The question was have
componenttext: Well some of it is seasonality and some it is growth, right? If we had, had slower growth and new subs churn at a much higher rate than mature subs like a 10% rate versus a 1.5% rate, with slow growth we would have seen slower churn. The question was have we seen an all-time low on seasonality? Erin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Could it continue to decline?
componenttext: Could it continue to decline?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. Could churn continue to decline on a seasonal basis, yes. If consumers -- if we continue to improve the overall quality and the service in a way that increases subscriber engagement with the service, then the answer is yes. Certainly in t
componenttext: Yes, I think so. Could churn continue to decline on a seasonal basis, yes. If consumers -- if we continue to improve the overall quality and the service in a way that increases subscriber engagement with the service, then the answer is yes. Certainly in the current competitive environment. If the competitive environment sits dramatically or if we make bad decisions about how to invest in a quality of the service, and we're not successful in increasing engagement, then the trend could reverse, no questions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And Barry, if our sub growth keeps on accelerating, I mean 49%, that could also have an effect on the public churn right here.
componenttext: And Barry, if our sub growth keeps on accelerating, I mean 49%, that could also have an effect on the public churn right here.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, although we are forecasting faster growth and lower churn.
componenttext: Yes, although we are forecasting faster growth and lower churn.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Andy Hargreaves, Pacific Crest. Last quarter you said the goal is to hold second half marketing expense below second half 2009 marketing expense on an absolute basis. Is this still the case?
componenttext: Our last question comes from Andy Hargreaves, Pacific Crest. Last quarter you said the goal is to hold second half marketing expense below second half 2009 marketing expense on an absolute basis. Is this still the case?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Barry and I are looking at each other like, did you say that? I don't think we said that anyway. Going forward, what we're looking at is if we can spend it on content, efficiently, we'll spend it on content. And that would have reduced marketing. If we do
componenttext: Barry and I are looking at each other like, did you say that? I don't think we said that anyway. Going forward, what we're looking at is if we can spend it on content, efficiently, we'll spend it on content. And that would have reduced marketing. If we don't find the right deals, then we'll end up spending it on marketing. So if you add up to some of those marketing plus COGS, that'll say, I mean let's say it's not a consistent part of the P&L, but it's a trade-off between on the margin marketing expense and streaming content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So before we conclude the call, I'd like to just turn it back over to Reed for a few closing remarks.
componenttext: So before we conclude the call, I'd like to just turn it back over to Reed for a few closing remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you all for attending the call, and continue to give us feedback on the format if you like. In general, we've heard that it's more efficient for all of you. And It's quick for us. And I hope that it gets a higher quality of total information out. So
componenttext: Thank you all for attending the call, and continue to give us feedback on the format if you like. In general, we've heard that it's more efficient for all of you. And It's quick for us. And I hope that it gets a higher quality of total information out. So thank you for attending, and we'll talk to you again next quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's program. Thank you for your participation and have a wonderful day. Attendees, you may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's program. Thank you for your participation and have a wonderful day. Attendees, you may now disconnect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Erin Kasenchak, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahea
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Erin Kasenchak, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We release earnings for the second quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. Earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's resu
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We release earnings for the second quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. Earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. 
Like last quarter, this call will consist solely of Q&A, and we are going to conduct this Q&A via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to ir@netflix.com.
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 22, 2010. 
A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific Time today. Before moving in to Q&A, I'd like to turn the call over to Reed for a few opening remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll welcome everyone and let's jump in with the questions. Erin?
componenttext: I'll welcome everyone and let's jump in with the questions. Erin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: First question is from Steve Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Does the recent content deal with Relativity Media signal a material increase in the overall content expenditures or a continuation of the trend of shifting investments from physical to digital?
componenttext: First question is from Steve Frankel at Brigantine Advisors. Does the recent content deal with Relativity Media signal a material increase in the overall content expenditures or a continuation of the trend of shifting investments from physical to digital?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Steven, it's a little of both. We have been investing more in streaming content quarter after quarter, year after year. As we get revenue growth and confirmation that the streaming content investment is a smart one and Relativity does indicate a material
componenttext: Steven, it's a little of both. We have been investing more in streaming content quarter after quarter, year after year. As we get revenue growth and confirmation that the streaming content investment is a smart one and Relativity does indicate a material step up in that, most of that doesn't come in until Relativity delivers the films, so that would be next year and beyond. So it's not a material step up this year through Relativity. But we are out looking for more content and unique to Relativity is that it's completely exclusive for Internet subscription to Netflix. So it's the first of essentially a side shift in our strategy which is due also in light of things [ph]  Exclusive content in addition to non-exclusive content. We don't see a big radical shift. It's just that we're doing some of the content on movies and TV shows exclusively now, which as you know is -- opens new positive  content availability because much of the content in the pay TV window is sold exclusively.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And second question is what is the percentage of subscribers on Blu-ray plan?
componenttext: And second question is what is the percentage of subscribers on Blu-ray plan?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Steven, it's a little over 10%.
componenttext: Steven, it's a little over 10%.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Dave Miller of Caris & Company. Can you confirm whether or not the introduction of the iPad app has resulted in additional subs beyond your expectations or whether the Netflix app has resulted in an already existing subs acquiring the i
componenttext: Next question from Dave Miller of Caris & Company. Can you confirm whether or not the introduction of the iPad app has resulted in additional subs beyond your expectations or whether the Netflix app has resulted in an already existing subs acquiring the iPad?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well Dave, having new platform, whether that's the Wii, the iPad, all the platforms do both. They help us with existing subscribers getting more value from the Netflix service, and they help us attract new subscribers. And the iPad was a big success for u
componenttext: Well Dave, having new platform, whether that's the Wii, the iPad, all the platforms do both. They help us with existing subscribers getting more value from the Netflix service, and they help us attract new subscribers. And the iPad was a big success for us as the Wii was and has really all of our platforms have been.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Youssef Squali at Jefferies & Company. How was the rate of activations on the Wii versus what you have seen for the Xbox in the first 90 days?
componenttext: Next question from Youssef Squali at Jefferies & Company. How was the rate of activations on the Wii versus what you have seen for the Xbox in the first 90 days?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, we don't break out platform specifics, but I would say that we were very happy with Xbox when it came out, and we've been very happy with the PS3, and now we're very happy with the Wii. They all have large install bases. And that's a meaningful w
componenttext: Youssef, we don't break out platform specifics, but I would say that we were very happy with Xbox when it came out, and we've been very happy with the PS3, and now we're very happy with the Wii. They all have large install bases. And that's a meaningful way for our subscribers to get value from our servers and watch great movies and TV shows.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question, is there a subsegment of subscribers who only stream the service and stop ordering DVDs? If so, can you quantify?
componenttext: The second question, is there a subsegment of subscribers who only stream the service and stop ordering DVDs? If so, can you quantify?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The majority of subscribers do both, stream and take DVDs.
componenttext: The majority of subscribers do both, stream and take DVDs.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. Are the marketing expense associated with the Canadian expansion already factored into your operating margin guidance for 2010?
componenttext: Next question from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. Are the marketing expense associated with the Canadian expansion already factored into your operating margin guidance for 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is.
componenttext: Yes, it is.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And what percentage of your CDM partners will support Canadian subscribers?
componenttext: And what percentage of your CDM partners will support Canadian subscribers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Assuming that you meant CDN there, in which case, there's no real issues at Internet, our providers such as Akamai and Limelight and others work hard in Canada.
componenttext: Assuming that you meant CDN there, in which case, there's no real issues at Internet, our providers such as Akamai and Limelight and others work hard in Canada.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. As Netflix gears up to enter the Canadian market and presumably other foreign markets, what is the most significant content delivery challenge facing the company? Do you expect higher-content deliver
componenttext: Next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. As Netflix gears up to enter the Canadian market and presumably other foreign markets, what is the most significant content delivery challenge facing the company? Do you expect higher-content delivery unit costs than you have in the U.S.?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Delivery -- by delivery, one means the cost of streaming, that's a fairly small part of the total picture. So I would say in Canada, the challenge is our licensing, the right content, the right cost, and then taking advantage of the right marketing channe
componenttext: Delivery -- by delivery, one means the cost of streaming, that's a fairly small part of the total picture. So I would say in Canada, the challenge is our licensing, the right content, the right cost, and then taking advantage of the right marketing channels at the right cost. Those are the two primary drivers, the content and the marketing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Dan Ernst at Hudson Square. Questions on accessing rights to digital content for instant watch? Does the size of your subscriber base relative to large cable and satellite carriers factor at all into your ability to gain such rights? An
componenttext: Next question from Dan Ernst at Hudson Square. Questions on accessing rights to digital content for instant watch? Does the size of your subscriber base relative to large cable and satellite carriers factor at all into your ability to gain such rights? And if you will state your top 500 titles across the year, what percentage of those are now available for instant watch?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well let's see, a relative size isn't a direct impact, Dan. It's more the absolute size of our checks. So if the biggest check we can write for a piece of content is $10,000, it's a long shot to get it. If the biggest is $20 million for some piece of cont
componenttext: Well let's see, a relative size isn't a direct impact, Dan. It's more the absolute size of our checks. So if the biggest check we can write for a piece of content is $10,000, it's a long shot to get it. If the biggest is $20 million for some piece of content, we're pretty likely to be outbid anybody else. So it's as you would expect in that way, so there's an indirect influence around our revenue or our content spending budget. The larger that it is, the more effective we can be. And then you ask about the top 500. I'm not sure how to answer that exactly, but I would say that the power of Netflix is to take a lot of content. It may not be the hottest content, and make it feel like it's an incredible service to subscribers. That's where we add value as a service, and that one is nearly carrying the hottest content on the planet. There's not as much of a trough of opportunity in that, because you'd have to pay the content owner, well, the content owner has earned most of the value generated to extract that. So our key is not around top 500, our key is breadth and what percent of our subscribers are streaming. Can we keep them actively streaming? Because if they're actively streaming, and taking DVDs, then they'll retain better. And you can see that in the year-over-year improvements in retention that we generated.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question is related to churn. Churn, a second area of interest is on churn. What are the top two areas a customer goes to instead of Netflix when they leave? Also, of the customers you've added over the last year, what percentage of those have
componenttext: The second question is related to churn. Churn, a second area of interest is on churn. What are the top two areas a customer goes to instead of Netflix when they leave? Also, of the customers you've added over the last year, what percentage of those have been Netflix customers previously?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our rejoin rate is usually around the third, plus or take five points. And on the first part of the question, what's that Erin?
componenttext: Our rejoin rate is usually around the third, plus or take five points. And on the first part of the question, what's that Erin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Where do the top two places that people go when they churn?
componenttext: Where do the top two places that people go when they churn?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: When we ask them, it's a little bit of a choppy answer I could give you, because we ask about movies, where did you get movies from? There's just going to be different answer than the one you get TV shows from, but when you ask where we get movies from, c
componenttext: When we ask them, it's a little bit of a choppy answer I could give you, because we ask about movies, where did you get movies from? There's just going to be different answer than the one you get TV shows from, but when you ask where we get movies from, consumers say that kiosks with $1 rental, that's the big one and it's still rising. Almost everything else is in the noise.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Jeff Rath at Canaccord. Free subscribers, as a percentage of paying subscribers, have reached the highest level ever for Netflix. What's causing this? And how should we expect this to trend for the remainder of 2010?
componenttext: Next question from Jeff Rath at Canaccord. Free subscribers, as a percentage of paying subscribers, have reached the highest level ever for Netflix. What's causing this? And how should we expect this to trend for the remainder of 2010?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's not a huge difference. In general, that's a reflection of our growth rates. So our growth rates, astoundingly, have been moving up all year long, and we expect them to continue to grow and higher growth rate will be associated with a higher rate of f
componenttext: It's not a huge difference. In general, that's a reflection of our growth rates. So our growth rates, astoundingly, have been moving up all year long, and we expect them to continue to grow and higher growth rate will be associated with a higher rate of free trials at any point in time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That's pretty much it. There's this seasonality contributes ever so slightly to the number of revenue in months generated in a quarter, which bears on the mix of both free and paid. Q2 tends to be slightly back-end loaded, Q3 is pretty much flat along thr
componenttext: That's pretty much it. There's this seasonality contributes ever so slightly to the number of revenue in months generated in a quarter, which bears on the mix of both free and paid. Q2 tends to be slightly back-end loaded, Q3 is pretty much flat along through the quarter. Q4 is back-end loaded. But we described the predominant influence which is sub-growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Nat Schindler of BofA Merrill. Dramatic increase in subscriber guidance, up $1.2 million on top and bottom end of guidance for the year end, coupled with limited increase in revenue guidance suggest that you now view ARPU coming down mu
componenttext: Next question from Nat Schindler of BofA Merrill. Dramatic increase in subscriber guidance, up $1.2 million on top and bottom end of guidance for the year end, coupled with limited increase in revenue guidance suggest that you now view ARPU coming down much faster than you did before. What has changed?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, not so much. The only thing that's changed in the business, and it's quite a significant change, is the accelerated growth, and we attribute that to streaming. And streaming implies for 1-out Unlimited price point. So I said on the Q3 call a
componenttext: I would say, not so much. The only thing that's changed in the business, and it's quite a significant change, is the accelerated growth, and we attribute that to streaming. And streaming implies for 1-out Unlimited price point. So I said on the Q3 call a year ago that if prices decline rapidly towards that 1-out Unlimited plan, we'll be very excited. That's great news for the business, because it means that streaming is resonating with consumers and likely, we will see accelerating growth, and in fact we are seeing accelerated growth. So if you're doing a year-over-year comp, it helps to remember that we initiated, in part, of Blu-ray price increase in Q2 a year ago for two months of the quarter and then three months of the quarter in Q3, and so that dampens the effect of the shift towards the 1-out plan. But absent that effect, we're tracking year-over-year, say Q3, Q4, I think will be on par, one to another.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And now we do expect as streaming continues to be successful as it has been for us, that our $8.99 1-U plan will be a larger and larger percentage, both the sign-ups and therefore the installed base. We're not seeing any material migration of the installe
componenttext: And now we do expect as streaming continues to be successful as it has been for us, that our $8.99 1-U plan will be a larger and larger percentage, both the sign-ups and therefore the installed base. We're not seeing any material migration of the installed base. That has stayed pretty constant when people come in on a certain plan, they stay with it. So it's just that new subscribers are predominantly coming in on the unlimited streaming one DVD at a time plan.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to remind everyone that I think the pure indicator of the growth potential of the business is subscriber growth. We've had lots of discussion about ASP over time in its decline. And because of that discussion, we added a metric which was gross prof
componenttext: I want to remind everyone that I think the pure indicator of the growth potential of the business is subscriber growth. We've had lots of discussion about ASP over time in its decline. And because of that discussion, we added a metric which was gross profit per paying sub. And on a year-over-year basis, we actually saw an increase of about $0.30 in that metrics. So even though ASP is going down, and revenues are growing slower than subscribers are growing in terms of gross profit dollar, we were adding more per new sub in Q2 of this year than we did a year ago.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His second question, how do you get visibility into Q4 subscriber growth? Or in other words, how do you get comfortable without quarter guidance?
componenttext: His second question, how do you get visibility into Q4 subscriber growth? Or in other words, how do you get comfortable without quarter guidance?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We have lots of confidence about next week's outcome, declining less ability to be accurate next month and as you point out, declining less ability the following quarter. It's really a continuum. The trend lines that are propelling Netflix is acceleration
componenttext: We have lots of confidence about next week's outcome, declining less ability to be accurate next month and as you point out, declining less ability the following quarter. It's really a continuum. The trend lines that are propelling Netflix is acceleration had been a very steady, strong acceleration since the beginning of the year, at least. And that's what gives us confidence that it's not one short-term aspect. And while we're not able to -- we're choosing not to predict continued acceleration of growth in Q4, that is our model, our expectation and guidance is that growth will remain at a very strong 48%, 49% subscriber growth in Q4. It's because of the continuity and the steadiness of our acceleration to date as opposed to, I'd say, we're banking on CPM rates or some specific aspect of Q4.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Can you update us on our three- to five-year outlook for operating margins?
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Can you update us on our three- to five-year outlook for operating margins?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, by update, that implies, which have not seen that in the past, which I don't believe we have. In general, we would hold the domestic business, we would want that to steadily improve probably at a fairly modest rate, because the top line is expandin
componenttext: Jason, by update, that implies, which have not seen that in the past, which I don't believe we have. In general, we would hold the domestic business, we would want that to steadily improve probably at a fairly modest rate, because the top line is expanding so dramatically. The global operating margin was dependent upon international. And at what rate, it was prudent to invest.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given that the three largest devices, install bases, Xbox, PS3 and Wii have already launched, how should we think about the subscriber contribution from the initial launches versus follow-on contribution
componenttext: Next question from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given that the three largest devices, install bases, Xbox, PS3 and Wii have already launched, how should we think about the subscriber contribution from the initial launches versus follow-on contribution from the existing install base versus incremental growth in the console install base?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, we've been very happy that the Xbox, which is our longest-outstanding device relationship, we continue to see substantial growth in the number of Xbox users and Xbox activations for Netflix. And that's partially because they're continuing to sell m
componenttext: Scott, we've been very happy that the Xbox, which is our longest-outstanding device relationship, we continue to see substantial growth in the number of Xbox users and Xbox activations for Netflix. And that's partially because they're continuing to sell more, new devices into the market at a considerable rate. And it's partially because we are marketing our service to people who include current Xbox owners. So both install bases, Netflix and Xbox, are growing. And from that, we're seeing continued growth. So we look at it, and we think that we will continue to generate substantial growth from all three of the game platforms because all three are growing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: While Netflix may have the scale to aggressively acquire streaming content, availability of content appears limited due to the exclusivity agreements between premium TV networks and most major studio. Are there other buckets of contents similar to Relativ
componenttext: While Netflix may have the scale to aggressively acquire streaming content, availability of content appears limited due to the exclusivity agreements between premium TV networks and most major studio. Are there other buckets of contents similar to Relativity Media but are not tied up in exclusive agreement? Or will Netflix need to pursue another Starz Live distribution deal with the likes of FX or Showtime in order to dramatically expand the content library?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, you want to separate that out between TV shows and movies. So in movies, there's a small number of makers, and as you mentioned, a number of exclusive deals. And so, we are definitely interested in licensing from HBO, from FX, from Showtime. In add
componenttext: Again, you want to separate that out between TV shows and movies. So in movies, there's a small number of makers, and as you mentioned, a number of exclusive deals. And so, we are definitely interested in licensing from HBO, from FX, from Showtime. In addition, there are pockets of content like Relativity. That's all in the movie side. The TV network side, there's a vast array of content and providers, and exclusives are, of the type, that are in movies are much less common, and there's a lot of incremental ability for us to generate new profits for those networks. Because we focus on the prior season, we try to be particularly careful about not conflicting with cable networks, which focus on the newest episode. And we focus on the prior season in generating incremental viewing better than anyone from the prior season viewing. And you will see us continue to expand on that in the coming years.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next questions are from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. There are change in film now from three months ago in terms of shifting sense from marketing content spending. It seems like you are more definitive about the second half content spend increase after Q1
componenttext: Our next questions are from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. There are change in film now from three months ago in terms of shifting sense from marketing content spending. It seems like you are more definitive about the second half content spend increase after Q1 than now?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: There was no intended shift in film, Doug. We expect to significantly increase the spending, streaming in the second half of the year, as compared to the first half of the year, and the first half was a big increase over the second half of the prior year.
componenttext: There was no intended shift in film, Doug. We expect to significantly increase the spending, streaming in the second half of the year, as compared to the first half of the year, and the first half was a big increase over the second half of the prior year. So as the business scales in terms of subscribers, we generate stores with more and more capacity to reallocate spending, and so that's our plan. You're probably referring to the language in my commentary which said that if we're not successful in licensing additional content, then we will spend that money in marketing and grow the sub-growth, and I was kind of inoculated us against creating expectations on the part of investors that in the absence of increased content spending, it would all fall to the bottom line. I didn't want earnings expectations to run away from us. It was another way of reminding folks that earnings is the managed outcome, and we consciously every quarter, make a choice between how much earnings to deliver on the bottom line and how much to invest quarterly in growth either in the form of marketing or making the service better to drive additional foot growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And Doug, I would say, to echo the statement is we've got a consistent strategy which is content gets first ins on the budget, marketing spends what's leftover, and contents try to only buy efficiently. What they don't want to do is send in efficiently. A
componenttext: And Doug, I would say, to echo the statement is we've got a consistent strategy which is content gets first ins on the budget, marketing spends what's leftover, and contents try to only buy efficiently. What they don't want to do is send in efficiently. And so that combination works well. It worked well for us in Q2 and worked well for us the rest of the year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His second question, in deals like Relativity and others, how does the timing of content payments work in terms of cash payments and financial statement recognition? How lumpy our payments here? And when would you start to actively begin talking to Starz
componenttext: His second question, in deals like Relativity and others, how does the timing of content payments work in terms of cash payments and financial statement recognition? How lumpy our payments here? And when would you start to actively begin talking to Starz about renewing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the accounting and cash flow part of the question. Of course, we don't make disclosures on a deal-by-deal basis. But in general, and by way of reminder, if we negotiate a multi-year deal for streamed content, and if we're not able to allocate
componenttext: Let me take the accounting and cash flow part of the question. Of course, we don't make disclosures on a deal-by-deal basis. But in general, and by way of reminder, if we negotiate a multi-year deal for streamed content, and if we're not able to allocate value for the deal to individual titles, then we amortize the cost of the license agreement on a straight-line basis over the term. And cash flow aspects of the deal are each unique to any individual deal and can vary quite a bit, nothing about any of the deals that we've negotiated. They change in a significant way, the cash flow attributes of the business.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And what's the second part?
componenttext: And what's the second part?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: When might you start discussions about the Starz renewal?
componenttext: When might you start discussions about the Starz renewal?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On these Hollywood type deals, they're always in discussions. That never ends. There's no particular time does it begin or end.
componenttext: On these Hollywood type deals, they're always in discussions. That never ends. There's no particular time does it begin or end.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. With the slowdown in growth of DVD shipments, are we at an inflection point where we could start to see DVD shipments growth flatline or even start to decline, I mean really start to take off? Or is this more
componenttext: Next question from Mark Mahaney at Citigroup. With the slowdown in growth of DVD shipments, are we at an inflection point where we could start to see DVD shipments growth flatline or even start to decline, I mean really start to take off? Or is this more of a function of limited content acquired during the quarter that DVD shipments could continue to grow and/or even accelerate?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Mark, DVD shipments are growing. We don't expect them to flatten this year. It's as we said, the growth is less than we thought. So that would imply the peak would be a year earlier than we have thought. We'll know more each quarter on do those tren
componenttext: Well, Mark, DVD shipments are growing. We don't expect them to flatten this year. It's as we said, the growth is less than we thought. So that would imply the peak would be a year earlier than we have thought. We'll know more each quarter on do those trends continue. And yes, there's great news in this which is if churn stays low and DVD shipments grow slower than revenue, then that frees up a lot of money for marketing, for content, both growth-oriented investments or for earnings. So good outcomes in all cases if essentially streaming and substituting for DVD as it seems to be happening for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His next question, you said over the next two quarters you will spend on content and marketing, especially streaming content in order to drive subscriber growth. What metrics will you be looking at in order to determine where you focused your spend? Could
componenttext: His next question, you said over the next two quarters you will spend on content and marketing, especially streaming content in order to drive subscriber growth. What metrics will you be looking at in order to determine where you focused your spend? Could we expect other forms of marketing spend like more TV, print, mobile advertising?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We're very happy with the mix of marketing that we're doing. And if we spent more, you would see us be doing more online and more TV, but no radical changes. It's simply getting more impressions of the great advertising that we've got.
componenttext: We're very happy with the mix of marketing that we're doing. And if we spent more, you would see us be doing more online and more TV, but no radical changes. It's simply getting more impressions of the great advertising that we've got.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from George Askew at Stifel, Nicolaus. You state in your commentary that you see TV shows that's equally important to the franchise as movies. Within the Watch Instantly Library, could you share with us the mix of contents between TV shows a
componenttext: Next question from George Askew at Stifel, Nicolaus. You state in your commentary that you see TV shows that's equally important to the franchise as movies. Within the Watch Instantly Library, could you share with us the mix of contents between TV shows and movies?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: George, we don't break it out, the mix of content. And because TV shows are a smaller unit, you'd get unit viewable, hours of viewing, hours of viewable, all different kinds of measures. But what I can tell you is they're both very big for us and both ver
componenttext: George, we don't break it out, the mix of content. And because TV shows are a smaller unit, you'd get unit viewable, hours of viewing, hours of viewable, all different kinds of measures. But what I can tell you is they're both very big for us and both very substantial. And we continue to expand both on the movie side and on the TV show side.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: His next question is, based on what you know about the Hulu Plus subscription offerings, do you view it as a substitute or as a complement to the Netflix streaming service?
componenttext: His next question is, based on what you know about the Hulu Plus subscription offerings, do you view it as a substitute or as a complement to the Netflix streaming service?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a potential significant competitor, and it is a direct competitor. It's movies and TV shows streaming, so subscription, and we take it seriously as a direct competitor.
componenttext: It's a potential significant competitor, and it is a direct competitor. It's movies and TV shows streaming, so subscription, and we take it seriously as a direct competitor.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Does the Digital Entertainment Content Ecosystem's recent branding campaign and stated goal of rolling out a standard digital platform for new release movies changed Netflix's stand on offering new digi
componenttext: Next question from Ralph Schackart at William Blair. Does the Digital Entertainment Content Ecosystem's recent branding campaign and stated goal of rolling out a standard digital platform for new release movies changed Netflix's stand on offering new digital movies/VOD? If not, what is the rationale given Netflix's membership in the DECE?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've often addressed this topic. We just sort of -- what's our relationship to pay-per-view? And sometimes called download to own, which are two variance, a $4 variance and a $20 variance. And that is that there are many companies in that business:
componenttext: Well, we've often addressed this topic. We just sort of -- what's our relationship to pay-per-view? And sometimes called download to own, which are two variance, a $4 variance and a $20 variance. And that is that there are many companies in that business: Amazon, Apple, Sony, Microsoft, CinemaNow and others. It's well addressed. We don't know how to add any particular value to that space. And we are really focused on subscription, and we've got such a big opportunity in subscription that this year, our growth is accelerating dramatically. And so we don't see any need or desire to expand our available market. We're just very focused on subscription.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Tony Wible of Janney Montgomery Scott. Will Netflix have exclusive access to all of the Relativity films or only the single-production films? Will the joint-production films still go to HBO and Starz?
componenttext: Next question from Tony Wible of Janney Montgomery Scott. Will Netflix have exclusive access to all of the Relativity films or only the single-production films? Will the joint-production films still go to HBO and Starz?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tony, the Relativity does, as you know, a broad range of production and then we did a deal for some of the content, but we're not the sole distribution partner or sole pay TV partner for Relativity-produced films.
componenttext: Tony, the Relativity does, as you know, a broad range of production and then we did a deal for some of the content, but we're not the sole distribution partner or sole pay TV partner for Relativity-produced films.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
