componenttext: Next question is from John Blackledge from Credit Suisse. What is driving streaming content purchase decisions? Is it about acquiring as much quality content Netflix can get at fair value, or are the initial viewing trends from subscriber shaping purchasing decision?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The two factors are how much budget we have for streaming content? And then, can we get it -- you referred to fair market value, but really, can we just get an agreement of a price that works for us both. And if so, then we do that deal.
componenttext: The two factors are how much budget we have for streaming content? And then, can we get it -- you referred to fair market value, but really, can we just get an agreement of a price that works for us both. And if so, then we do that deal.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Ed Williams at BMO. How quickly do you think you might be able to expand outside of Canada into other international markets?
componenttext: Next question is from Ed Williams at BMO. How quickly do you think you might be able to expand outside of Canada into other international markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, we're going to take a look and see how we do in Canada with fewer streaming model, see if we've got the right amount of content, the right marketing approach, and we'll take a look at those results, and then try to figure out what that means for our o
componenttext: Ed, we're going to take a look and see how we do in Canada with fewer streaming model, see if we've got the right amount of content, the right marketing approach, and we'll take a look at those results, and then try to figure out what that means for our opportunity in other countries. So until we get a couple of months after the launch, we're going to be sitting still.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question, can you provide some color on the usage patterns of Watch Instantly, specifically our new subscribers using this service differently than those that have subscribers for a longer period of time. Is there a measurable base of subscribe
componenttext: The second question, can you provide some color on the usage patterns of Watch Instantly, specifically our new subscribers using this service differently than those that have subscribers for a longer period of time. Is there a measurable base of subscribers who are exclusively using Watch Instantly?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, to the last part, almost everyone takes both DVDs and streaming, and partially that's because the DVDs have all the new releases. So there's a pretty big sector of content there that's DVD only. But in terms of viewing patterns, newer subs, as a class
componenttext: Ed, to the last part, almost everyone takes both DVDs and streaming, and partially that's because the DVDs have all the new releases. So there's a pretty big sector of content there that's DVD only. But in terms of viewing patterns, newer subs, as a class are more streaming-centric and partially, is because when they came to Netflix and established their habits, we have great streaming. Whereas if you joined us five years ago, you're used to us as a DVD business, so of 1,000 people that are with us that joined five years, you get a fewer than are streaming-centric as you do in the new subs. Pretty much as you would expect. The migration, though, is happening in all classes, and it's increasing amongst all classes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Jim Friedland from Cowen. Did you ever offer new release titles on a pay-per-view basis on the digital video service?
componenttext: Next question from Jim Friedland from Cowen. Did you ever offer new release titles on a pay-per-view basis on the digital video service?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, you've probably put that question in before I answered it a few minutes ago, so I'll go to the next one.
componenttext: Jim, you've probably put that question in before I answered it a few minutes ago, so I'll go to the next one.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Andy Hargreaves from Pacific Crest. Does your increased focus on TV content change conversations with content providers than for this potentially more competitive with their broadcast or affiliate fee businesses?
componenttext: Next question from Andy Hargreaves from Pacific Crest. Does your increased focus on TV content change conversations with content providers than for this potentially more competitive with their broadcast or affiliate fee businesses?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Andy, what has that potential if we weren't focused on prior season instead of current season. On current season, you do get potential competition with essentially the DVR model, the advertising model, all of those things, but on prior season, we are able
componenttext: Andy, what has that potential if we weren't focused on prior season instead of current season. On current season, you do get potential competition with essentially the DVR model, the advertising model, all of those things, but on prior season, we are able to create value that wasn't there before and generate incremental profits for the content owner. And so there's not a conflict there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Heath Terry at FBR. Can you break down the components of the increase in SAC, rising ad cost, mix of higher bounty deals or lower response rates to non-bounty deals, TV, radio?
componenttext: Next question from Heath Terry at FBR. Can you break down the components of the increase in SAC, rising ad cost, mix of higher bounty deals or lower response rates to non-bounty deals, TV, radio?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I could, then I'd get skewered by our CMO, so I'm going to take a pass on that. Your walkaway should be that there's nothing that's happening in the marketplace particularly that's increasing our cost of doing business. So the increase in SAC is strictly
componenttext: I could, then I'd get skewered by our CMO, so I'm going to take a pass on that. Your walkaway should be that there's nothing that's happening in the marketplace particularly that's increasing our cost of doing business. So the increase in SAC is strictly a managed outcome. Leslie [Leslie Kilgore] would say, she starts with the lowest cost of subscriber acquisition and then layer on layer, she builds out her acquisition channels and as the budget permits. And there are quarters like Q4 when consumers are very active and the cost of acquisition is relatively low, and there are an abundance of marketing opportunities available to her. It just so happens that Q2 is the slowest quarter by far. And so an aggressive spend in Q2 is a little bit like pushing on a water balloon.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And so, Heath, if we ever drop the marketing budget on a year-over-year basis and have SAC increase, then you could worry about that case kind of what's happening. It's harder to get subs. But when you increase marketing dramatically on a year-over-year b
componenttext: And so, Heath, if we ever drop the marketing budget on a year-over-year basis and have SAC increase, then you could worry about that case kind of what's happening. It's harder to get subs. But when you increase marketing dramatically on a year-over-year basis, as Barry said, depending on how much you increase it, that's what driving the SAC up on the margin.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Nat Schindler of BofA Merrill. With churn ticking up for the first time sequentially in four quarters, admittedly due to seasonality, do you think we are at or near the low for churn on a seasonally adjusted basis? Or over the long term
componenttext: Next question from Nat Schindler of BofA Merrill. With churn ticking up for the first time sequentially in four quarters, admittedly due to seasonality, do you think we are at or near the low for churn on a seasonally adjusted basis? Or over the long term, will continued streaming will just drive this churn even lower?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, some of it is seasonality and some of it is growth, right? If we had, had slower growth and new subs churn at a much higher rate than mature subs like a 10% rate versus a 1.5% rate, with slow growth we would have seen slower churn. The question was
componenttext: Well, some of it is seasonality and some of it is growth, right? If we had, had slower growth and new subs churn at a much higher rate than mature subs like a 10% rate versus a 1.5% rate, with slow growth we would have seen slower churn. The question was have we seen an all-time low on seasonality? Erin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Could it continue to decline?
componenttext: Could it continue to decline?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. Could churn continue to decline on a seasonal basis, yes. If consumers -- if we continue to improve the overall quality and the service in a way that increases subscriber engagement with the service, then the answer is yes. Certainly in t
componenttext: Yes, I think so. Could churn continue to decline on a seasonal basis, yes. If consumers -- if we continue to improve the overall quality and the service in a way that increases subscriber engagement with the service, then the answer is yes. Certainly in the current competitive environment. If the competitive environment sits dramatically or if we make bad decisions about how to invest in a quality of the service, and we're not successful in increasing engagement, then the trend could reverse, no questions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And Barry, if our sub growth keeps on accelerating, I mean 49%, that could also have an effect on the public churn right here.
componenttext: And Barry, if our sub growth keeps on accelerating, I mean 49%, that could also have an effect on the public churn right here.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, although we are forecasting faster growth and lower churn.
componenttext: Yes, although we are forecasting faster growth and lower churn.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Andy Hargreaves, Pacific Crest. Last quarter you said the goal is to hold second half marketing expense below second half 2009 marketing expense on an absolute basis. Is this still the case?
componenttext: Our last question comes from Andy Hargreaves, Pacific Crest. Last quarter you said the goal is to hold second half marketing expense below second half 2009 marketing expense on an absolute basis. Is this still the case?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Barry and I are looking at each other like, did you say that? I don't think we said that anyway. Going forward, what we're looking at is if we can spend it on content, efficiently, we'll spend it on content. And that would have reduced marketing. If we do
componenttext: Barry and I are looking at each other like, did you say that? I don't think we said that anyway. Going forward, what we're looking at is if we can spend it on content, efficiently, we'll spend it on content. And that would have reduced marketing. If we don't find the right deals, then we'll end up spending it on marketing. So if you add up to some of those marketing plus COGS, that'll say, I mean let's say it's not a consistent part of the P&L, but it's a trade-off between on the margin marketing expense and streaming content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So before we conclude the call, I'd like to just turn it back over to Reed for a few closing remarks.
componenttext: So before we conclude the call, I'd like to just turn it back over to Reed for a few closing remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Thank you all for attending the call, and continue to give us feedback on the format if you like. In general, we've heard that it's more efficient for all of you. And It's quick for us. And I hope that it gets a higher quality of total information out. So thank you for attending, and we'll talk to you again next quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's program. Thank you for your participation and have a wonderful day. Attendees, you may now disconnect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Netflix's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Netflix's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A SESSION. We released earnings for the third quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A SESSION. We released earnings for the third quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. As is our standard practice, this call will consist solely of Q&A, and we are going to conduct the Q&A via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to ir@netflix.com. 
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 22, 2010. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific Time today. With that, let's begin the Q&A session.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies. How important is exclusivity of content to Netflix when doing digital deal?
componenttext: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies. How important is exclusivity of content to Netflix when doing digital deal?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, it's Reed here. It's not inherently important to, but many of the other buyers are exclusive and uninterested in not exclusive content. So we end up doing exclusive sometimes basically to play with the way the market is today. And there has some
componenttext: Youssef, it's Reed here. It's not inherently important to, but many of the other buyers are exclusive and uninterested in not exclusive content. So we end up doing exclusive sometimes basically to play with the way the market is today. And there has some benefits for us also, but it's not yet a core strategy. Over sufficient number of years, it could become a core strategy but we haven't made that determination.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Youssef. What is the percentage of the subscriber base against Blu-ray today versus one year ago?
componenttext: Second question from Youssef. What is the percentage of the subscriber base against Blu-ray today versus one year ago?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, it's up from the year ago, but it's pretty flat in recent quarters. So still a nice little part of the business and it's fine for us.
componenttext: Youssef, it's up from the year ago, but it's pretty flat in recent quarters. So still a nice little part of the business and it's fine for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray. What are your current thoughts on pricing? I realize you are in grabbing share mode but our opinions as referred to us in churn would not be significantly impacted by a $1 per month price increase, an
componenttext: The next question is from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray. What are your current thoughts on pricing? I realize you are in grabbing share mode but our opinions as referred to us in churn would not be significantly impacted by a $1 per month price increase, and you could argue that higher pricing would allow you to spend more on new content, thereby attracting new sets and reducing churn. How are you thinking about this?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Barry. From previous calls, in response to questions about pricing, we frequently remind our listeners that we're testing all the time and some of you will relatively have some price test in the marketplace currently. Absolutely, the pricing in Canad
componenttext: It's Barry. From previous calls, in response to questions about pricing, we frequently remind our listeners that we're testing all the time and some of you will relatively have some price test in the marketplace currently. Absolutely, the pricing in Canada is working off for us and maybe that will or will not play a role for us in the U.S. And as we continue to retest results, we'll continue to update our thinking about price.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. Would you expect the relatively higher mix of TV show consumption via streaming versus via DVD to continue going forward? Or do you expect it to come down as you build out more movie sele
componenttext: The next question is from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. Would you expect the relatively higher mix of TV show consumption via streaming versus via DVD to continue going forward? Or do you expect it to come down as you build out more movie selections? Is there something about streaming usage that tends to lend itself more to quick TV show consumption?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, I'd say that we're trying to figure out what next consumers want as opposed to trying to guide that, and so we're trying to get a broad selection of content both in movies and in TV shows. And currently, the subscribers are about accusing us in abou
componenttext: Mark, I'd say that we're trying to figure out what next consumers want as opposed to trying to guide that, and so we're trying to get a broad selection of content both in movies and in TV shows. And currently, the subscribers are about accusing us in about equal proportions. And the way we measure is not by stream starts or sessions starts, but by total minutes watched. So movies get a little bit of an advantage in minutes watched because they're longer. But we're not going to try to drive it one way or the other. We're just trying to build out a whole lot of content that our subscribers want to watch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Mark Mahaney. Are your earlier indications that recent free subscribers convert to paying subscribers at the same rate as they have for you historically?
componenttext: Second question from Mark Mahaney. Are your earlier indications that recent free subscribers convert to paying subscribers at the same rate as they have for you historically?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: If the question is the P1 conversion rate holding constant with historical levels, the answer to that question is yes.
componenttext: If the question is the P1 conversion rate holding constant with historical levels, the answer to that question is yes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Steve Frankel at Dougherty [ph] & Company. You commented that the increase in free subscribers was the reflection of both faster U.S. growth and the initial push into Canada. Would you expect free subscribers remain at this highe
componenttext: Our next question is from Steve Frankel at Dougherty [ph] & Company. You commented that the increase in free subscribers was the reflection of both faster U.S. growth and the initial push into Canada. Would you expect free subscribers remain at this higher level relative to the historical norms but will normalized in the next quarter or two?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It may normalize eventually but particularly in Q4, it tends to be seasonally see fast subscriber growth around the holidays, which tends to be back-end loaded and Q1 tends to be front-end loaded. So for at least Q4, that trend likely continues.
componenttext: It may normalize eventually but particularly in Q4, it tends to be seasonally see fast subscriber growth around the holidays, which tends to be back-end loaded and Q1 tends to be front-end loaded. So for at least Q4, that trend likely continues.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Steve Frankel. Can you clarify for me what your current operating margin goals are? And do you anticipate that expansion beyond North American in the back half 2011 would at least in the early going drop operating margins would carry be
componenttext: Next question from Steve Frankel. Can you clarify for me what your current operating margin goals are? And do you anticipate that expansion beyond North American in the back half 2011 would at least in the early going drop operating margins would carry below that level?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you can infer from our guidance forecast for Q4 based on the midpoint of earnings with the operating margin come in for the year roughly 12.5%. So slightly higher than the 12% that we have spoken about. And in Reed's commentary, you know that
componenttext: Yes, I think you can infer from our guidance forecast for Q4 based on the midpoint of earnings with the operating margin come in for the year roughly 12.5%. So slightly higher than the 12% that we have spoken about. And in Reed's commentary, you know that for 2011, we're guiding towards 12% on the North American business. And if we continue to track in Canada on the current trend line to move towards additional investments internationally. In his commentary, Reed spoke about a $50 million of investment to support that expansion.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: One final question from Steve Frankel. Reed commented that the company spent $500 million per year in postage. This is down from the $600 million figure the company has mentioned in the past. Has the increase in streaming already scaled back to postal exp
componenttext: One final question from Steve Frankel. Reed commented that the company spent $500 million per year in postage. This is down from the $600 million figure the company has mentioned in the past. Has the increase in streaming already scaled back to postal expense by that amount?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, no. Postage is still rising. It's between $500 million and $600 million. So my comment in today's script was over $500 million.
componenttext: Steve, no. Postage is still rising. It's between $500 million and $600 million. So my comment in today's script was over $500 million.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Nat Schindler, BofA Merril Lynch. Several years ago when the two-out-at-a-time option was your most popular, Reed said that the average user rented about five DVDs per month on average. Now with the one-at-a-time option becoming domi
componenttext: Next question is from Nat Schindler, BofA Merril Lynch. Several years ago when the two-out-at-a-time option was your most popular, Reed said that the average user rented about five DVDs per month on average. Now with the one-at-a-time option becoming dominant, where has this number gone? Also, have you seen a change to the average DVDs rented by customers as you add additional streaming content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as it relates to DVD usage, we haven't for quite some time reported on the average usage across the base, except to say that it's declined. And there've been two principal drivers. One, of course, is the mix change in the business with the increased
componenttext: Well, as it relates to DVD usage, we haven't for quite some time reported on the average usage across the base, except to say that it's declined. And there've been two principal drivers. One, of course, is the mix change in the business with the increased popularity of one unlimited subscribers. And secondly, it has been the growth in streaming in the substitution behavior. Now having said all of that, regardless of whether it's a three-unlimited, two-unlimited, one-unlimited plan if we booked the usage year-over-year for just DVD, we would see a decrease on average for paying sub.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next questions are from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. First, can you talk about the penetration rate for the Wii?
componenttext: The next questions are from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. First, can you talk about the penetration rate for the Wii?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ryan, it's been very strong with the Wii. It's a very popular device. It's often connected to the living room TV. It's more family-centric than more hard-core gaming consoles, and that's been a great platform for us.
componenttext: Ryan, it's been very strong with the Wii. It's a very popular device. It's often connected to the living room TV. It's more family-centric than more hard-core gaming consoles, and that's been a great platform for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The second question, what is the subscriber count for Canada?
componenttext: The second question, what is the subscriber count for Canada?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll, in Canada, we're not releasing subscriber count. But I can tell you our experience has been great in Canada. We've been hitting and exceeding all of our numbers, and we're on track to be profitable in Canada late next year. So really, just a super
componenttext: We'll, in Canada, we're not releasing subscriber count. But I can tell you our experience has been great in Canada. We've been hitting and exceeding all of our numbers, and we're on track to be profitable in Canada late next year. So really, just a super performance leading up to our high expectations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is question is from Jason Chiu [ph] at AVR Investment Strategy. Would you be willing to offer some color on the video game console opportunity? If an installed base of 75 million consoles PS3, 360 Wii, what's the net subscriber opportunities for Netf
componenttext: That is question is from Jason Chiu [ph] at AVR Investment Strategy. Would you be willing to offer some color on the video game console opportunity? If an installed base of 75 million consoles PS3, 360 Wii, what's the net subscriber opportunities for Netflix? How often can you market to that install base? And what has been net subscriber yield?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, most subscribers will watch content on a multiplicity of devices. They're going to watch on their PC. They'll also watch on an iPhone. They'll watch on the game console. And so don't think of it as a stall that controlled or influenced by a single
componenttext: Jason, most subscribers will watch content on a multiplicity of devices. They're going to watch on their PC. They'll also watch on an iPhone. They'll watch on the game console. And so don't think of it as a stall that controlled or influenced by a single device. Especially with multiple TVs in a household, there'll be a Blu-Ray player in one room that runs Netflix and a video game console in another. That being said, the answer to your question on marketing opportunities, with both PS3 and Xbox were advertised on the screen in various ways, so it's easy for a subscriber to click and get a direct lead to Netflix or get directed to sign up right there on the screen.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one additional question. Are you experiencing an acceleration in net set adds from consoles that now that the new disk is required?
componenttext: Just one additional question. Are you experiencing an acceleration in net set adds from consoles that now that the new disk is required?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That only the no-disk requirement has only lifted three, four days ago. So we're just in the process of rolling that out. We'll be able to comment more on that next quarter.
componenttext: That only the no-disk requirement has only lifted three, four days ago. So we're just in the process of rolling that out. We'll be able to comment more on that next quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next couple of questions are from George Askew at Stifel, Nicolaus. The streaming-only test in the U.S. offers a streaming-only plan $7.99 per month and a streaming plus DVD plan at $9.99 per month. Other than price, is there a difference between the
componenttext: The next couple of questions are from George Askew at Stifel, Nicolaus. The streaming-only test in the U.S. offers a streaming-only plan $7.99 per month and a streaming plus DVD plan at $9.99 per month. Other than price, is there a difference between the $9.99 plan you are testing and the existing $8.99 streaming-plus-DVD plan? Also, if you launch the streaming-only service, does that mean the $8.99 price plan will go away?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: George, that's one test sell of many that you are referring to, which is the $7.99 and $9.99 variants. And to answer you're precise question, the $9.99 in that test cell is the same as the $8.99 today.
componenttext: George, that's one test sell of many that you are referring to, which is the $7.99 and $9.99 variants. And to answer you're precise question, the $9.99 in that test cell is the same as the $8.99 today.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from George Askew. An important drivers growth has been the Consumer Electronics partnership. At this point, with the exception of Android, Netflix seems to on most major connected platforms. What platforms or devices are yet to be penetra
componenttext: Second question from George Askew. An important drivers growth has been the Consumer Electronics partnership. At this point, with the exception of Android, Netflix seems to on most major connected platforms. What platforms or devices are yet to be penetrated by Netflix?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: George, you're right that we had tremendous progress in getting integrated. The big push over the next two years will be as more and more TVs. Our Internet TVs, they have WiFi built-in. And we'll march along with that. But today, there's still a fair amou
componenttext: George, you're right that we had tremendous progress in getting integrated. The big push over the next two years will be as more and more TVs. Our Internet TVs, they have WiFi built-in. And we'll march along with that. But today, there's still a fair amount of TV sold that don't have WiFi. So that's the big push in terms of breadth. And then in terms of quality, we're upgrading the user interfaces in all of these devices, really, at web speed in the search of what the best user interface is for TV, and that will vary somewhat by screen and input device. So we've got a big investment program across all of those platforms.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. How does Netflix can give up the cable service provider? Are they long-term collaborators or adversaries?
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. How does Netflix can give up the cable service provider? Are they long-term collaborators or adversaries?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's two parts to a cable service, or at least three parts: voice, data and video. To the video side, we're mostly competitor except that we're at a very different price point with a very small fraction of their content. That's the analogy I've u
componenttext: Well, there's two parts to a cable service, or at least three parts: voice, data and video. To the video side, we're mostly competitor except that we're at a very different price point with a very small fraction of their content. That's the analogy I've used were the motorcycle on there to car. But on balance, we're competitive. To data, we're huge ally, drives a lot of data adoption, larger plans so very aligned. And voice, no interaction with them.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Among the content available on Watch Instantly, are you seeing greater demand from movies, broadcast, TV shows or pay-TV shows like Showtime? What is the average number of minutes per streaming ses
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Among the content available on Watch Instantly, are you seeing greater demand from movies, broadcast, TV shows or pay-TV shows like Showtime? What is the average number of minutes per streaming session? And do people tend to come back and finish the movie if show is interrupted?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, with the content availability, we don't see greater demand for one or the other. We don't divide it up by broadcast or pay or cable network. We're just looking for great shows that we can license for our subscribers. We don't disclose the average n
componenttext: Jason, with the content availability, we don't see greater demand for one or the other. We don't divide it up by broadcast or pay or cable network. We're just looking for great shows that we can license for our subscribers. We don't disclose the average number of minutes per stream session. And yes, lots of people come back to finish movies and TV shows, so they'll be watching on the television and then they're in the car and they finish on iPod and iTouch or the iPhone and there's all those different -- and they move to a different room and they get to restart and of course, our software are smart enough to restart them in the right place so that all works very well. And you would expect Internet-oriented service to work.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Daniel Ernst at Hudson Square Research. Do you have a sense for what percentage of subscriber are viewing Instant Watch on their television versus a PC?
componenttext: The next question is from Daniel Ernst at Hudson Square Research. Do you have a sense for what percentage of subscriber are viewing Instant Watch on their television versus a PC?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, for us, they're all just screens. There's 4-inch screens that are on mobile phones. There's 9-inch screen on iPad, 12-inch screens on laptops, and then a wide variety of television side screens from 20 to 100 inches. And that's not a key determina
componenttext: Daniel, for us, they're all just screens. There's 4-inch screens that are on mobile phones. There's 9-inch screen on iPad, 12-inch screens on laptops, and then a wide variety of television side screens from 20 to 100 inches. And that's not a key determinant for us. And it's not something that I can give any more color on.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Dan Ernst. Do you have a sense for what percentage of subscribers in the quarter or perhaps year-to-date that are returning subscribers, i.e. previous subscribers who have come back to Netflix?
componenttext: Second question from Dan Ernst. Do you have a sense for what percentage of subscribers in the quarter or perhaps year-to-date that are returning subscribers, i.e. previous subscribers who have come back to Netflix?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, the percentage historically has been running about a third, slightly higher, and the acceleration growth of percentages is following on a little bit.
componenttext: Actually, the percentage historically has been running about a third, slightly higher, and the acceleration growth of percentages is following on a little bit.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Fitzgerald of UBS. How do you think about streaming content cost per user in the future in light of the recent and upcoming content deals? Will it be pretty balanced in terms of streaming content cost being offset by a now
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Fitzgerald of UBS. How do you think about streaming content cost per user in the future in light of the recent and upcoming content deals? Will it be pretty balanced in terms of streaming content cost being offset by a now this postal increases? Where will it be lumpy if certain deals come in or maybe built to its inflection point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's likely to be some lumps. It's not going to be completely smooth. Epic is a great example what where we're stepping forward on that one and that's pressuring the margins in Q4. And as we grow into that over next year, that will smooth out. But in t
componenttext: There's likely to be some lumps. It's not going to be completely smooth. Epic is a great example what where we're stepping forward on that one and that's pressuring the margins in Q4. And as we grow into that over next year, that will smooth out. But in terms of the long-term margin structure, we would like to try to keep it between 30% and 35% gross margin, replacing the postal cost with content cost.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. There are now 200 plus Netflix-enabled products that will result in 60-million-plus devices sold in 2010. Could you give a rough break of percentage that is maybe exclusive and maybe rough estimates of what t
componenttext: Another question from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. There are now 200 plus Netflix-enabled products that will result in 60-million-plus devices sold in 2010. Could you give a rough break of percentage that is maybe exclusive and maybe rough estimates of what these numbers look like for 2011? Any rough spots on TV for set-top boxes versus tables versus the PCs versus mobile phone?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's no material set of devices that are exclusive. Basically with software, it tends to be applications to our architectures. And so none of the devices, there's no material ones that I can think of that are exclusive. In terms of the nu
componenttext: I don't think there's no material set of devices that are exclusive. Basically with software, it tends to be applications to our architectures. And so none of the devices, there's no material ones that I can think of that are exclusive. In terms of the number of devices, that's probably not the relevant thing. The next hundred devices are the hundreds smaller devices than the initial 200. So really it's coverage. Again, that's a big change over the next two years is WiFi getting built into more TVs. And as that happens whether it's got the Google TV software built into it or it's got our native client, both work really well, that's the big change in the industry.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next few questions are from Andy Hargreaves of Pacific Crest. Do any of the content deals you signed give rights for global distribution? Or you have to renegotiate for each geography?
componenttext: The next few questions are from Andy Hargreaves of Pacific Crest. Do any of the content deals you signed give rights for global distribution? Or you have to renegotiate for each geography?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Andy, the general pattern is per geography because it mirrors the other distribution channels.
componenttext: Andy, the general pattern is per geography because it mirrors the other distribution channels.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Andy Hargreaves. Are the majority of the streaming deals you are signing still fixed?
componenttext: Next question from Andy Hargreaves. Are the majority of the streaming deals you are signing still fixed?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Andy, we like to think of them as fixed because they generally are in the short term. But when it comes to renegotiation time, it ends up in some long-term basis, sharing our upside with the content owners as we grow.
componenttext: Well, Andy, we like to think of them as fixed because they generally are in the short term. But when it comes to renegotiation time, it ends up in some long-term basis, sharing our upside with the content owners as we grow.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the final question from Andy Hargreaves of Pacific Crest. Can you explain in more detail the music rights impact? Where and why were you paying $3.5 million from music rights before?
componenttext: And the final question from Andy Hargreaves of Pacific Crest. Can you explain in more detail the music rights impact? Where and why were you paying $3.5 million from music rights before?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure if the question requires an explanation of what music rights are as the public performance rights or the notes in the words associated with the music that's synched in the TV and movie content that we stream over the Internet. There is public
componenttext: I'm not sure if the question requires an explanation of what music rights are as the public performance rights or the notes in the words associated with the music that's synched in the TV and movie content that we stream over the Internet. There is public performance rights required from one of three right societies, ASCAP, SESAC, BMI. Two of those ASCAP and BMI involve rate courts for the setting of rates. Rates are in dispute and so as a consequence, we, through time, have made estimates about that relates to our expectations for license fees associated with the public performance of the music and that get some recent decisions in the courts which have caused us to rethink the amount of money we had set aside for the public performance rates. So it's a monthly accrual. And then eventually when license deals struck, they'll be an exchange of moneys and we'll move on. But right now, it's a hanging accrual in the balance sheet.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And coming back to an earlier question I referred to, starting to target 30% to 35% gross margin of that new content deals replace the postage, and that is true in North America. If we do global aggressively in the short term as we launch, that will be di
componenttext: And coming back to an earlier question I referred to, starting to target 30% to 35% gross margin of that new content deals replace the postage, and that is true in North America. If we do global aggressively in the short term as we launch, that will be different. But the goal statement is true in the long term globally and on an ongoing basis in North America.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord Genuity. Could you talk about the level of adoption or activation levels you're seeing with the variety of web-enabled devices in the marketplace such as web-enabled TVs, Apple products, such as the iPad
componenttext: The next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord Genuity. Could you talk about the level of adoption or activation levels you're seeing with the variety of web-enabled devices in the marketplace such as web-enabled TVs, Apple products, such as the iPad or other product like devices and even gaming consoles? Are mobile handsets becoming a key driver to driving new subscriber activation or just the opportunity remains still relatively early?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wayne, for music services, mobile is the core and then the more living-room based formats are an auxillary. And with the video formats, it's the inverse. So the living-room formats and the laptop formats and iPad formats are quite large. And the mobile, a
componenttext: Wayne, for music services, mobile is the core and then the more living-room based formats are an auxillary. And with the video formats, it's the inverse. So the living-room formats and the laptop formats and iPad formats are quite large. And the mobile, a good supplements, but it's relatively modest.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jim Friedland at Cowen. Regarding Canada streaming, in the comment, you indicated that the Canadian business is on track to breakeven in the second half of next year. Does that imply that your Canadian content deals scale with su
componenttext: The next question is from Jim Friedland at Cowen. Regarding Canada streaming, in the comment, you indicated that the Canadian business is on track to breakeven in the second half of next year. Does that imply that your Canadian content deals scale with subscriber growth? Or are you paying big upfront fees to streaming content regardless of the number of subscribers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, that would be the latter.
componenttext: Jim, that would be the latter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And second question from Jim Friedland at Cowen. With regards to U.S. streaming, do you think the long-term operating margins of a digital-only business are similar to the margins of the business today around 12% flat?
componenttext: And second question from Jim Friedland at Cowen. With regards to U.S. streaming, do you think the long-term operating margins of a digital-only business are similar to the margins of the business today around 12% flat?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The long-term margins are really driven by competition because that really influences the pricing. So you'd have to tell me what the competitive environment is to get what the long-term operating margins are. It will be again significantly influenced by t
componenttext: The long-term margins are really driven by competition because that really influences the pricing. So you'd have to tell me what the competitive environment is to get what the long-term operating margins are. It will be again significantly influenced by the amount of competition. And at this point, we don't know what that will be.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from John Blackledge of Crdit Suisse. What was changed in these shipments per sub per month in Q3 2010 on a year-over-year basis? I think in Q2 2010, these shipments were down about 20% year-over-year. Just wondering if you would ex
componenttext: The next question is from John Blackledge of Crdit Suisse. What was changed in these shipments per sub per month in Q3 2010 on a year-over-year basis? I think in Q2 2010, these shipments were down about 20% year-over-year. Just wondering if you would expect the decline to accelerate in the near term or stay around Q2, Q3 levels.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, as I said and an answer to an earlier question, we're not breaking out the disk usage per sub per month. I think the only color commentary we gave was in Reed's remarks, and pointed he out that total shipments had grown on a year-over-year basis by
componenttext: John, as I said and an answer to an earlier question, we're not breaking out the disk usage per sub per month. I think the only color commentary we gave was in Reed's remarks, and pointed he out that total shipments had grown on a year-over-year basis by about 10%.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard Capital Market. Impact on other forms of entertainment consumption, are you beyond total network Watch Instantly on the iPad? For that reason, we're not inclined to buy more case DVDs. They get more than
componenttext: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard Capital Market. Impact on other forms of entertainment consumption, are you beyond total network Watch Instantly on the iPad? For that reason, we're not inclined to buy more case DVDs. They get more than enough content from the Pixar and Disney movies and PBX stick so as on Netflix. Are there other Netflix subscribers like it? Do you see any evidence that people are buying fewer DVDs as they stream more Netflix content? Could you also update us on the cord-cutting question? Do you still profess to see no evidence that Netflix subscribers are cutting the cord?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the latter part on cord cutting, we still see no evidence that sub cut cords at greater rates for the general population. And it's something we're sure they're on Now and Then on. On your personal experience, it's all over the map. We have tons of anec
componenttext: On the latter part on cord cutting, we still see no evidence that sub cut cords at greater rates for the general population. And it's something we're sure they're on Now and Then on. On your personal experience, it's all over the map. We have tons of anecdotes of people the streaming stimulates their usage in other format, others for home, like you said, that streaming meets most of their entertainment need. So quite a lot of variety with 70 million members.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next two questions are from Michael Pachter at Wedbush. The press release says that in Q4, a majority of Netflix's subscribers will watch more content streamed from Netflix than delivered on DVD. There's "more content" in more hours of content or a gr
componenttext: The next two questions are from Michael Pachter at Wedbush. The press release says that in Q4, a majority of Netflix's subscribers will watch more content streamed from Netflix than delivered on DVD. There's "more content" in more hours of content or a greater number of streaming sessions than DVD transaction.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, that's not more hours. We're measuring everything to combine it by the hours.
componenttext: Michael, that's not more hours. We're measuring everything to combine it by the hours.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Michael Pachter. Also, the following that consist that the business will have transitioned from mostly DVDs to mostly streaming. If more than 50% of users consume more than 50% of their content via streaming, I can see how you could s
componenttext: Second question from Michael Pachter. Also, the following that consist that the business will have transitioned from mostly DVDs to mostly streaming. If more than 50% of users consume more than 50% of their content via streaming, I can see how you could say mostly streaming for those customers. But I presume that the 34% of customers who don't use streaming get 100% of their content via DVD, so I don't see how you conclude that more than 50% of content is streaming. Would you please clarify what you're talking about and give us the split in terms of hours spent? It really doesn't make sense and the second sentence in price that over half of all hours spent are spent watching streaming but the metric you provide don't support that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's just a math question here, Michael. We track how many DVDs we shipped and we track that one length, and we make an assumption that each DVD is watched once. So you could take some are never watched and some are watched twice, but we assume watched on
componenttext: It's just a math question here, Michael. We track how many DVDs we shipped and we track that one length, and we make an assumption that each DVD is watched once. So you could take some are never watched and some are watched twice, but we assume watched once. And then we look at the streaming hours that we're delivering and compare those. So we're seeing two things which are independent. One is that the total number of minutes of entertainment delivered by Netflix is higher on streaming than on DVD. Second, majority of our members are more than 50% in Q4 will watch a majority of their content by minute on streaming than on DVD, which basically gets you a distribution measure. It says that it's not that say, 10% of the streamers are watching an enormous amount of content and everyone else is majority DVD. So it's two views. Total view were more streaming and from a subscriber view, the majority of our subscribers, consumer majority of their content on streamings and DVD.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Doug Mitchelson at Deutsche Bank Security. How much of your churn comes from subscribers that are on free promotion? Asked another way, how low is your churn rate on core Netflix subscribers? Say those two have been subscribers f
componenttext: The next question is from Doug Mitchelson at Deutsche Bank Security. How much of your churn comes from subscribers that are on free promotion? Asked another way, how low is your churn rate on core Netflix subscribers? Say those two have been subscribers for over three months or six months or one year, however, you measure it. The obvious reason for the question is we do not typically see consumer subscriber businesses grow so fast while sustaining such a high churn rate. It should settle down to a lower level to the extent you are offering a good price value.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Barry, let me tackle that question. We don't normally see subscriber growth business grow this fast. So there are two cohorts essentially to focus on with respect to churn to the free trials subscribers as you referred to. And we see slightly lowe
componenttext: This is Barry, let me tackle that question. We don't normally see subscriber growth business grow this fast. So there are two cohorts essentially to focus on with respect to churn to the free trials subscribers as you referred to. And we see slightly lower -- well, we anticipate we are seeing slightly lower conversion rates in Canada and mix in the U.S. So let me just focus on the U.S. where we have a rich history. And we said repeatedly through time and it remains true today, but that nine and 10 subscribers who take a free trial become a paying subscriber. So great conversion rate, but that implies one in 10 free trial subscribers dropout, that's a 10% churn rate. So point one, as it relates to the paying subscribers, a churn declines over time. And if you'd been here for 12 months or longer and more than half of subscribers have been here for more than 12 months, then your churn rate is in the 2% range or lower. So not terribly dissimilar from churn rates for basic cable, which is in the 1.5% range. And of course, whether or not that churn rate is sustainable from a financial perspective, also depends on what the acquisition cost is. And of course, we're at historical low acquisition cost because of investment we've made in improving the quality service and streaming. And then I suppose the follow-up question might be well, how does retention rate for streaming customers compare with retention rates on DVD-only customers? And because of the improvements we've made in the quarter with streaming service, we're going to have to say that actually retention for streaming customers has just crossed over the retention for DVD-only customers, so it's actually better now for streaming only. And that's important, of course, because the majority of the growth is streaming related.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Edward Williams at BMO. Has subscriber growth has grown due to streaming? How has that demographics of Netflix subscriber changed?
componenttext: The next question is from Edward Williams at BMO. Has subscriber growth has grown due to streaming? How has that demographics of Netflix subscriber changed?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not significantly. We're still pretty much the broad Internet demographic has credit card.
componenttext: Not significantly. We're still pretty much the broad Internet demographic has credit card.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next couple of questions are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given the number of deals you made on the content side in Q3, are you still seeing opportunities to continue to aggressively invest in digital content?
componenttext: The next couple of questions are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given the number of deals you made on the content side in Q3, are you still seeing opportunities to continue to aggressively invest in digital content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, we're pretty spent up for Q4 that we're three weeks into the quarter already. So that probably makes sense. And we have a lot of opportunity next year as the subscriber base continues to grow.
componenttext: Scott, we're pretty spent up for Q4 that we're three weeks into the quarter already. So that probably makes sense. And we have a lot of opportunity next year as the subscriber base continues to grow.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Scott Devitt. With the rollout of the new Disc-Free applications on Wii and PS3, you seem to be focusing a lot on reducing friction, improving the user interface and increasing search functionality. Are there any other areas you hope
componenttext: Second question from Scott Devitt. With the rollout of the new Disc-Free applications on Wii and PS3, you seem to be focusing a lot on reducing friction, improving the user interface and increasing search functionality. Are there any other areas you hope to focus on in order to differentiate your streaming products from other video applications from a technology standpoint?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not particularly, Scott. I would say that any technology advantage quickly gets copied. So we try to do great work, and we're improving the UI, but obviously, all the great work that we do there will be quickly copied within a year or two by anybody who w
componenttext: Not particularly, Scott. I would say that any technology advantage quickly gets copied. So we try to do great work, and we're improving the UI, but obviously, all the great work that we do there will be quickly copied within a year or two by anybody who wants to.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That next question are from Eric Wold at MCF. In the prepared remarks, you state that Q4 will experience year-over-year reductions in marketing spending. Are you referring to the overall dollar amount or SAC?
componenttext: That next question are from Eric Wold at MCF. In the prepared remarks, you state that Q4 will experience year-over-year reductions in marketing spending. Are you referring to the overall dollar amount or SAC?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Both.
componenttext: Both.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Eric Wold. The DVD shipments continued to flow or even decline in certain markets like the Bay Area. At what point would you consider closing distribution centers or is there always need to stay in place for the next day delivery bene
componenttext: Second question from Eric Wold. The DVD shipments continued to flow or even decline in certain markets like the Bay Area. At what point would you consider closing distribution centers or is there always need to stay in place for the next day delivery benefit?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mostly the latter, Eric. Over a sufficient number of years, the volumes come down by 50%. There might be some small closures probably many, many years out.
componenttext: Mostly the latter, Eric. Over a sufficient number of years, the volumes come down by 50%. There might be some small closures probably many, many years out.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Do you believe MSOs will move to usage base billing as part of the FCC debate over title's theory? Do you see an opportunity to use compression technique and minimize bandwidth if that is th
componenttext: The next question is from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Do you believe MSOs will move to usage base billing as part of the FCC debate over title's theory? Do you see an opportunity to use compression technique and minimize bandwidth if that is the case?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a key question, Tony, and a good one. We have some vulnerability depending on cap usage and what happens. Comcast has a cap but it's 250 gigabytes, and so most users feel that they have unlimited experience and it gives us plenty of room to deliver a
componenttext: It's a key question, Tony, and a good one. We have some vulnerability depending on cap usage and what happens. Comcast has a cap but it's 250 gigabytes, and so most users feel that they have unlimited experience and it gives us plenty of room to deliver a high-def stream. On the other hand, AT&T mobile data on an iPad is now capped to two gigabytes. So not enough room to deliver hours and hours of high def. There's not a lot of improvement in compression techniques, but what we can do is just deliver a lower bit stream, a lower quality video experience. So, for example, not too high def. So that's one possible way to partially mitigate that impact. But we're definitely sensitive, as you pointed out, to -- in the long term, just most of the industry end up at 250 gigabyte or two with the other extreme.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Arthur Mangriotis [ph] at Fox Point Capital. Please elaborate on your comment that the international competitive window will only be opened temporarily.
componenttext: The next question is from Arthur Mangriotis [ph] at Fox Point Capital. Please elaborate on your comment that the international competitive window will only be opened temporarily.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Arthur, broadband is growing rapidly across the world, and that creates an opportunity for us and potentially for others. And five or 10 years from now, you'd have to believe that if we're not, there are other people will be. So that's what we're re
componenttext: Well, Arthur, broadband is growing rapidly across the world, and that creates an opportunity for us and potentially for others. And five or 10 years from now, you'd have to believe that if we're not, there are other people will be. So that's what we're referring to.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That next question is from Dough Anmuth at Barclays. Is stock down more because you deliberately push marketing dollars toward content cost or as a result of the some subscriber growth, i.e. if you go into the quarter and tending to spend a bit less on ac
componenttext: That next question is from Dough Anmuth at Barclays. Is stock down more because you deliberately push marketing dollars toward content cost or as a result of the some subscriber growth, i.e. if you go into the quarter and tending to spend a bit less on acquisition?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We spent to our plan. Marketing spending as a percent of revenue was up slightly on Q-over-Q basis on a year-over-year basis. And the decrease in SAC reflects the increase in the organic growth, which is a function of the increase investment we'll be maki
componenttext: We spent to our plan. Marketing spending as a percent of revenue was up slightly on Q-over-Q basis on a year-over-year basis. And the decrease in SAC reflects the increase in the organic growth, which is a function of the increase investment we'll be making in the licensing of stream content. So historically, you have heard me talk about in a relationship between gross margin SAC and churn and the way in which we play one-off against the other in order to increase the overall growth rate and enterprise value associated with the growth in subscribers. And that's what you see it play here.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as Barry mentioned in his written comments as part of absorbing the FX lump, the spending lighter on marketing and Q4 than historically we would, and that will have different lower gross margins and lower SAC than we're use to seeing from us.
componenttext: And as Barry mentioned in his written comments as part of absorbing the FX lump, the spending lighter on marketing and Q4 than historically we would, and that will have different lower gross margins and lower SAC than we're use to seeing from us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. What are you doing differently in terms of distribution centers as we prepare for overall disc business to decline? I know your focus on continued automation and efficiency, but you have broader plans yet on
componenttext: Another question from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. What are you doing differently in terms of distribution centers as we prepare for overall disc business to decline? I know your focus on continued automation and efficiency, but you have broader plans yet on how you'll ultimately scale back these facilities over time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Nationwide, our DVD shipments are still growing about 10% year-over-year. So right now, we're trying to figure out how to handle the increase load and get our new automation deployed quickly. So I'm sure someday, we'll have to think about the issues you r
componenttext: Nationwide, our DVD shipments are still growing about 10% year-over-year. So right now, we're trying to figure out how to handle the increase load and get our new automation deployed quickly. So I'm sure someday, we'll have to think about the issues you referred to but not in the near term.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question from Michael Olson at Piper Jaffray. Question for Barry. With your comment in the prepared remarks regarding Q4 guidance where you say year-over-year reductions in marketing spending will mostly from the increased content spending because
componenttext: Another question from Michael Olson at Piper Jaffray. Question for Barry. With your comment in the prepared remarks regarding Q4 guidance where you say year-over-year reductions in marketing spending will mostly from the increased content spending because it keep the marketing spend on a dollar basis will be down year-over-year in Q4, or are you saying it will be down year-over-year as a percentage of revenue?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It will be down as a percentage of revenue, and it will be down Q-over-Q.
componenttext: It will be down as a percentage of revenue, and it will be down Q-over-Q.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Doug Robinson, a private investor. When will be Android cellphone be supported for streaming app?
componenttext: The next question is from Doug Robinson, a private investor. When will be Android cellphone be supported for streaming app?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're watching on Android now. And as soon as we have something to announce, we'll announce that.
componenttext: We're watching on Android now. And as soon as we have something to announce, we'll announce that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd like to supplement my previous answers as it relates to marketing spending. It can make a slightly different point. I want to remind everyone on the call that earnings is a managed outcome. And so there had been many quarters in the past, by way of ex
componenttext: I'd like to supplement my previous answers as it relates to marketing spending. It can make a slightly different point. I want to remind everyone on the call that earnings is a managed outcome. And so there had been many quarters in the past, by way of example, to support quarter of last year, if memory serves me, during the quarter, because the business was much more profitable than we forecast, it were going to be -- we allocated during the quarter an additional spending to marketing in something like $6 million. We delivered earnings that where we'd forecast we were going to deliver and we will able to deliver more growth in part because we hurdled and invest in more marketing dollars. So if as Q4 unfolds similar dynamic occurs relative to our forecast, and we have the wind in our back and we would be anxious to invest additional money in marketing because it will further accelerate our growth. But based on our plan, we're expecting the answer I gave which is an decrease both on a percentage basis and a decrease Q-over-Q in terms of absolute dollars spent on marketing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question from Barton Crockett at Lazard with to the Starz deal. Starz received net of sales fees of close to $2 per subscriber per month while providing its flagship Starz on core package to cable. In my observation, the line up of Starz content o
componenttext: Another question from Barton Crockett at Lazard with to the Starz deal. Starz received net of sales fees of close to $2 per subscriber per month while providing its flagship Starz on core package to cable. In my observation, the line up of Starz content on Netflix is better than on cable into more title availability, easier navigation, et cetera. In your renewal talks with Starz, is it conceivable that Netflix to pay rate per Starz content comparable to what cable pay? Can you comment generally on your optimism or skepticism about the successful renewal of the Starz deal?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, I can't comment on the specifics. And I'm optimistic in the long term that is we have money to pay, and they're in the business of collecting money. So there's no reason in the long term strategically it shouldn't work out. How soon and w
componenttext: Well, obviously, I can't comment on the specifics. And I'm optimistic in the long term that is we have money to pay, and they're in the business of collecting money. So there's no reason in the long term strategically it shouldn't work out. How soon and whether hiccups along the way, I'd like see in so many content-supplier relationship that's DVD. But with the breadth of our content offered, we'll be fine and just look forward to working on that deal.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Final question. It's from Michael Pachter at Wedbush. Since postage hasn't decline precipitously, you're really saying that overall consumption of it entertainment is up a lot, DVD usage a little and streaming up a lot. That's a high cost problem and cons
componenttext: Final question. It's from Michael Pachter at Wedbush. Since postage hasn't decline precipitously, you're really saying that overall consumption of it entertainment is up a lot, DVD usage a little and streaming up a lot. That's a high cost problem and consist a higher value proposition. Could you confirm that I'm reading the response correctly?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the only thing that I heard in that question was the DVD down, but DVD is actually up. It emphasizes your theme that DVD is growing slowly for a DVD shipment and streaming is growing rapidly. But I'm not sure if I heard the question.
componenttext: Well, the only thing that I heard in that question was the DVD down, but DVD is actually up. It emphasizes your theme that DVD is growing slowly for a DVD shipment and streaming is growing rapidly. But I'm not sure if I heard the question.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's right. That was the question. Do you really think an overall consumption is up a lot? So usage per sub down a little and streaming up a lot. Is DVD usage on a per sub-basis down?
componenttext: That's right. That was the question. Do you really think an overall consumption is up a lot? So usage per sub down a little and streaming up a lot. Is DVD usage on a per sub-basis down?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a 50% sub growth and probably 10% shipment growth.
componenttext: That's a 50% sub growth and probably 10% shipment growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the question is on a per sub basis, are you seeing greater consumption? Are you seeing greater consumption as entertainment? And I think the answer to that is yes. So said differently, subscribers are extracting more value from the service than th
componenttext: I think the question is on a per sub basis, are you seeing greater consumption? Are you seeing greater consumption as entertainment? And I think the answer to that is yes. So said differently, subscribers are extracting more value from the service than they have historically, which I think explains in part one the increased organic growth and the decline in subscriber acquisition cost and to the continued decrease in churn.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's the last question I have. Before we conclude the call, I'd like to turn this call back over to Reed for a few brief closing remarks.
componenttext: That's the last question I have. Before we conclude the call, I'd like to turn this call back over to Reed for a few brief closing remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us today. Hopefully, we answered all your questions efficiently. There's a lot to talk about this quarter. The year-over-year subscriber growth at 52% is accelerating, more content, more device partnerships, our entry in Canada. And by
componenttext: Thanks for joining us today. Hopefully, we answered all your questions efficiently. There's a lot to talk about this quarter. The year-over-year subscriber growth at 52% is accelerating, more content, more device partnerships, our entry in Canada. And by any measure, our evolution to a streaming company has just been phenomenal. I think you'll see that evolution even more clearly when we report our fourth quarter results and look forward to talking with you then. Thank you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, everyone.
componenttext: Thanks, everyone.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation on today's conference. This does conclude the program, and you may now disconnect.
