componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation on today's conference. This does conclude the program, and you may now disconnect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Netflix's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Netflix's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix third quarter 2010 earnings Q&A session. We released earnings for the third quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's r
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix third quarter 2010 earnings Q&A session. We released earnings for the third quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. As is our standard practice, this call will consist solely of Q&A, and we are going to conduct the Q&A via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to ir@netflix.com. 
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 22, 2010. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific Time today. With that, let's begin the Q&A session.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies. How important is exclusivity of content to Netflix when doing digital deals?
componenttext: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies. How important is exclusivity of content to Netflix when doing digital deals?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, it's Reed here. It's not inherently important to us, but many of the other buyers are exclusive and uninterested in not exclusive content. So we end up doing exclusive sometimes basically to play with the way the market is today. And that has som
componenttext: Youssef, it's Reed here. It's not inherently important to us, but many of the other buyers are exclusive and uninterested in not exclusive content. So we end up doing exclusive sometimes basically to play with the way the market is today. And that has some benefits for us also, but it's not yet a core strategy. Over sufficient number of years, it could become a core strategy but we haven't made that determination.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Youssef. What is the percentage of the subscriber base against Blu-ray today versus one year ago?
componenttext: Second question from Youssef. What is the percentage of the subscriber base against Blu-ray today versus one year ago?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, it's up from a year ago, but it's pretty flat in recent quarters. So still a nice little part of the business and it's fine for us.
componenttext: Youssef, it's up from a year ago, but it's pretty flat in recent quarters. So still a nice little part of the business and it's fine for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray. What are your current thoughts on pricing? I realize you are in grabbing share mode but our opinion is that growth adds and churn would not be significantly impacted by a $1 per month price increase,
componenttext: The next question is from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray. What are your current thoughts on pricing? I realize you are in grabbing share mode but our opinion is that growth adds and churn would not be significantly impacted by a $1 per month price increase, and you could argue that higher pricing would allow you to spend more on new content, thereby attracting new sets and reducing churn. How are you thinking about this?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Barry. From previous calls, in response to questions about pricing, we frequently remind our listeners that we're testing all the time and some of you will observe that we have some price tests in the marketplace currently. Actually, the pricing in C
componenttext: It's Barry. From previous calls, in response to questions about pricing, we frequently remind our listeners that we're testing all the time and some of you will observe that we have some price tests in the marketplace currently. Actually, the pricing in Canada is working well for us and maybe that will or will not play a role for us in the U.S. And as we continue to read test results, we'll continue to update our thinking about price.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. Would you expect the relatively higher mix of TV show consumption via streaming versus via DVD to continue going forward? Or do you expect it to come down as you build out more movie sele
componenttext: The next question is from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. Would you expect the relatively higher mix of TV show consumption via streaming versus via DVD to continue going forward? Or do you expect it to come down as you build out more movie selections? Is there something about streaming usage that tends to lend itself more to quick TV show consumption?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, I'd say that we're trying to figure out what next consumers want as opposed to trying to guide that, and so we're trying to get a broad selection of content both in movies and in TV shows. And currently, the subscribers are using us in about equal p
componenttext: Mark, I'd say that we're trying to figure out what next consumers want as opposed to trying to guide that, and so we're trying to get a broad selection of content both in movies and in TV shows. And currently, the subscribers are using us in about equal proportions. And the way we measure is not by stream starts or session starts, but by total minutes watched. So movies get a little bit of an advantage in minutes watched because they're longer. But we're not trying to drive it one way or the other. We're just trying to build out a whole lot of content that our subscribers want to watch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Mark Mahaney. Are your earlier indications that recent free subscribers convert to paid subscribers at the same rate as they have for you historically?
componenttext: Second question from Mark Mahaney. Are your earlier indications that recent free subscribers convert to paid subscribers at the same rate as they have for you historically?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: If the question is the P1 conversion rate holding constant with historical levels, the answer to that question is yes.
componenttext: If the question is the P1 conversion rate holding constant with historical levels, the answer to that question is yes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Steve Frankel at Dougherty [ph] & Company. You commented that the increase in free subscribers was the reflection of both faster U.S. growth and the initial push into Canada. Would you expect free subs to remain at this higher le
componenttext: Our next question is from Steve Frankel at Dougherty [ph] & Company. You commented that the increase in free subscribers was the reflection of both faster U.S. growth and the initial push into Canada. Would you expect free subs to remain at this higher level relative to the historical norms but will it normalized in the next quarter or two?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It may normalize eventually but particularly in Q4, it tends to be seasonally see fast subscriber growth around the holidays, which tends to be back-end loaded and Q1 tends to be front-end loaded. So for at least Q4, that trend likely continues.
componenttext: It may normalize eventually but particularly in Q4, it tends to be seasonally see fast subscriber growth around the holidays, which tends to be back-end loaded and Q1 tends to be front-end loaded. So for at least Q4, that trend likely continues.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Steve Frankel. Can you clarify for me what your current operating margin goals are? And do you anticipate that expansion beyond North America in the back half 2011 would at least in the early goings drop operating margins materially bel
componenttext: Next question from Steve Frankel. Can you clarify for me what your current operating margin goals are? And do you anticipate that expansion beyond North America in the back half 2011 would at least in the early goings drop operating margins materially below that level?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you can infer from our guidance forecast for Q4 based on the midpoint of earnings with the operating margin come in for the year roughly 12.5%. So slightly higher than the 12% that we have spoken about. And in Reed's commentary, you know that
componenttext: Yes, I think you can infer from our guidance forecast for Q4 based on the midpoint of earnings with the operating margin come in for the year roughly 12.5%. So slightly higher than the 12% that we have spoken about. And in Reed's commentary, you know that for 2011, we're guiding towards 12% on the North American business. And if we continue to track in Canada on the current trend line to move towards additional investments internationally. And in his commentary, Reed spoke about a $50 million investment to support that expansion.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: One final question from Steve Frankel. Reed commented that the company spent $500 million per year in postage. This is down from the $600 million figure the company has mentioned in the past. Has the increase in streaming already scaled back the postal ex
componenttext: One final question from Steve Frankel. Reed commented that the company spent $500 million per year in postage. This is down from the $600 million figure the company has mentioned in the past. Has the increase in streaming already scaled back the postal expense by that amount?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, no. Postage is still rising. It's between $500 million and $600 million. So my comment in today's script was over $500 million.
componenttext: Steve, no. Postage is still rising. It's between $500 million and $600 million. So my comment in today's script was over $500 million.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Nat Schindler, BofA Merrill Lynch. Several years ago when the two-out-at-a-time option was your most popular, Reed said that the average user rented about five DVDs per month on average. Now with the one-at-a-time option becoming dom
componenttext: Next question is from Nat Schindler, BofA Merrill Lynch. Several years ago when the two-out-at-a-time option was your most popular, Reed said that the average user rented about five DVDs per month on average. Now with the one-at-a-time option becoming dominant, where has this number gone? Also, have you seen a change to the average DVDs rented by customers as you add additional streaming content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as it relates to DVD usage, we haven't for quite some time reported on the average usage across the base, except to say that it's declined. And there've been two principal drivers. One, of course, is the mix change in the business with the increased
componenttext: Well, as it relates to DVD usage, we haven't for quite some time reported on the average usage across the base, except to say that it's declined. And there've been two principal drivers. One, of course, is the mix change in the business with the increased popularity of one unlimited subscribers. And secondly, has been the growth in streaming in the substitution behavior. Now having said all of that, regardless of whether it's a three-unlimited, two-unlimited, one-unlimited plan if we looked at usage year-over-year for just DVD, we would see a decrease on average for paying sub.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next questions are from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. First, can you talk about the penetration rate for the Wii?
componenttext: The next questions are from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. First, can you talk about the penetration rate for the Wii?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ryan, it's been very strong with the Wii. It's a very popular device. It's often connected to the living room TV. It's more family-centric than the more hard-core gaming consoles, and that's been a great platform for us.
componenttext: Ryan, it's been very strong with the Wii. It's a very popular device. It's often connected to the living room TV. It's more family-centric than the more hard-core gaming consoles, and that's been a great platform for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The second question. What is the subscriber count for Canada?
componenttext: The second question. What is the subscriber count for Canada?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in Canada, we're not releasing subscriber count. What I can tell you our experience has been great in Canada. We've been hitting and exceeding all of our numbers, and we're on track to be profitable in Canada late next year. So really, just a super
componenttext: Well, in Canada, we're not releasing subscriber count. What I can tell you our experience has been great in Canada. We've been hitting and exceeding all of our numbers, and we're on track to be profitable in Canada late next year. So really, just a super performance leading up to our high expectations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Chiu [ph] at AVR Investment Strategy. Would you be willing to offer some color on the video game console opportunity? If an installed base of 75 million consoles PS3, 360 Wii, what's the net subscriber opportunities for Net
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Chiu [ph] at AVR Investment Strategy. Would you be willing to offer some color on the video game console opportunity? If an installed base of 75 million consoles PS3, 360 Wii, what's the net subscriber opportunities for Netflix? How often can you market to that install base? And what has been the net subscriber yield?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, most subscribers will watch content on a multiplicity of devices. So theyll watch on their PC. They'll also watch on an iPhone. They'll watch on a game console. And so don't think of it as a sub that controlled or influenced by a single device.
componenttext: Jason, most subscribers will watch content on a multiplicity of devices. So theyll watch on their PC. They'll also watch on an iPhone. They'll watch on a game console. And so don't think of it as a sub that controlled or influenced by a single device. Especially with multiple TVs in a household, there'll be a Blu-Ray player in one room that runs Netflix and a video game console in another. That being said, the answer to your question on marketing opportunities, with both PS3 and Xbox were advertised on the screen in various ways, so it's easy for a subscriber to click and get a direct lead to Netflix or get directed to sign up right there on the screen.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: He had one additional question. Are you experiencing an acceleration in net set ads from consoles now that the no-disk is required?
componenttext: He had one additional question. Are you experiencing an acceleration in net set ads from consoles now that the no-disk is required?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That only -- the no-disk requirement has only lifted three, four days ago. So we're just in the process of rolling that out. We'll be able to comment more on that next quarter.
componenttext: That only -- the no-disk requirement has only lifted three, four days ago. So we're just in the process of rolling that out. We'll be able to comment more on that next quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next couple of questions are from George Askew at Stifel, Nicolaus. The streaming-only test in the U.S. offers a streaming-only plan for $7.99 per month and a streaming plus DVD plan at $9.99 per month. Other than price, is there a difference between
componenttext: The next couple of questions are from George Askew at Stifel, Nicolaus. The streaming-only test in the U.S. offers a streaming-only plan for $7.99 per month and a streaming plus DVD plan at $9.99 per month. Other than price, is there a difference between the $9.99 plan you are testing and the existing $8.99 streaming-plus-DVD plan? Also, if you launch the streaming-only service, does that mean the $8.99 price point will go away?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: George, that's one test sell of many that you are referring to, which is the $7.99 and $9.99 variants. And to answer you're precise question, the $9.99 in that test sell is the same as the $8.99 today.
componenttext: George, that's one test sell of many that you are referring to, which is the $7.99 and $9.99 variants. And to answer you're precise question, the $9.99 in that test sell is the same as the $8.99 today.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from George Askew. An important driver of growth has been the Consumer Electronics partnership. At this point, with the exception of Android, Netflix seems to be on most major connected platforms. What platforms or devices are yet to be pe
componenttext: Second question from George Askew. An important driver of growth has been the Consumer Electronics partnership. At this point, with the exception of Android, Netflix seems to be on most major connected platforms. What platforms or devices are yet to be penetrated by Netflix?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: George, you're right that weve had tremendous progress in getting integrated. The big push over the next two years will be as more and more TVs are internet TVs, they have WiFi built-in. And we'll march along with that. But today, there's still a fair
componenttext: George, you're right that weve had tremendous progress in getting integrated. The big push over the next two years will be as more and more TVs are internet TVs, they have WiFi built-in. And we'll march along with that. But today, there's still a fair amount of TV sold that don't have WiFi. So that's the big push in terms of breadth. And then in terms of quality, we're upgrading the user interfaces in all of these devices, really, at web speed in the search of what that best user interface is for TV, and that will vary somewhat by screen and input device. So we've got a big investment program across all of those platforms.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. How does Netflix can give up the cable service provider? Are they long-term collaborators or adversaries?
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. How does Netflix can give up the cable service provider? Are they long-term collaborators or adversaries?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's two parts to a cable service, or at least three parts: voice, data and video. To the video side, we're mostly competitor except that we're at a very different price point with a very small fraction of their content. That's the analogy I use
componenttext: Well, there's two parts to a cable service, or at least three parts: voice, data and video. To the video side, we're mostly competitor except that we're at a very different price point with a very small fraction of their content. That's the analogy I use of were the motorcycle and theyre the car. But on balance, we're competitive. To data, we're huge ally, drives a lot of data adoption, larger plans so very aligned. And voice, no interaction with them.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Among the content available on Watch Instantly, are you seeing greater demand for movies, broadcast TV shows or pay-TV shows like Showtime? What is the average number of minutes per streaming sessi
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Among the content available on Watch Instantly, are you seeing greater demand for movies, broadcast TV shows or pay-TV shows like Showtime? What is the average number of minutes per streaming session? And do people tend to come back and finish a movie or show if interrupted?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, with the content availability, we don't see greater demand for one or the other. We don't divide it up by broadcast or pay or cable network. We're just looking for great shows that we can license for our subscribers. We don't disclose the average n
componenttext: Jason, with the content availability, we don't see greater demand for one or the other. We don't divide it up by broadcast or pay or cable network. We're just looking for great shows that we can license for our subscribers. We don't disclose the average number of minutes per streaming session. And yes, lots of people come back to finish movies and TV shows, so they'll be watching on the television and then they're in the car and they finish on iPod or the iPhone and there's all those different -- and they move to a different room and they get to restart and of course, our software is smart enough to restart them in the right place so that all works very well. As you would expect an Internet-oriented service to work.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Daniel Ernst at Hudson Square Research. Do you have a sense for what percentage of subscriber are viewing Instant Watch on their television versus a PC?
componenttext: The next question is from Daniel Ernst at Hudson Square Research. Do you have a sense for what percentage of subscriber are viewing Instant Watch on their television versus a PC?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, for us, they're all just screens. There's 4-inch screens that are on mobile phones. There's 9-inch screens on iPad, 12-inch screens on laptops, and then a wide variety of television size screens from 20 to 100 inches. And that's not a key determin
componenttext: Daniel, for us, they're all just screens. There's 4-inch screens that are on mobile phones. There's 9-inch screens on iPad, 12-inch screens on laptops, and then a wide variety of television size screens from 20 to 100 inches. And that's not a key determinant for us. And it's not something that I can give any more color on.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Dan Ernst. Do you have a sense for what percentage of subscribers in the quarter or perhaps year-to-date that are returning subscribers, i.e. previous subscribers who have come back to Netflix?
componenttext: Second question from Dan Ernst. Do you have a sense for what percentage of subscribers in the quarter or perhaps year-to-date that are returning subscribers, i.e. previous subscribers who have come back to Netflix?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, the percentage historically has been running about a third, slightly higher, and with the acceleration in growth, the percentage has followed it a little bit.
componenttext: Actually, the percentage historically has been running about a third, slightly higher, and with the acceleration in growth, the percentage has followed it a little bit.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Fitzgerald of UBS. How do you think about streaming content cost per user in the future in light of the recent and upcoming content deals? Will it be pretty balanced in terms of streaming content cost being offset by analog
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Fitzgerald of UBS. How do you think about streaming content cost per user in the future in light of the recent and upcoming content deals? Will it be pretty balanced in terms of streaming content cost being offset by analogous postal increases? Or will it be lumpy if certain deals come in or maybe build to its inflection point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's likely to be some lumps. It's not going to be completely smooth. Epics is a great example where we're stepping forward on that one and that's pressuring the margins in Q4. And as we grow into that over next year, that will smooth out. But in terms
componenttext: There's likely to be some lumps. It's not going to be completely smooth. Epics is a great example where we're stepping forward on that one and that's pressuring the margins in Q4. And as we grow into that over next year, that will smooth out. But in terms of the long-term margin structure, we would like to try to keep it between 30% and 35% gross margin, replacing the postal cost with content cost.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. There are now 200 plus Netflix-enabled products that will result in 60-million-plus devices sold in 2010. Could you give a rough break of e tpercentage that is maybe exclusive and maybe rough estimates of wha
componenttext: Another question from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. There are now 200 plus Netflix-enabled products that will result in 60-million-plus devices sold in 2010. Could you give a rough break of e tpercentage that is maybe exclusive and maybe rough estimates of what these numbers look like for 2011? Any rough spots on TV for set-top boxes versus tables versus the PCs versus mobile phone?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think -- there's no material set of devices that are exclusive. Basically with software, it tends to be applications to our architectures. And so none of the devices, at least there's no material ones that I can think of that are exclusive. In ter
componenttext: I don't think -- there's no material set of devices that are exclusive. Basically with software, it tends to be applications to our architectures. And so none of the devices, at least there's no material ones that I can think of that are exclusive. In terms of the number of devices, that's probably not the relevant thing. The next hundred devices are the hundred smaller devices than the initial 200. So really it's coverage. Again, the big change over the next two years is WiFi getting built into more TVs. And as that happens whether it's got the Google TV software built into it or it's got our native client, both work really well, that's the big change in the industry.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next few questions are from Andy Hargreaves of Pacific Crest. Do any of the content deals youve signed give rights for global distribution? Or you have to renegotiate for each geography?
componenttext: The next few questions are from Andy Hargreaves of Pacific Crest. Do any of the content deals youve signed give rights for global distribution? Or you have to renegotiate for each geography?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Andy, the general pattern is per geography because it mirrors the other distribution channels.
componenttext: Andy, the general pattern is per geography because it mirrors the other distribution channels.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Andy Hargreaves. Are the majority of the streaming deals you are signing still fixed?
componenttext: Next question from Andy Hargreaves. Are the majority of the streaming deals you are signing still fixed?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Andy, we like to think of them as fixed because they generally are in the short term. But then when it comes to renegotiation time, it ends up in some long-term basis, sharing our upside with the content owners as we grow.
componenttext: Well, Andy, we like to think of them as fixed because they generally are in the short term. But then when it comes to renegotiation time, it ends up in some long-term basis, sharing our upside with the content owners as we grow.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the final question from Andy Hargreaves of Pacific Crest. Can you explain in more detail the music rights impact? Where and why were you paying $3.5 million for music rights before?
componenttext: And the final question from Andy Hargreaves of Pacific Crest. Can you explain in more detail the music rights impact? Where and why were you paying $3.5 million for music rights before?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure if the question requires an explanation of what music rights are as the public performance rights or the notes in the words associated with the music that's synched in the TV and movie content that we stream over the Internet. There is public
componenttext: I'm not sure if the question requires an explanation of what music rights are as the public performance rights or the notes in the words associated with the music that's synched in the TV and movie content that we stream over the Internet. There is public performance rights acquired from one of three rights societies, ASCAP, SESAC, BMI. Two of those, ASCAP and BMI, involve re-courts for the setting of rates. Rates are in dispute and so as a consequence, we, through time, have made estimates about -- that relates to our expectations for license fees associated with the public performance of the music and thereve been some recent decisions in the courts which have caused us to rethink the amount of money we had set aside for the public performance rights. So it's a monthly accrual. And then eventually when license fees are struck, they'll be an exchange of moneys and we'll move on. But right now, it's a hanging accrual in the balance sheet.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And coming back to an earlier question I referred to, starting to target 30% to 35% gross margin of -- that new content deals replace the postage, and that is true in North America. If we do global aggressively in the short term as we launch, that will be
componenttext: And coming back to an earlier question I referred to, starting to target 30% to 35% gross margin of -- that new content deals replace the postage, and that is true in North America. If we do global aggressively in the short term as we launch, that will be different. But the goal statement is true in the long term globally and on an ongoing basis in North America.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord Genuity. Could you talk about the level of adoption or activation levels you're seeing with the variety of web-enabled devices in the marketplace such as web-enabled TVs, Apple products, such as the iPad
componenttext: The next question is from Wayne Chang at Canaccord Genuity. Could you talk about the level of adoption or activation levels you're seeing with the variety of web-enabled devices in the marketplace such as web-enabled TVs, Apple products, such as the iPad or other tablet-like devices and even gaming consoles? Are mobile handsets becoming a key driver to driving new subscriber activations? Or does the opportunity remain still relatively early?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wayne, for music services, mobile is the core and then the more living-room based formats are an auxiliary. And with the video format, it's the inverse. So the living-room formats and the laptop formats and iPad formats are quite large. And the mobiles
componenttext: Wayne, for music services, mobile is the core and then the more living-room based formats are an auxiliary. And with the video format, it's the inverse. So the living-room formats and the laptop formats and iPad formats are quite large. And the mobiles a good supplement, but it's relatively modest.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jim Friedland at Cowen. Regarding Canada streaming. In the comment, you indicated that the Canadian business is on track to breakeven in the second half of next year. Does that imply that your Canadian content deals scale with su
componenttext: The next question is from Jim Friedland at Cowen. Regarding Canada streaming. In the comment, you indicated that the Canadian business is on track to breakeven in the second half of next year. Does that imply that your Canadian content deals scale with subscriber growth? Or are you paying big upfront fees to streaming content regardless of the number of subscribers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, that would be the latter.
componenttext: Jim, that would be the latter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And second question from Jim Friedland at Cowen. With regards to U.S. streaming, do you think the long-term operating margins of a digital-only business are similar to the margins of the business today around 12% flat?
componenttext: And second question from Jim Friedland at Cowen. With regards to U.S. streaming, do you think the long-term operating margins of a digital-only business are similar to the margins of the business today around 12% flat?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The long-term margins are really driven by competition because that really influences the pricing. So you'd have to tell me what the competitive environment is to get what the long-term operating margins are. It will be again significantly influenced by t
componenttext: The long-term margins are really driven by competition because that really influences the pricing. So you'd have to tell me what the competitive environment is to get what the long-term operating margins are. It will be again significantly influenced by the amount of competition. And at this point, we don't know what that will be.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from John Blackledge of Crdit Suisse. What was change in disk shipments per sub per month in Q3 2010 on a year-over-year basis? I think in Q2 2010, disk shipments were down about 20% year-over-year. Just wondering if you would expec
componenttext: The next question is from John Blackledge of Crdit Suisse. What was change in disk shipments per sub per month in Q3 2010 on a year-over-year basis? I think in Q2 2010, disk shipments were down about 20% year-over-year. Just wondering if you would expect the decline to accelerate in the near term or stay around Q2, Q3 levels.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, as I said in an answer to an earlier question, we're not breaking out the disk usage per sub per month. I think the only color commentary we gave was in Reed's remarks, and he pointed out that total shipments had grown on a year-over-year basis by a
componenttext: John, as I said in an answer to an earlier question, we're not breaking out the disk usage per sub per month. I think the only color commentary we gave was in Reed's remarks, and he pointed out that total shipments had grown on a year-over-year basis by about 10%.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard Capital Market. Impact on other forms of entertainment consumption. Our young children love Netflix and Watch Instantly on the iPad. For that reason, we're not inclined to buy more kids DVDs. They get mo
componenttext: The next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard Capital Market. Impact on other forms of entertainment consumption. Our young children love Netflix and Watch Instantly on the iPad. For that reason, we're not inclined to buy more kids DVDs. They get more than enough content from the Pixar and Disney movies and PBS kids shows on Netflix. Are there other Netflix subscribers like us? Do you see any evidence that people are buying fewer DVDs as they stream more Netflix content? Could you also update us on the cord-cutting question? Do you still profess to see no evidence that Netflix subscribers are cutting the cord?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the latter part on cord cutting, we still see no evidence that our subs cut cords at greater rates than the general population. And it's something we survey now and then on. On your personal experience, it's all over the map. We have tons of anecdotes
componenttext: On the latter part on cord cutting, we still see no evidence that our subs cut cords at greater rates than the general population. And it's something we survey now and then on. On your personal experience, it's all over the map. We have tons of anecdotes of people who the streaming stimulates their usage in other formats, like you said, that streaming meets most of their entertainment need. So quite a lot of variety with 17 million members.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next two questions are from Michael Pachter at Wedbush. The press release says that in Q4, a majority of Netflix subscribers will watch more content streamed from Netflix than delivered on DVD. Does "more content" mean more hours of content or a great
componenttext: The next two questions are from Michael Pachter at Wedbush. The press release says that in Q4, a majority of Netflix subscribers will watch more content streamed from Netflix than delivered on DVD. Does "more content" mean more hours of content or a greater number of streaming sessions than DVD transactions?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, that's at more hours. We're measuring everything to combine it by the hours.
componenttext: Michael, that's at more hours. We're measuring everything to combine it by the hours.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Michael Pachter.  Also, the following sentence says that the business will have transitioned from mostly DVDs to mostly streaming. If more than 50% of users consume more than 50% of their content via streaming, I can see how you could
componenttext: Second question from Michael Pachter.  Also, the following sentence says that the business will have transitioned from mostly DVDs to mostly streaming. If more than 50% of users consume more than 50% of their content via streaming, I can see how you could say mostly streaming for those customers. But I presume that the 34% of customers who don't use streaming get 100% of their content via DVD, so I don't see how you conclude that more than 50% of content is streaming. Would you please clarify what you're talking about and give us the split in terms of hours spent? It really doesn't make sense and the second sentence implies that over half of all hours spent are spent watching streaming but the metrics you provide don't support that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's just a math question here, Michael. We track how many DVDs we shipped and we track that one length, and we make an assumption that each DVD is watched once. So you could say some are never watched and some are watched twice, but we assume watched onc
componenttext: It's just a math question here, Michael. We track how many DVDs we shipped and we track that one length, and we make an assumption that each DVD is watched once. So you could say some are never watched and some are watched twice, but we assume watched once. And then we look at the streaming hours that we're delivering and compare those. So we're saying two things which are independent. One is that the total number of minutes of entertainment delivered by Netflix is higher on streaming than on DVD. Second, majority of our members, so more than 50% in Q4, will watch a majority of their content by minutes on streaming than on DVD, which basically gets you a distribution measure. It says that it's not that say, 10% of the streamers are watching an enormous amount of content and everyone else is majority DVD. So it's two views. Total view were more streaming, and from a subscriber view, the majority of our subscribers, consume majority of their content on streaming than DVD.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Doug Mitchelson at Deutsche Bank Security. How much of your churn comes from subscribers that are on free promotion? Asked another way, how low is your churn rate on core Netflix subscribers? Say those two have been subscribers f
componenttext: The next question is from Doug Mitchelson at Deutsche Bank Security. How much of your churn comes from subscribers that are on free promotion? Asked another way, how low is your churn rate on core Netflix subscribers? Say those two have been subscribers for over three months or six months or one year, however you measure it. The obvious reason for the question is we do not typically see consumer subscriber businesses grow so fast while sustaining such a high churn rate. It should settle down to a lower level to the extent you are offering a good price value.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Barry, let me tackle that question. We don't normally see subscriber growth businesses grow this fast. So there are two cohorts essentially to focus on with respect to churn. There are the free trial subscribers you referred to. And we see slightl
componenttext: This is Barry, let me tackle that question. We don't normally see subscriber growth businesses grow this fast. So there are two cohorts essentially to focus on with respect to churn. There are the free trial subscribers you referred to. And we see slightly lower -- well, we anticipate we are seeing slightly lower conversion rates in Canada than wed see in the U.S. So let me just focus on the U.S. where we have a rich history. And we said repeatedly through time and it remains true today, but about nine in 10 subscribers who take a free trial become a paying subscriber. So great conversion rate, but that implies one in 10 free trial subscribers dropout, that's a 10% churn rate. So point one, as it relates to the paying subscribers, a churn declines over time. And if you'd been here for 12 months or longer and more than half of subscribers have been here for more than 12 months, then your churn rate is in the 2% range or lower. So not terribly dissimilar from churn rates for basic cable, which is in the 1.5% range. And of course, whether or not that churn rate is sustainable from a financial perspective, also depends on what the acquisition cost is. And of course, we're at historical low acquisition costs because of investment we've made in improving the quality service and streaming. And then I suppose the follow-up question might be well, how does retention rates for streaming customers compare with retention rates on DVD-only customers? And because of the improvements we've made in the quality of the streaming service, we're going to have to say that actually retention for streaming customers has just crossed over the retention for DVD-only customers, so it's actually better now for streaming only. And that's important, of course, because the majority of the growth is streaming related.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Edward Williams at BMO. As subscriber growth has grown due to streaming, how has the demographics of the Netflix subscriber changed?
componenttext: The next question is from Edward Williams at BMO. As subscriber growth has grown due to streaming, how has the demographics of the Netflix subscriber changed?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not significantly. We're still pretty much the broad Internet demographic that has credit cards.
componenttext: Not significantly. We're still pretty much the broad Internet demographic that has credit cards.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next couple of questions are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given the number of deals you made on the content side in Q3, are you still seeing opportunities to continue to aggressively invest in digital content?
componenttext: The next couple of questions are from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. Given the number of deals you made on the content side in Q3, are you still seeing opportunities to continue to aggressively invest in digital content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, we're pretty spent up for Q4, but we're three weeks into the quarter already so that probably makes sense. And we have a lot of opportunity next year as the subscriber base continues to grow.
componenttext: Scott, we're pretty spent up for Q4, but we're three weeks into the quarter already so that probably makes sense. And we have a lot of opportunity next year as the subscriber base continues to grow.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Scott Devitt. With the rollout of the new Disc-Free applications on Wii and PS3, you seem to be focusing a lot on reducing friction, improving the user interface and increasing search functionality. Are there any other areas you hope
componenttext: Second question from Scott Devitt. With the rollout of the new Disc-Free applications on Wii and PS3, you seem to be focusing a lot on reducing friction, improving the user interface and increasing search functionality. Are there any other areas you hope to focus on in order to differentiate your streaming products from other video applications from a technology standpoint?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not particularly, Scott. I would say that any technology advantage quickly gets copied. So we try to do great work, and we're improving the UI, but obviously, all the great work that we do there will be quickly copied within a year or two by anybody who w
componenttext: Not particularly, Scott. I would say that any technology advantage quickly gets copied. So we try to do great work, and we're improving the UI, but obviously, all the great work that we do there will be quickly copied within a year or two by anybody who wants to.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That next questions are from Eric Wold at MCF. In the prepared remarks, you state that Q4 will experience year-over-year reductions in marketing spending. Are you referring to the overall dollar amount or SAC?
componenttext: That next questions are from Eric Wold at MCF. In the prepared remarks, you state that Q4 will experience year-over-year reductions in marketing spending. Are you referring to the overall dollar amount or SAC?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Both.
componenttext: Both.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Eric Wold. The DVD shipments continued to flow or even decline in certain markets like the Bay Area. At what point would you consider closing distribution centers or is there always need to stay in place for the next day delivery bene
componenttext: Second question from Eric Wold. The DVD shipments continued to flow or even decline in certain markets like the Bay Area. At what point would you consider closing distribution centers or is there always need to stay in place for the next day delivery benefit?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mostly the latter, Eric. Over a sufficient number of years, the volume come down by 50%. There might be some small closures probably many, many years out.
componenttext: Mostly the latter, Eric. Over a sufficient number of years, the volume come down by 50%. There might be some small closures probably many, many years out.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Do you believe MSOs will move to usage base billing as part of the FCC debate over title's theory? Do you see an opportunity to use compression techniques to minimize bandwidth if that is th
componenttext: The next question is from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Do you believe MSOs will move to usage base billing as part of the FCC debate over title's theory? Do you see an opportunity to use compression techniques to minimize bandwidth if that is the case?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a key question, Tony, and a good one. We have some vulnerability depending on cap usage and what happens. Comcast has a cap but it's 250 gigabytes, and so most users feel that they have an unlimited experience and it gives us plenty of room to delive
componenttext: It's a key question, Tony, and a good one. We have some vulnerability depending on cap usage and what happens. Comcast has a cap but it's 250 gigabytes, and so most users feel that they have an unlimited experience and it gives us plenty of room to deliver a high-def stream. On the other hand, AT&T mobile data on an iPad is now capped to two gigabytes. So not enough room to deliver hours and hours of high-def. There's not a lot of improvement in compression techniques, but what we can do is just deliver a lower bit stream, a lower quality video experience. So, for example, not too high-def. So that's one possible way to partially mitigate that impact. But we're definitely sensitive, as you pointed out, to -- in the long term, just most of the industry end up at 250 gigabytes or two at the other extreme.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Arthur Mangriotis [ph] at Fox Point Capital. Please elaborate on your comment that the international competitive window will only be opened temporarily.
componenttext: The next question is from Arthur Mangriotis [ph] at Fox Point Capital. Please elaborate on your comment that the international competitive window will only be opened temporarily.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Arthur, broadband is growing rapidly across the world, and that creates an opportunity for us and potentially for others. And five or 10 years from now, you'd have to believe that if we're not, there are other people will be. So that's what we're re
componenttext: Well, Arthur, broadband is growing rapidly across the world, and that creates an opportunity for us and potentially for others. And five or 10 years from now, you'd have to believe that if we're not, there are other people will be. So that's what we're referring to.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That next question is from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. Is stock down more because you deliberately push marketing dollars toward content cost? Or as a result of the strong subscriber growth? i.e. If you go into the quarter and tending to spend a bit less on
componenttext: That next question is from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. Is stock down more because you deliberately push marketing dollars toward content cost? Or as a result of the strong subscriber growth? i.e. If you go into the quarter and tending to spend a bit less on acquisition?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We spent to our plan. Marketing spending as a percent of revenue was up slightly on a Q-over-Q basis and on a year-over-year basis. And the decrease in SAC reflects the increase in the organic growth, which is a function of the increased investment we'll
componenttext: We spent to our plan. Marketing spending as a percent of revenue was up slightly on a Q-over-Q basis and on a year-over-year basis. And the decrease in SAC reflects the increase in the organic growth, which is a function of the increased investment we'll be making in the licensing of streamed content. So historically, you have heard me talk about in a relationship between gross margin SAC and churn and the way in which we play one off against the other in order to increase the overall growth rate and enterprise value associated with the growth in subscribers. And that's what you see it play here.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as Barry mentioned in his written comments as part of absorbing the FX lump, well be spending lighter on marketing in Q4 than historically we would, and that will have therefore lower gross margins and lower SAC than you're used to seeing from us.
componenttext: And as Barry mentioned in his written comments as part of absorbing the FX lump, well be spending lighter on marketing in Q4 than historically we would, and that will have therefore lower gross margins and lower SAC than you're used to seeing from us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. What are you doing differently in terms of distribution centers as we prepare for overall disc business to decline? I know your focus on continued automation and efficiency, but do you have broader plans yet
componenttext: Another question from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. What are you doing differently in terms of distribution centers as we prepare for overall disc business to decline? I know your focus on continued automation and efficiency, but do you have broader plans yet on how you'll ultimately scale back these facilities over time?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Nationwide, our DVD shipments are still growing about 10% year-over-year. So right now, we're trying to figure out how to handle the increased load and get our new automation deployed quickly. So I'm sure someday, we'll have to think about the issues you
componenttext: Nationwide, our DVD shipments are still growing about 10% year-over-year. So right now, we're trying to figure out how to handle the increased load and get our new automation deployed quickly. So I'm sure someday, we'll have to think about the issues you referred to but not in the near term.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question from Michael Olson at Piper Jaffray. Question for Barry. With your comment in the prepared remarks regarding Q4 guidance where you say year-over-year reductions in marketing spending will mostly fund the increased content spending. Is the
componenttext: Another question from Michael Olson at Piper Jaffray. Question for Barry. With your comment in the prepared remarks regarding Q4 guidance where you say year-over-year reductions in marketing spending will mostly fund the increased content spending. Is the Q4 marketing spend on a dollar basis will be down year-over-year in Q4, or are you saying it will be down year-over-year as a percentage of revenue?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It will be down as a percentage of revenue, and it will be down Q-over-Q.
componenttext: It will be down as a percentage of revenue, and it will be down Q-over-Q.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Doug Robinson, a private investor. When will the Android cellphone be supported for streaming apps?
componenttext: The next question is from Doug Robinson, a private investor. When will the Android cellphone be supported for streaming apps?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're working on Android now. And as soon as we have something to announce, we'll announce that.
componenttext: We're working on Android now. And as soon as we have something to announce, we'll announce that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd like to supplement my previous answer as it relates to marketing spending. Id like to make a slightly different point. I want to remind everyone on the call that earnings is a managed outcome. And so there had been many quarters in the past, by way
componenttext: I'd like to supplement my previous answer as it relates to marketing spending. Id like to make a slightly different point. I want to remind everyone on the call that earnings is a managed outcome. And so there had been many quarters in the past, by way of example, the fourth quarter of last year, where if memory serves me, during the quarter, because the business was much more profitable than we forecasted it was going to be -- we allocated during the quarter an additional spending to marketing of something like $6 million. We delivered the earnings number wed forecast we were going to deliver and we were also able to deliver more growth in part because we were able to invest more marketing dollars. So if as Q4 unfolds similar dynamic occurs relative to our forecast, and we have the wind in our back and we would be anxious to invest additional money in marketing because it will further accelerate our growth. But based on our plan, we're expecting the answer I gave which is a decrease both on a percentage basis and a decrease Q-over-Q in terms of absolute dollars spent on marketing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question from Barton Crockett at Lazard with regards to the Starz deal. Starz received net-of-selling fees of close to $2 per subscriber per month while providing its flagship Starz encore package to cable. In my observation, the line-up of Starz
componenttext: Another question from Barton Crockett at Lazard with regards to the Starz deal. Starz received net-of-selling fees of close to $2 per subscriber per month while providing its flagship Starz encore package to cable. In my observation, the line-up of Starz content on Netflix is better than on cable into more title availability, easier navigation, et cetera. In your renewal talks with Starz, is it conceivable that Netflix could pay rates to Starz content comparable to what cables pay? Can you comment generally on your optimism or skepticism about the successful renewal of the Starz deal?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, I can't comment on the specifics. And I'm optimistic in the long term that is we have money to pay, and they're in the business of collecting money. So there's no reason in the long term strategically it shouldn't work out. How soon and w
componenttext: Well, obviously, I can't comment on the specifics. And I'm optimistic in the long term that is we have money to pay, and they're in the business of collecting money. So there's no reason in the long term strategically it shouldn't work out. How soon and whether there are hiccups along the way, I'd like see in so many content-supplier relationship that's DVD. But with the breadth of our content offered, we'll be fine and we look forward to working on that deal.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Final question. It's from Michael Pachter at Wedbush. Since postage hasn't decline precipitously, you're really saying that overall consumption of entertainment is up a lot, DVD usage down a little and streaming up a lot. That's a high cost problem and co
componenttext: Final question. It's from Michael Pachter at Wedbush. Since postage hasn't decline precipitously, you're really saying that overall consumption of entertainment is up a lot, DVD usage down a little and streaming up a lot. That's a high cost problem and consists a higher value proposition. Could you confirm that I'm reading the response correctly?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the only thing that I heard in that question was the DVD down, but DVD is actually up. It emphasizes your theme that DVD is growing slowly for us -- DVD shipment -- and streaming is growing rapidly. But I'm not sure if I heard the question.
componenttext: Well, the only thing that I heard in that question was the DVD down, but DVD is actually up. It emphasizes your theme that DVD is growing slowly for us -- DVD shipment -- and streaming is growing rapidly. But I'm not sure if I heard the question.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's right. That was the question. Do you really think an overall consumption is up a lot? So usage per sub down a little and streaming up a lot. Is DVD usage on a per sub-basis down?
componenttext: That's right. That was the question. Do you really think an overall consumption is up a lot? So usage per sub down a little and streaming up a lot. Is DVD usage on a per sub-basis down?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a 50% sub growth and probably 10% shipment growth.
componenttext: That's a 50% sub growth and probably 10% shipment growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the question is on a per sub basis, are you seeing greater consumption? Are you seeing greater consumption of entertainment? And I think the answer to that is yes. So said differently, subscribers are extracting more value from the service than th
componenttext: I think the question is on a per sub basis, are you seeing greater consumption? Are you seeing greater consumption of entertainment? And I think the answer to that is yes. So said differently, subscribers are extracting more value from the service than they have historically, which I think explains in part one the increased organic growth and the decline in subscriber acquisition cost and two the continued decrease in churn.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's the last question I have. Before we conclude the call, I'd like to turn this call back over to Reed for a few brief closing remarks.
componenttext: That's the last question I have. Before we conclude the call, I'd like to turn this call back over to Reed for a few brief closing remarks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us today. Hopefully, we answered all your questions efficiently. There's a lot to talk about this quarter. The year-over-year subscriber growth at 52% is accelerating, more content, more device partnerships, our entry into Canada. And b
componenttext: Thanks for joining us today. Hopefully, we answered all your questions efficiently. There's a lot to talk about this quarter. The year-over-year subscriber growth at 52% is accelerating, more content, more device partnerships, our entry into Canada. And by any measure, our evolution to a streaming company has just been phenomenal. I think you'll see that evolution even more clearly when we report our fourth quarter results and look forward to talking with you then. Thank you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, everyone.
componenttext: Thanks, everyone.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation on today's conference. This does conclude the program, and you may now disconnect.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation on today's conference. This does conclude the program, and you may now disconnect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Netflix third quarter 2010 earnings Q&A session. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Plea
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Netflix third quarter 2010 earnings Q&A session. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix third quarter 2010 earnings Q&A session. We released earnings for the third quarter at approximately 1.05 PM Pacific Time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's resu
componenttext:
Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix third quarter 2010 earnings Q&A session. We released earnings for the third quarter at approximately 1.05 PM Pacific Time today. The earnings press release, management's commentary on the quarter's results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the Company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com.
As is our standard practice, this call will consist solely of Q&A and we are going to conduct the Q&A via email. Please email your questions to ir@netflix.com. We may make forward looking statements during this call regarding the Company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business.
A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our Annual Report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 22nd, 2010. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6.00 PM Pacific Time today. With that, lets begin the Q&A session.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jeffries. How important is exclusivity of content in Netflix when doing digital deals?
componenttext: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jeffries. How important is exclusivity of content in Netflix when doing digital deals?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, its Reed here. Its not inherently important to us, but many of the other buyers are exclusive and I am interested in non-exclusive content. But we end up doing exclusive sometimes basically to play with the way that market is today. And tha
componenttext: Youssef, its Reed here. Its not inherently important to us, but many of the other buyers are exclusive and I am interested in non-exclusive content. But we end up doing exclusive sometimes basically to play with the way that market is today. And that has some benefits for us also. But its not yet a core strategy. Over a sufficient number of years, it could become a core strategy, but we havent made that determination.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Youssef. What is the percentage of the subscriber base that get Blu-ray today versus one year ago?
componenttext: Second question from Youssef. What is the percentage of the subscriber base that get Blu-ray today versus one year ago?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Youssef, its up from a year ago, but its pretty flat in recent quarters. So, now its still a nice little part of the business and its fine for us.
componenttext: Youssef, its up from a year ago, but its pretty flat in recent quarters. So, now its still a nice little part of the business and its fine for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mike Olson at Piper Jaffray. What are your thoughts on pricing? I realize you are in grabbing share mode, but I think its occurred to us churn would not be significantly impacted by a $1 per months price increase. And you coul
componenttext: The next question is from Mike Olson at Piper Jaffray. What are your thoughts on pricing? I realize you are in grabbing share mode, but I think its occurred to us churn would not be significantly impacted by a $1 per months price increase. And you could argue that higher pricing would allow you to spend more on new content, thereby attracting new sets and reducing churn. How are you thinking about this?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Its Barry. You know from previous calls in response to questions about pricing we had frequently reminded our listeners that we are testing all the time and some of you (inaudible) price test in the marketplace currently. Obviously, the pricing in Cana
componenttext: Its Barry. You know from previous calls in response to questions about pricing we had frequently reminded our listeners that we are testing all the time and some of you (inaudible) price test in the marketplace currently. Obviously, the pricing in Canada is working off for us and may be that will or will not play for us in the U.S. and as we continue to read test results, well continue to update our thinking about pricing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. Would you expect the relatively higher mix of TV show consumption via streaming versus via DVD to continue going forward or do you expect it to come down as you build out more movie selec
componenttext: The next question is from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. Would you expect the relatively higher mix of TV show consumption via streaming versus via DVD to continue going forward or do you expect it to come down as you build out more movie selection? Is there something about streaming usage that tends to lend itself more to quick TV show consumption?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, Id say that were trying to figure out what next consumers want as opposed to trying to guide that and so we are trying to get a broad selection of content both in movies and in TV shows. And currently, the subscribers (inaudible) in about equa
componenttext: Mark, Id say that were trying to figure out what next consumers want as opposed to trying to guide that and so we are trying to get a broad selection of content both in movies and in TV shows. And currently, the subscribers (inaudible) in about equal proportion and the way we measure it is by - not by stream starts or session starts, but by total minutes watched. So, movies get a little bit of an advantage in minutes watched because they are longer. But we are not trying to drive it one way or the other. We are just trying to build out a whole lot of content that our subscribers want to watch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question from Mark Mahaney. Are there earlier indications that recent free subscribers convert to pay subscribers at the same rate as they have for you historically?
componenttext: Second question from Mark Mahaney. Are there earlier indications that recent free subscribers convert to pay subscribers at the same rate as they have for you historically?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry, is the question, is the P1 conversion rate whole and constant with historical levels, answer to that question is yes.
componenttext: Sorry, is the question, is the P1 conversion rate whole and constant with historical levels, answer to that question is yes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Steve Frankel at Dougherty & Company. You commented that the increase in free subscribers was a reflection of both faster U.S. growth and the initial push into Canada. Do you expect free subs to remain at these higher levels rela
componenttext: Our next question is from Steve Frankel at Dougherty & Company. You commented that the increase in free subscribers was a reflection of both faster U.S. growth and the initial push into Canada. Do you expect free subs to remain at these higher levels relative to the historical norm or will it normalize in the next quarter or two?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it may normalize eventually, but particularly in - Q4 tends to be seasonally - see fast subscriber growth around the holidays, which tends to be back end loaded and Q1 tends to be front-end loaded. So for at least Q4, that trend likely continues.
componenttext: Well, it may normalize eventually, but particularly in - Q4 tends to be seasonally - see fast subscriber growth around the holidays, which tends to be back end loaded and Q1 tends to be front-end loaded. So for at least Q4, that trend likely continues.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question from Steve Frankel. Can you clarify for me what your current operating margin goals are and do you anticipate that expansion beyond North America in the back half of 2011 would at least in early going drop operating margins materially below
componenttext: Next question from Steve Frankel. Can you clarify for me what your current operating margin goals are and do you anticipate that expansion beyond North America in the back half of 2011 would at least in early going drop operating margins materially below that level?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you can infer from our guidance forecast for Q4 based on the mid-point of earnings that the operating margin come in pretty roughly 12.5%, so slightly higher than the 12% that we had spoken about. And in Reeds commentary you know that for 2011 we
componenttext: Yes, you can infer from our guidance forecast for Q4 based on the mid-point of earnings that the operating margin come in pretty roughly 12.5%, so slightly higher than the 12% that we had spoken about. And in Reeds commentary you know that for 2011 we are guiding towards a 12% on the North American business and that we - if we continue to track in Canada on the current trend line to move towards additional investments internationally and in his commentary Reed spoke about a $50 million investment to support that expansion.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: One final question from Steve Frankel. Reed commented that the company spends $500 million per year in postage. This is down from the $600 million figure the company has mentioned in the past. Has the increase in streaming already scaled back the postal e
componenttext: One final question from Steve Frankel. Reed commented that the company spends $500 million per year in postage. This is down from the $600 million figure the company has mentioned in the past. Has the increase in streaming already scaled back the postal expense by that amount?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, no, postage is still rising. Its between $500 million and $600 million, so my comments in todays press was over $500 million.
componenttext: Steve, no, postage is still rising. Its between $500 million and $600 million, so my comments in todays press was over $500 million.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Nat Schindler, BofA-Merrill Lynch. Several years ago when the two-out-at-a-time option was your most popular, you said that the average user rented about five DVDs per month on average. Now, with the one-out-a-time option becoming do
componenttext:
Next question is from Nat Schindler, BofA-Merrill Lynch. Several years ago when the two-out-at-a-time option was your most popular, you said that the average user rented about five DVDs per month on average. Now, with the one-out-a-time option becoming dominant, where has this number gone?
Also, have you seen a change to the average DVDs rented by customers as you add additional streaming content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as it relates to DVD usage, we havent for quite some time reported on the average usage across the days except to say that its declined and there have been two principal drivers, one, of course, is the mix change in the business with the incre
